To be able to continue working and to augment their earnings, they would like to receive investment in their business, for which the group asks for a loan to acquire merchandise to sell; like clothes, hats, scissors, needles, threads, shoes, school supplies, in addition to ingredients and merchandise to sell, like meat, fruits, vegetables, vinegar, flower, dairy products, rice, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva volunteer.

Las integrantes de este comité se dedican a variadas actividades entre las que se puede destacar la venta de ropas, comidas rápidas como empanadas, tortillas, croquetas asaditos de carne etc.; otras se dedican al reciclaje de cartón, plástico, y todo tipo de metales en desuso. Además de manejar sus microempresas ellas en su mayoría son cabeza de hogar y se encargan de administrar los ingresos, cuidar de la educación de sus hijos y los cuidados de la casa.

Actualmente este comité se encuentra en su sexto ciclo del programa lo que demuestra que son un grupo bien organizado y solidario. Los deseos de progresar que tienen cada una de las que integrantes es el ingrediente más importante para mantener el éxito de todas. Ellas desean que sus hijos no pasen por las mismas limitaciones laborales y educativas que ellas tuvieron cuando jóvenes, por eso se esfuerzan el doble para poder brindar a sus hijos oportunidades de progresar.

Para poder seguir trabajando y lograr aumentar sus ganancias, ellas desean seguir invirtiendo en sus negocios por lo que el grupo solicita un crédito para adquirir mercaderías para la venta como ropas, sombreros, tijeras, agujas, hilos, zapatos, artículos escolares, además de ingredientes y mercaderías para despensa como carne, frutas, verduras, aceite, harina, lácteos, arroz, fideos, enlatados, etc.

loans.use: Merchandise to sell in their businesses

loans.name: Helen Ruth

texts.es:
Doña Helen is a 41-year-old single woman living in her own home 4-1/2 blocks from the municipal theater. She has two children, a married son and a daughter living with her who is in her third year of secondary school. Doña Helen has worked with Fundacion Leon 2000 for 10 years, during which time she has invested in her business and acquired housing where she also has her small business. She has gradually been improving her beauty salon in order to provide suitable service to her clientele.

Her business was started because she needed to be self-employed. Since she had completed a beauty course and did not have other employment, she decided to open her own beauty salon herself with the help of Fundacion Leon. Her big dream is to be able to air-condition and expand her salon, in order to support her children's professional development.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva volunteer

Doña Helen tiene 41 años de edad es soltera, vive del teatro municipal 4 cuadras y media al sur vive en casa propia, tiene dos hijos uno ya esta casado y la otra es una niña vive con ella es menor de edad cursa el tercer año de secundaria , Doña Helen tiene de trabajar con fundacion leon 2000 10 años tiempo durante el cual ha sabido invertir en su negocio y adquirir una vivienda siendo esta donde actualmente tiene su pequeño negocio. En su pequeño salon de belleza ha venido poco a poco mejorandolo de esta manera ofrecer un servicio adecuado a su clientela negocio dio origen como una necesidad de crear su propio autoempleo, ya que ella habia adquirido un curso de belleza y no tenia otro empleo decidio poner su propio salon de belleza con esfuerzo propio y apoyo de nuestra isntitución, su mayor sueño es poder acondicionar y ampliar mas su salon de belleza, así como poder apoyar a sus hijos a que se desarrollen profesionalmente.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Peter Fru

texts.en:
Peter Fru A. was born in 1952. He is married and has two wives and six children, but his first wife left him because he lost his job and was bankrupt. Due to lack of money to pay for medication, three of his children have died. Two of these children were below fifteen years of age. Mr. A. did not receive a basic education because his parents died when he was very young.  He was left with no other option but to do odd jobs, and try to save money to learn a trade.

He saw the need for his children to have good education after losing his job, so he became a member of GHAPE in 2005. He believes that GHAPE can help him achieve his ambitions in life. Peter has already been able to receive and manage loans totaling $120. The profit from these loans was used to educate his children by buying books, uniforms, paying school fees. The standard of living of his family has also changed, and they are now able to eat three square meals a day. 

Peter is requesting a new loan of $500 to continue with his poultry farming,  pig farming, and farming of crops like cassava. He would also like to add honey production. Peter greatly believes that he will succeed because he is the only person in his area who is producing honey, which would be in high demand. He is also the sole supplier of poultry and pigs in his area. The profit of this loan will be used to construct a better house for his family, educate his children, and expand his business.

He plans to repay this loan in 18 months and the first installment repayment begins four months after disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of poultry, piglets, and feed

loans.name: Hilaria

texts.es:
Ms. Hilaria G. is single and lives in her own house with one of her daughters. Both of her daughters are now adults, and one of them emigrated to Spain in search of work and better opportunities, and she sends money to her mother from there to help with the responsibilities of the house.

Hilaria has a business located in one of the most visited markets called Market Number 5. This is located in the exact center of the city, and every day a large number of people come to this place to buy their basic needs as well as for lunch, hence the variety of business found there is plenty.

Hilaria dedicates herself to the sale of fruits and homemade sweets in her stand. Hilary starts her day early; at 4 .m. she’s already going to buy her merchandise to later go to her stand. In addition to the fruits and sweets she also sells refreshments that the people drink with their mates or terere, which are typical Paraguayan drinks.

One of her goals is to grow her business soon, including the equipment and mobility of the business. Today she is asking for a loan to be able to invest it in the purchase of seasonal fruits like apples, pears, grapefruits, oranges, plums, and bananas, among others, as well as guaya, milk and mani sweets.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Hilaria G., es soltera, vive en su propia casa con una de sus dos hijas. Ambas hijas ya son mayores de edad, una de ella emigro a España en busca de trabajo y mejores oportunidades, ella envía dinero a su madre desde allá para ayudarla con los ingresos de la casa.

Hilaria posee un negocio lo tiene en la entrada misma de uno de los mercados municipales mas concurridos por la población llamado Mercado Nº 5. El mismo está situado en el centro mismo de la ciudad y todos los días una gran cantidad de personas acuden hasta el lugar para surtirse de sus necesidades básicas, al igual que para almorzar pues la variedad de negocios que se encuentran ahí son bastantes.

La señora Hilaria se dedica a la venta de frutas y dulces caseros en su puesto. Hilaria empieza su día a tempranas horas de la madrugada, a las 04:00 am. ella ya va a comprar sus mercaderías para luego ir hasta su local de ventas. Además de las frutas y los dulces, también vende remedios refrescantes que la gente toma con sus mates o tereré que son bebidas típicas en nuestro país.

Una de sus aspiraciones es poder ampliar próximamente este negocio, en cuanto al equipamiento y mobiliario del negocio. Ella hoy solicita un crédito para poder invertirlo en la compra de frutas de estación como manzanas, peras, pomelos, naranjas, ciruelas, bananas, entre otros al igual que dulces de guayaba, de leche y de maní.

loans.use: Buying seasonal fruits and sweets

loans.name: Sandra

texts.es:
Sandra has been teaching for 24 years. She is 46 years old, married, her husband is a carpenter and helps with household expenses. She has a son of 9 years of age who is receiving his primary education. Sandra's dream is to be able to finish building her home, and the loan she is looking for is to purchase tiles for her home. Sandra also sells cooked frijoles and popsicles from her home, and in this way is able to earn other income and satisfy the needs of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Sandra desde hace 24 años se dedica a la docencia, tiene 46 años de edad, es casada, su marido es carpintero y le apoya con los gastos del hogar. Tiene un hijo de 9 años de edad, quien se encuentra estudiando la educación primaria. El sueño de Doña Sandra es poder terminar de construir su casa de habitación, el préstamo lo está solicitando para la compra de cerámica la cual pondrá en la sala de su vivienda. Doña Sandra también se dedica a la venta de frijoles cocidos y paletas de helado en su casa de habitación, para así poder tener otros ingresos y satisfacer las necesidades de su familia.

loans.use: To purchase tiles for the floor of her home

loans.name: Nubia

texts.es:
Mrs. Nubia O. is 57 years old, married, with two children 18 and 21 years old.  One is in the third year of a Psychology major, the other in the second year of Graphic Deisgn.  Her husband, who is also in tailoring, is the administrator of the business, while Doña Nubia works for a seamstress shop for extra income for her family.  Her big dream and life goal is to expand and equip her small workshop, upgrading it with industrial machines, in order to work in the home with her husband and be near her family.  Her daughters would also be involved in the handwork.  

They would offer their products to businesses that would direct-order products such as curtains, table sets, pillows, bedding, and cushions among other handicrafts.  She has been in this line of work for 45 years--the business was inherited from her parents who were also in tailoring.  They are asking for financing as working capital--further along they will use the profits to buy machinery and expand their shop.
Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva volunteer 

La señora nubia O., tiene 57 años de edad es casada, tiene dos hijos, una cursa el tercer año de la carrera de Psicologia y su otra hija cursa el segundo año de la carrera de diseño Grafico, estando en edades comprendidas de los 18 y 21 años de edad.
Su esposo quien tambien se dedica al arte de la costura o sastreria, es quien administra directamente el negocio ya que doña Nibia ofrece sus servicio para una tienda donde confeccionan ropa, obteniendo de esta manera otros ingresos para el nucleo familiar, su mayor sueño y proposito en la vida es poder acodncionar y ampliar su pequeño taller, tecnificarlo con maquinas insdustriales y trabajar en conjunto con su esposo en la casa y estar cerca a su familia, tambien sus hijas formarian parte de la mano de obra de esta manera ofrecer su producto a comerciantes que le encargan directamente ropa como cortinas, juegos de cobertores, almohadas, ropa de cama, cojines entre otras manualidades, la señora tiene 45 años de tener esta actividad, dicho negocio surge como una herencia de sus padres ya que éstos tambien tambien trabajaban en el arte de la costura; el financiamineto lo solicitan para capital de trabajo y mas adelante con las ganancias poder ir comprando maquinaria y ampliar su mercado.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Nicolas

texts.en:
Nicolas N. was born in the year 1936. He is married with five children. His family has always faced the problem of serious illness, resulting in death due to lack of money to pay for medication. He also had an accident which rendered him helpless to his family for a long period of time. He finds it difficult to push forward in life after his recovery from the accident.

He was motivated by the above circumstances to become a member of GHAPE. He has successfully received and managed two loans totaling $160. The profit from these loans was used to pay school fees for his children, to pay hospital bills and to provide furniture for the home. Nicholas is requesting a new loan to invest in pigs, poultry, and farm crops like yams, cassava, and beans. He believes he will succeed because he has enough land to farm, enough experience, and enough time to work on his farm. His wife and children are going to help him work the farm. The profit from this loan will be used to add the farm land and to continue to provide for the family.

Nicholas plans to repay this loan in 18 months and the first installment repayment begins four months after disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase pigs and poultry

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana B. was born in 1955. She is married and a mother of seven children all of whom are above the age of 15. Due to poverty she was unable to further her education after primary school and was sent to learn to a trade. She never had enough capital to make her business succeed. She and her husband were unable to send their children to school and it was very difficult even to provide food for them.

Susana became a member of GHAPE in 2005. So far, she has borrowed and repaid loans totaling $130. The profit from these loans was used to educate her children, pay for medication, and provide the family with three square meals a day.

Susana is requesting a loan to add buy more materials for her hair business. Her business is going to succeed because she has good business sense, enough capital, enough customers and enough apprentices to keep the business going.

She plans to repay this loan in 18 months and the first installment repayment begins four months after disbursement.

loans.use: To buy, sell, and plait hair

loans.name: Dzima

texts.fr:
Dzima T. is over 60 years old, married, and the father of 7 children. He lives in Assahoun located 50 kilometers from Lomé, the capital of Togo. He is the owner of a taxi which he uses for business. With this new loan he would like to reinvest by replacing the vehicle's motor which is already paid off, but which is prone to frequent breakdowns. The replacement of the motor and the overhaul of the car will allow him to thus spend less and save more.

Translated from French by Allana Carlyle, Kiva Volunteer.

Dzima T. est âgé de plus de 60ans, marié et père de 7 enfants. Il habite à Assahoun 50 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. II est propriétaire d’un véhicule taxi dont il tient son exploitation. Avec ce nouveau crédit, il désire investir de nouveau en renouvelant le moteur qui semble être déjà amorti ce qui est source de fréquentes pannes. Le renouvellement du moteur et la révision de la voiture lui permettront de dépenser moins et d’épargner plus en conséquence.

loans.use: To replace a vehicle motor

loans.name: Peter Anyah

texts.en:
Peter Anyah T. is a thirty-three year old widower with two children. He has already lost many loved ones: his wife, one child, his father, a brother and a sister. Now a single father, Peter's greatest goal in life is to care for his children and send them to school.

Peter joined GHAPE in 2004 to find a steadier source of income and care for his children. He says that he enjoys being a GHAPE member, “It makes me work very hard.” He has already successfully borrowed and repaid three loans totaling $375. These loans allowed him to buy dyes, which he uses to color thread. He then weaves the colored thread into bags and wall hangings in the traditional Cameroonian style. The profits from this business have already allowed him to begin a small pig farm and pay his children’s school fees.

Peter is requesting this new loan to continue his weaving business, expand his pig farm, and begin raising poultry as well. The largest part of the loan will go to buy additional pigs, since they are the most profitable, but pigs require time to grow and reproduce. So he plans to add poultry to his farm, since they can be raised in just three months, turning a faster profit. Meanwhile, he will add about $30 to the capital in his weaving business. He says that his businesses will succeed, because pigs, poultry, and woven bags are in great demand in his community, and his local production saves people from having to travel to the city to buy these items.

Peter plans to repay his loan in 18 months. The first repayment will be due on the fourth month following disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of pigs, poultry, and dyes

loans.name: Unida Para Seguir Group

texts.en:
Eloise M. is a married mother of three children, ages 10, 12, and 17, who wishes to see her children advance in their studies. She has a salon/barbershop that she has been operating for about 5 years now, 3 of the most recent years being with help from loans. When she is not busy with her business, she enjoys reading a variety of genres and watching television. Mrs. M. hopes to grow her business and continue earning income so that she can pay for the education of her children.

Mrs. M. is a member of a 5 person group, Group 2, which part of a larger micro-bank is called Unida Para Seguir, United to Continue in English. In the picture, Mrs. M. is in the center in the center along with the other four members of her group. Her story is just one of a list of men and women who are improving their quality of life through the help of micro-credit loans of Esperanza. Together, this group has united with a common vision of a better life with faith and hope in their hearts and an unbreakable spirit. The concept of group lending is to have loans paid in a group to reduce the risk of a person defaulting, as others pick up where a person may lag to receive the next loan. Each of the associates in this bank has a similar business whether it is a salon service or selling clothing. Thank you for your support and awareness of this issue, and it is your concern and efforts that is able to bring a difference to the lives of people such as Mrs. M..

loans.use: The women of this group would like to improve their businesses, like Eloise, who would like to improve her salon.

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en:
Mama Emilia A. is a 56 year old widow and the mother of six children. Since her husband’s death, she has had to care for herself and her children single-handedly, which is not an easy task. She joined GHAPE in 2002 and since that time, she has successfully borrowed and repaid four loans, totaling $590. A farmer for all her life, Mama Emilia used her previous loans to begin a pig farm, to clear and work her farmland, and most recently, to start a business selling corn, groundnuts, and beans in the market. With her growing profits, she has paid for her children’s education and supported  her household.

Mama Emilia is now requesting a loan to buy her market items in bulk: corn, beans, and groundnuts by the bag. She is confident in her success because her business experience is growing, she doesn’t have to pay any rent for her market space, and she has the support of her children, who are more than happy to assist her because she has given them a good start in life.

Her loan will be repaid in 24 months, with the first installment repayment due on the fourth month following disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of groundnuts, beans and corn

loans.name: Lucas

texts.en:
Pa Lucas T. is 68 years old, and has been a farmer all his life. He is married, and the father of seven children. Pa Lucas joined GHAPE in 2002 so he could expand and diversify his farming activities, and overcome the problems he has faced all his life: poverty, sickness and death. With his first four loans, Pa Lucas has moved beyond his main crop, coffee, by adding pigs, goats, additional farmland, and palm trees, which will soon start to produce palm nuts.

Now, Pa Lucas requests a loan that he will divide equally between three small farms where he grows coffee, palm nuts, and cassava. Asked why he thinks his business will succeed, he gives the best answer first: “It is a business that I like.” He has also been trained in good farming methods and has a lifetime of experience. With the profits from his business, Pa Lucas hopes to provide a better future for his children, who are mostly grown. “I will send my children for higher education, and I will buy them plots of land so they can begin their own farms.”

Pa plans to repay his loan in 18 months, with the first installment due the fourth month after disbursement, a GHAPE procedure to accommodate the agricultural season.

loans.use: Farming coffee, cassava and palm trees

loans.name: Mohamed's Group

texts.en:
Mohamed B., Mohamed B., Abu Bakarr K., Daniel S. and Justine F. K. are military personnel requesting a loan of Le 4,000,000.

Mohamed B. is the leader of this group. He is 28 years old and was born in Kailahun. He has one child. Mohamed and Daniel S. would like to use their loans to further educate themselves. Mohamed B. and Abu-Bakarr K. want loans to give to their wives to do some petty trading. This can help them a lot to earn extra income to make ends meet. Justine F. K. will use his loan to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: Pay school fees and other school charges.

loans.name: Bayron Leonardo

texts.es:
Bayron Leonardo T. S. is 21 years old, single with no children, living in his mother's house. He is finishing his third year of secondary school. He has not been able to complete his studies due to his parents' lack of resources. He intends to improve his living situation and his business, so he has been working with Leon 2000 for 5 seasons in order to invest more in his business. His dream is to be able to open a small wholesale distributorship to offer products such as rice, sugar, oil, detergents, soap, and costume jewelry and perhaps become an employer. His business is located in the market. He has taken loans at Leon 2000 for working capital in order to help his mother and defray household expenses.

His ambition is to enlarge his business and finish his studies, and later to be able to have his own home supported by his own work.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva volunteer

El joven Bayron Leonardo T. S., tiene 21 años de edad es soltero vive en casa de su mamá, no tiene hijos, el actualmente cursa el tercer año de sucundaria ya que por falta de recursos de sus padres no ha podido terminar sus estudios, Este joven tiene el proposito de ampliar sus condiciones de vida y del negocio, para ello tiene 5 ciclos de trabajar con nuestra institución y poder invertir mas a su negocio, ya que su mayor sueño es poder instalar una mini distribuidora y ofrecer mas productos como arroz, azucar, aceita , detergentes, jabon, bisuteria y por consiguiente generar empleos, su negocio esta ubicado en el mercado la estacion surgiendo la idea producto de que una tia le dejo el tramo y se fue para costa rica, de ahí el joven a venido realizando prestamos a leon 2000 para capital de trabajo de esta menera poder ayudar a su señora madre y a sufragar gastos del hogar. Su mayor sueño es ampliar su negocio y terminar sus estudios y mas adelante poder tener su propia casa de habitacion producto del esfuerzo de su trabajo.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Tania Magally

texts.es:
Tania is 31 years of age and lives in the neighbourhood of Laureles Norte. Her partner is a salesman, and she helps him with the household expenses. She has 3 children of 11, 8 and 5 years of age, and she says that her plans are to finish building their home and to educate her three children. Tania has sold cosmetics for 2 years. It is this business that creates the income necessary to support her family, and this is why she works a great deal to get ahead. The loan she is asking for is to improve the infratructure of parts of her house and in this way to improve it little by little.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne, Kiva volunteer.

Tania tiene 31 años de edad, habita en el barrio Laureles Norte, su compañero de vida es vendedor y le ayuda con los gastos del hogar. Tiene 3 hijos de 11, 8 y 5 años de edad y ella cuenta que los planes son poder terminar de construir su casa de habitación y darles educación a sus tres hijos. Tania se dedica a la venta de cosméticos desde hace 2 años, y es éste negocio quien le da los ingresos necesarios para mantener a su familia, por eso trabaja mucho para sacarlo adelante. El crédito lo está solicitando para hacer mejoras de infraestructura en varias partes de su casa, y así poder ir mejorándola poco a poco.

loans.use: To improve the infratructure of her house

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Herminia Del Carmen

texts.es:
Herminia lives in the neighbourhood of Laureles Norte where she sells pork products. She is 40 years old, her partner is a taxi driver. She has a daughter of 15 years of age who is a student, and who Herminia would like to become a professional and to get ahead in life. Herminia started her small business selling pork 7 years ago, with the difficult economic situation she hopes to have enough resourses to continue with it and, if possible, to increase her inventory. But she needs to replace the roof of her room immediately as it is in a very bad state and the rains are affecting it a lot.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne, Kiva volunteer.

Herminia habita en el barrio Laureles Norte donde se dedica a la venta de carne de cerdo. Tiene 40 años de edad, su compañero de vida es taxista y tiene una hija de 15 años de edad, estudiante y quien Herminia desea que se convierta en una profesional para que salga adelante en la vida. Herminia hace 7 años empezó el pequeño negocio de la venta de carne de cerdo, con lo difícil de la situación económica ella espera poder tener los recursos suficientes para mantenerlo y si es posible poder aumentar en inventario. Pero sus necesidades inmediatas son cambiar el techo de su casa de habitación que está en muy mal estado y las lluvias le están afectando mucho.

loans.use: To replace the roof of her room

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Kemokoh's Group

texts.en:
Kemokoh C., Frank D. S., Sheika I. S., Tennyacy Y. K. and Abu B. D. are a group of soldiers requsting a loan of Le 3,600,000.

Kemokoh C. is the leader of this group. He was born in Freetown. He is 42 years of age and is married with 4 children. Kemokoh wants a loan to help him continue his education. Frank D. S. would like to use his loan to purchase a plot of land. Sheika and Tennyacy would like to use theirs to build houses. Abu B. D. will invest his loan in agriculture.

loans.use: Pay school fees and other charges.

loans.name: Iccel Amanda

texts.es:
Iccel M. has a store in her home, which she set up 4 years ago with her own funds. She plans to make her business stronger. In order to do this she wants to convert it into a point of reference in the neighbourhood of Lareles Sur where she lives, and also to continue to help her husband with the household expenses. She is 28 years old, married and her husband is a construction worker, and together they support their family. They have a young daughter of 5 years of age, who they would like to give an education and a stable life. The loan would be used to build a small room in their house and could give more comfort and independence to their little girl.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne, Kiva volunteer.

Iccel M. tiene una pulpería en su casa de habitación, la cual pudo empezar hace 4 años con fondos propios, los planes para su negocio es hacerlo más sólido para que éste se pueda convertir en un punto de referencia en el barrio Laureles Sur donde ella habita, y así también seguir apoyando a su marido en los gastos del hogar. Tiene 28 años de edad, es casada y su esposo es albañil y juntos se encargan de llevar el sustento a su familia. Tienen una pequeña hija de 5 años de edad, a la cual ellos desean darle educación y una vida estable. El préstamo será usado en la construcción de una pequeña habitación en su casa y poder darle comodidad e independencia a su pequeña niña.

loans.use: To build a room

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Mohamed's Group

texts.en:
These military personnel are requesting a loan of Le 3,000,000.00. Their leader is Mohamed T.. He is 27. Born in Makeni. He is married with 2 children. Mohamed T.`s wife is a business woman who sells assorted items. Mohamed will like to give his loan to his wife to invest in her current business.

The other two are Assanatu K. and Bai S.. The former will use her  loan to start doing business and the latter will give his loan to his wife to invest in her current business.

loans.use: Buy more local produces to add to existing business

loans.name: Sheika's Group

texts.en:
These soldiers working in Makeni are Sheika B., Adama M., Gbassay K., and Victor M.. They are requesting a loan of Le 3,5000,000. This is their first loan from SMT. With this loan, they'll be able to engage in either agriculture or in a business that will earn them some money to complement their salaries.

Sheika B., the leader of this group, would like to give his wife the loan so she can start selling cosmetics. This was a long-held dream of theirs, but Sheika's salary was too small to enable his wife to start a business, considering their numerous other needs. With a loan from SMT, Sheika can now give his wife the required capital she needs to start a small business. Sheika is 36, and he was born in Kailahun in eastern Sierra Leone. He is married with 2 children.

loans.use: Start businesses to supplement their salaries

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr:
Mamadou W. is a married artisan who lives in the Belfort neighborhood of Ziguinchor. He has made a living with his art for over 15 years, and is requesting this loan to strengthen his production and prepare for the tourist season that will begin again in September.

Translated from French by Erin Johnson, Kiva Volunteer.

Mamadou W. est un artisan marié et domicilié au quartier Belfort de Ziguinchor. il vit de son art depuis plus d'une quinzaine d'année, il sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer sa production et préparer la saison touristique qui va démarrer en septembre.

loans.use: Strengthen his shop in a traditional village

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es:
Yolanda is 35 years of age. She completed education through the fifth year of high school. She speaks the Aymará (langauge spoken by the Aymará people of the Andes) and Castillian (Spanish) languages. She is married with two sons who are studying in elementary and high school. Their home is located in the Sector Marquiri, in the town of Caritamaya, District of Acora, Province of Puno.

She buys and sells livestock including sheep and cows that she buys in the markets of Acora and Ilave. Also, she produces handicrafts like puppets, Peruvian-style wool hats, gloves, and scarves that she sells to third parties in the Acora market.

She belongs to the "Nuevo Horizonte" community bank where she started with a loan of 300 new soles with which she was able to buy four sheep to raise. With this loan of 800 new soles ($300), one that she will repay in four months, she will buy a cow that she will sell later.

She is very grateful for the loan which will help her increase her capital and also her income.

Her big dream is for her children to be professionals and to increase her capital so that she can continue in her business.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer.

Yolanda tiene 35 años de edad, logro estudiar hasta el quinto de secundaria, habla el idioma Aymará y Castellano, es casada tiene dos hijos varones, quienes están estudiando en la escuela y colegio, su domicilio esta ubicado en el sector Marquiri, en el Centro Poblado Caritamaya, Distrito de Acora, Provincia de Puno.

Ella se dedica a la compra y venta de ganado como ovejas y vacas que los adquiere en la ferias de Acora e Ilave; también se dedica a la producción de artesanía como títeres, chalinas, guantes, chullos que los vende a personas intermediarias en la feria de Acora.

Pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nuevo Horizonte” donde inicio con un crédito de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles con lo que pudo comprar cuatro ovejas para engorde; Con este crédito de S/. 800.00 nuevos soles, el cual será pagado en de cuatro meses, comprarà una vaca, que posteriormente será vendida.

Esta muy agradecida por el crédito, por que le ayuda a incrementar su capital y su vez su ingreso económico.

El gran sueño que tiene es que sus hijos sean profesionales e incrementar su capital para seguir con el negocio.

loans.use: Purchase of Cattle

loans.name: Yanet

texts.es:
Señora Yanet is 30 years of age, succeeded in finishing high school, speaks the Aymará (langauge spoken by the Aymará people of the Andes) and Castillian (Spanish) languages, and lives with her two sons who are studying in the school in Puno.

She is from the Sector of Marquiri, but it is for her children that she lives in Puno.

She makes puppets, Peruvian-style wool hats, scarves, gloves on request. She has been doing this for four years, selling products to third-party sellers in Puno.

She belongs to the "Nuevo Horizonte" community bank where she received an initial loan of 300 new soles with which she was able to buy seven kilos of multi-color synthetic wool.

With this loan of 200 new soles ($75) which she will repay in four months, she will buy 5 kilos of multi-color synthetic wool and two kilos of filling to stuff the puppets.

She shows that she has learned to be responsible and on-time with her payments. She is very grateful for the loan that helped her easily buy the materials for her products.

Her big dream is to buy her own home in Puno, open a grocery shop, and for her children to study and become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Yanet tiene 30 años de edad, logro estudiar secundaria completa, habla el idioma Aymará y Castellano, convive y tiene dos hijos varones que están estudiando en la escuela de Puno.

Ella es del Sector de Marquiri, por sus hijos, es que vive en Puno.

Se dedica a la producción de Títeres, chullos, chalinas, guantes, de acuerdo al pedido que se le hace, a esta actividad se dedica desde hace cuatro años, producto que vende a personas intermediarias en Puno.

Pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nuevo Horizonte” donde tuvo un crédito inicial de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles con lo que pudo comprar siete kilos de lana sintética multicolor.

Con este crédito de S/.200.00 nuevos soles el cual será pagado en cuatro meses, comprarà 5 kilos de lana sintética multicolor y 2 kilos de napa para relleno de los títeres.

Ella manifiesta que aprendió a ser responsable y puntual en sus pagos. Esta muy agradecida con el crédito por que le ayudo a comprar con facilidad sus materiales de producción.

El gran sueño que tiene es comprar una casa propia en Puno, abrir una tienda de abarrotes, y que sus hijos estudien y sean profesionales.

loans.use: The Bulk Purchase of Wool and Filling for Dolls

loans.name: Virginia

texts.es:
Doña Virginia is 28 years old. She has completed elementary school, is the mother of three children, is married, and lives in the M. in the town of Camicachi, Ilave district, Province of El Calloa and the Region of Puno.

She is an active member of the "22 de Septiembre" community bank in M.. With the first loans she received, she embarked on the business of purchasing and selling cattle in the markets in the districts of Pilcuyo and Ilave. This business has generated earnings.

With this loan of 300 new soles ($125), one that she will repay in 4 months, she will buy more cattle.

Her dream is to increase her income to buy a house in the city of Ilave, to continue raising cattle, and for her children to study and become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Virginia tiene 28 años de edad, su nivel educativo es primaria completa, es madre de tres hijos, es casada y vive en la parcialidad de M., del Centro Poblado de Camicachi, del distrito de Ilave, provincia El Collao y Región de Puno.

Ella es socia activa del Banco Comunal de 22 de Septiembre de la parcialidad de M., con los primeros créditos que recibió emprendió el negocio de compra y venta de ganado vacuno, en las ferias del distrito de Pilcuyo y del distrito de Ilave, este negocio generó ganancias.

Con este crédito de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, el cual serà pagado en 4 meses, comprarà màs ganado vacuno.

Su sueño es incrementar más su capital para comprar una casa en la ciudad de Ilave, continuar con el engorde de ganado vacuno y que estudien sus hijos y sean profesionales.

loans.use: Purchase of Cattle

loans.name: Cheikh Sadibou

texts.fr:
This young entrepreneur is involved in services (photocopies, word-processing). He is requesting this loan to boost his business by developing bookbinding and to stock reams of paper more cheaply for wholesale purchases. Situated across from the ACAPES School, his clientele consists of students and teachers, not to mention economic operators.

Translated from French by Erin Johnson, Kiva Volunteer

Ce jeune entrepreneur intervient dans les services (photocopies, tritement de texte). Il demande ce srédit pour renforcer ses activités en développant la reliure et stocker des rames de papiers à moindre pour les achats en gros. Situé en face du Groupe Scolaire ACAPES, il a une clientéle constituée d'éléves et d'enseignants sans compter les opérateurs économiques.

loans.use: Boost business

loans.name: Hacia Adelante Groups 3 And 4

texts.en:
In just three loan cycles, Milandina has more than doubled her loan amount, starting with a loan of $5000 DOP and currently borrowing $12000. Her rapid progress is most easily observed in her well–stocked store. Though the store is successful, Milandina has dreams to expand: she wants a more spacious store with a wider variety of merchandise (specifically accessories). This determined attituD. has had noticeable benefits for her family and community.

Milandina is a group leader in her Bank of Hope, Hacia Adelante (“onward”), and her loan officer Ramona often uses her story as an inspiration for new associates. Of all her successes, Milandina seems most proud of the fact that her family can now always count on her—proof that Esperanza fosters solidarity and responsibility as well as entrepreneurship.

loans.use: This group would like to improve their various businesses, like Milandina who would like to expand her accessories store.

loans.name: Timotea

texts.es:
Mrs Timotea is a member of the Communal Bank Nuevo Norizone in the Centro Poblado of Caritamaya in the sector of Marquiri, in the district of Acora, in the Province and Region of Puno.

She is dedicated to the fattening of livestock (preferably cattle). Previous loans were used to increase her capital and economic gains, thus bringing about more work with these loans. With this loan of S/. 500.00 Peruvain Soles ($200.00), which will be repaid in four months, she will purchase 2 better cows in order to fatthen them and sell them within the next three months at the livestock market of Acora.

She is vey happy, and is little by little increasing her capital and living a better life than previously. She no longer is lacking money to purchase provisions for cooking. She is currently 55 years old, completed primary school, married and is a mother of four children, as takes care of a niece who is dependent on her. Her greatest wish is to live happily, to expand her business and to proviD. an educaiton for her niece.

Translated from Spanish by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Timotea, es socia del Banco Comunal Nuevo Horizonte del Centro Poblado D. Caritamaya sector Marquiri, del distrito D. Acora, Provincia y Región D. Puno. Ella se dedica al engorD. D. ganado ovino mejorado, con los préstamos anteriores logró incrementar su capital e ingresos económicos, lo cual sigue motivando trabajar con los préstamos. Con este préstamo D. S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, el mismo que será pagado en cuatro meses, comprará 2 ovinos mejorados para el engorD. y venderá D. aquí D. tres meses en la feria D. ganado D. Acora. Ella, está muy contenta, poco a poco está incrementando su capital y también esta viviendo mejor que antes, ya que no le falta dinero para comprar sus víveres para la cocina. Actualmente ella tiene 55 años D. edad, estudió hasta primaria completa, madre D. cuatro hijos, es casada y a su responsabilidad solo está una nieta. Por ello su deseo granD. es vivir feliz, ampliar su negocio y estudie su nieta.

loans.use: Purchasing of livestock, cattle.

loans.name: Mamso Sheiko's Group

texts.en:
This group of soldiers is requesting a loan of Le 5,000,000. Their names are: Mamso T., Mamu S., Ibrahim B. M., Abdul Karim K. and Michael S.. They want a loan to give to their wives to add to their current businesses. This is a great help to the soldiers as many of them had wanted to expand their wives' businesses but lacked the required amount of money to enable them do so. They will repay their loans out of their monthly salaries.

Mamso is the group leader. He is 36 and was born in Kambiya, a town bordering neighboring Guinea. He is married with 4 children. Manso will give his loan to his wife who currently sells rice, cassava, and potatoes. She has been in this business for 3 years.

loans.use: Give to their wives to expand their businesses

loans.name: Susana

texts.es:
Susana is a member of the Zepita Communal Bank, in the district of Zepita, province of Chucuito-Juli and the region of Puno. She has been dedicated to the sale of groceries near the market in the city of Desaguadero. She has been in this business since she was 15 years old.

With previous loans she was able to increase her volume of merchandise and also lauched into the fattening of cattle, which need to fatten for three months prior to being sold. She maintains the general store business two days a week on tuesdays and fridays.

This loan of S/.1,800.00 Peruvian Soles ($ 650) which will be repaid in 4 months, would be invested in parts. Half would go towards the purchase of 1 cow to fatten up and the other part pour be used to purchase merchandise for the general store such as 3 boxes of sodas, 2 dozen Inca cola, pepsi and coca cola and 4 boxes of cookies, among others.

She is very happy, already has more financial resources than she did in previous years and also is able to increase her gains. Her favorite dream is to increase her business to the regional level and support her children in secondary education schooling.

Susana is 44 years old, married, attended school until the third year of secondary school and has three children (1 girl and 2 boys).

Translated from Spanish by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

Susana pertenece al Banco Comunal Zepita, del distrito de Zepita, provincia de Chucuito – Juli y Región de Puno. Se dedica a la venta de abarrotes cerca al mercado de la ciudad de Desaguadero, este negocio emprendió desde soltera a los 15 años de edad. Con los créditos anteriores que tuvo incremento su mercadería y emprendió el engorde de ganado vacuno, lo cual engorda durante tres meses para luego venderlo, mientras el negocio de abarrotes realiza dos veces a semana los días martes y viernes. Con el préstamo de S/.1,800.00 nuevos soles, el cual pagará en 4 meses, invertirá en partes, con la mitad comprará 01vaca para engorde y la otra parte comprará 4 paquetes de quinuafrujo, 3 paquetes de gaseosas, 2 docenas gaseosa de Inca cola, pepsi y coca cola, 4 cajas de galletas entre otras. Ella esta muy contenta, ya que tiene más ingresos que anteriores años y además incremento su capital. Su mayor sueño es ampliar su negocio a nivel regional y apoyar a sus hijos para sus estudios superiores. Susana, tiene 44 años de edad, es casada, estudió hasta tercero de secundaria y tiene tres hijos (una mujer y dos varones).

loans.use: Purchasing livestoock (1 cow). Purchasing various products (groceries).

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Manuela Ramos / CrediMUJER - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Youssouphe

texts.fr:
This artisan runs a shop in the traditional village of Ziguinchor. He sells shoes and belts made from reptile and animal skins. He wants to use this funding to boost his stock for the tourist season that is quickly approaching. This artisan provides for his family thanks to these business activities.

Translated from French by Erin Johnson, Kiva Volunteer

Cet artisan tient une boutique au village artisanal de Ziguinchor. Il vend des chaussures et des ceintures fabriqués à base de peaux d'animaux et reptiles. Il veut renforcer par ce financement son stock avec la saison touristique qui approche à grands pas.Grâce à ses activités, cet artisan arrive à faire vivre sa famille.

loans.use: Boost business

loans.name: Sebastiana

texts.es:
Sebastiana is 42 years old, attended school until second graD., speaks both Aymará and Castellano and is maried with two children who are currently students at school. Her house is located in the Marquiri sector of the Centro Poblado of Caritamaya, in the Acora District and the Puno Province.

She has been dedicated to the sales of cows and sheep in the markets of Llave and Acora since a very young age. She is a member of the Communcal Bank "Nuevo Horizonte" in order to increase her resources; with the initial loan of S/. 300.00 Peruvain Soles she invested in and purchased six sheep. With this loan of S/. 500.00 Peruvian Soles ($ 200) which will be repaid in four months, she will purchase three young sheep (in order for them to grow) and the remaining money will be used to purchase sheep to sell on a weekly basis.

She explains that is very pleased to have learned how to administer her payments and little by little increase her economic gains. Her vision for the future is to purchase more land for the small farmhouse, purchase more livestock and in this manner increase her economic gains in order to proviD. her children with an education so they may become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

Sebastiana tiene 42 años D. edad, estudio hasta el segundo año D. primaria; habla el idioma aymará y castellano es casada y tiene dos hijos quienes estudian en la escuela y colegio, su casa esta ubicada en el sector Marquiri del Centro Poblado D. Caritamaya, Distrito D. Acora, Provincia D. Puno. Se dedica a la compra y venta D. vacas, ovejas que los adquiere en las ferias D. Ilave y Acora y son vendidas en las mismas ferias, a esta actividad se dedica desD. muy joven, ingreso al Banco Comunal “Nuevo Horizonte” para incrementar su capital; donD. tuvo un crédito inicial D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles que lo invirtió en la compra D. seis ovejas; Con este crédito D. S/. 500.00 nuevos soles el cual lo cancelarà en cuatro meses, comprarà 3 ovejas para criarlas y con el resto del dinero lo utilizarà para la compra D. ovejas que las venD. semanalmente. Ella manifiesta que siendo socia aprendió a ser trabajadora administrar su dinero e incremento un poco mas su ingreso económico. La visión futura que ella tiene es comprar más terrenos para la chacra, comprar más ganado y D. esa manera incrementar su ingreso y lograr hacer estudiar a sus hijos para que sean profesionales.

loans.use: Purchasing livestock (sheep)

loans.name: Liberacion- Group 6

texts.en:
Nemias C. M. is a 32-yr old married mother of a 7-yr old child whom she is trying to put through school. She was able to start her business 2 years ago with the help of loans. She has a small restaurant where she cooks and sells foods such as plantains and fried fish. She is a dedicated Christian who very much enjoys Christian music as well as reading the Bible when she is not working with her business. Mrs. C. M. has dreams of seeing her business grow so that she can provide for her family and continue the education of her child.

Mrs. Nemias C. M. is a member of a 5 person group, Group 6, which is part of a larger micro-bank called Liberacion. In the picture, Mrs. C. M. is second from the left along with three members of Liberacion. Her story is just one of a list of men and women who are improving their quality of life through the help of micro-credit loans of Esperanza. Together, this group has united with a common vision of a better life with faith and hope in their hearts and an unbreakable spirit. The concept of group lending is to have loans paid in a group to reduce the risk of a person defaulting, as others pick up where a person may lag to receive the next loan. Each of the associates in this bank has a similar business whether it is a restaraunt or salon. Thank you for your support and awareness of this issue, and it is your concern and efforts that is able to bring a difference to the lives of people such as Mrs. C. M..

loans.use: This group of people would like to improve their various businesses, such as Nemias who would like to improve her restaurant.

loans.name: Apostolico Group

texts.en: Though Amancia had been selling her handmaD. clothes and ceramics for twenty years before she joined her Esperanza Bank of Hope (of which she is a group leader), her loans have had an undeniable impact on her life. In terms of her business, she has been able to widen the variety of merchandise her business offers. Not only that, but the loan has inspired her to start thinking more ambitiously and entrepreneurially: she has learned to gauge what her customers want, and hopes to one day move her business into a permanent stall. In terms of her family and community, she has taken leadership roles in both. She makes sure that her grandchildren have everything they need for school and medical supplies, and buys them clothes when she sees something she thinks they would like. Her home serves as the meeting site for Bank of Hope meetings, where she often serves lemonaD. and snacks to everyone. During this particular meeting, Amancia remains modest when I ask her questions—but her fellow group members chime in to tell me accomplishments she has left out.  Everyone present—the other associates, her loan officer Cristina—seems incredibly proud of her.

loans.use: This group would like to improve their businesses, like Amancia who would like to improve her handmade clothing and ceramics business.

loans.name: Hassan's Group

texts.en:
Hassan S., John F., John Yamba K., Abu Bakarr K. and Sorie C. have applied for loans in order to invest in businesses and thereby supplement their monthly salaries. All five men are soldiers based in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone. At the end of each month, repayments will be made to SMT through their paymaster.

Hassan Sambura is the group leader. He is 32 years old and was born in Kambia in the north of Sierra Leone. He is married with 4 children. Hassan's wife has a business selling local produce and he would give his loan to his wife so that she can expand her business. This will help the family increase their income a great deal.

Other members of the group plan to invest their loans in their wives' businesses as well. The exception is John F., who will invest his loan in his shoe and jewelry business.

loans.use: Give to their wives to invest in their businesses

loans.name: Mujeres En Ritmo Group

texts.es:
The ladies consisting of this committee are dedicated to various activities, among which we can cite the sale of various merchandise like clothes, shoes, arts, charcoal, cleaning products, makeup, foods, fruits and vegetables, among others.

Because of their limited chances of receiving capital to start their small businesses, now that the financial institutions generally ask for a business reference to give credit, they have applied to the Paraguay Foundation, which not only helped them get capital, but also gave them classes that will help them be better administrators.

So that their children don’t face the same economic and academic limitations that they had when they were younger, these beautiful ladies fight day to day to be able to obtain the financial ability to improve the quality of life for their families.

With the credit they take, they will purchase various merchandise and supplies for their businesses and will raise their incomes. The merchandise to be acquired is: charcoal, fruit, meat, sugar, dairy, cleaning products, art, vegetables, medicinal muds, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva volunteer.

Las señoras pertenecientes a este comité se dedican a diversas actividades, entre las que podemos citar la venta de mercaderías varias como ropas, zapatos, artesanías, carbón, artículos de limpieza, maquillaje, comidas, frutas y verduras, entre otros.

Debido a que sus posibilidades de conseguir capital para empezar sus pequeños emprendimientos, ya que las entidades financieras por lo general solicitan una basta referencia comercial para otorgar créditos, ellas acudieron a la Fundación Paraguaya que no solo accedió a ayudarlas si no que a la vez reciben capacitaciones que les ayuda a ser mejores administradoras.

Para que sus hijos no pasen por las mismas limitaciones tanto económicas como académicas que ellas tuvieron de jóvenes, estas bellas mujeres luchan día a día para lograr obtener el ingreso económico suficiente que permita mejorar la calidad de vida de sus familias. Con el crédito que llevarán compraran mercaderías e insumos varios para sus negocios y así lograr aumentar sus ingresos. Las mercaderías a ser adquiridas son: carbón, frutas, carnes, azúcar, lácteos, productos de limpieza, artesanías, verduras, productos de limpieza, barros medicinales, etc.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise and products

loans.name: Mujeres En Ritmo Group

texts.es:
The ladies consisting of this committee are dedicated to various activities, among which we can cite the sale of various merchandise like clothes, shoes, arts, charcoal, cleaning products, makeup, foods, fruits and vegetables, among others.

Because of their limited chances of receiving capital to start their small businesses, now that the financial institutions generally ask for a business reference to give credit, they have applied to the Paraguay Foundation, which not only helped them get capital, but also gave them classes that will help them be better administrators.

So that their children don’t face the same economic and academic limitations that they had when they were younger, these beautiful ladies fight day to day to be able to obtain the financial ability to improve the quality of life for their families.

With the credit they take, they will purchase various merchandise and supplies for their businesses and will raise their incomes. The merchandise to be acquired is: charcoal, fruit, meat, sugar, dairy, cleaning products, art, vegetables, medicinal muds, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva volunteer.

Las señoras pertenecientes a este comité se dedican a diversas actividades, entre las que podemos citar la venta de mercaderías varias como ropas, zapatos, artesanías, carbón, artículos de limpieza, maquillaje, comidas, frutas y verduras, entre otros.

Debido a que sus posibilidades de conseguir capital para empezar sus pequeños emprendimientos, ya que las entidades financieras por lo general solicitan una basta referencia comercial para otorgar créditos, ellas acudieron a la Fundación Paraguaya que no solo accedió a ayudarlas si no que a la vez reciben capacitaciones que les ayuda a ser mejores administradoras.

Para que sus hijos no pasen por las mismas limitaciones tanto económicas como académicas que ellas tuvieron de jóvenes, estas bellas mujeres luchan día a día para lograr obtener el ingreso económico suficiente que permita mejorar la calidad de vida de sus familias. Con el crédito que llevarán compraran mercaderías e insumos varios para sus negocios y así lograr aumentar sus ingresos. Las mercaderías a ser adquiridas son: carbón, frutas, carnes, azúcar, lácteos, productos de limpieza, artesanías, verduras, productos de limpieza, barros medicinales, etc.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise and supplies

loans.name: Isabelino

texts.es:
Mr. Isabelino Fereira is married, lives in his own house, and has grown children who help him in his business by waiting on customers. His business is in a very good location, being in a highly commercial district, and his notions store is one of the best-known companies in downtown Asunción.

Isabelino tells how he started his business with barely 3,000,000 Guaraní (about $700). The business grew quickly over the years to the point where he could rely on an expanded clientele, a result of his store’s location in a very busy shopping area that attracts tourists.

Among the items that Isabelino sells one can find glasses, sunglasses, bifocals and electronic articles such as calculators, flashlights, watches, and cd’s.

One of Isabelino’s aspirations is to expand his company soon, and in the future to open a business importing and distributing electronic equipment. Today he would like credit to buy a greater variety of goods in large quantities.

Translated from Spanish by Melissa Hays, Kiva volunteer.

El señor Isabelino F., es casado, viven en su propia casa, ya tiene hijos mayores de edad, quienes también le ayudan en su negocio en la atención de sus clientes. El negocio lo tiene muy bien ubicado, pues está en una zona altamente comercial y su mercería es uno de los comercios más conocidos del microcentro de Asunción.

Isabelino cuenta que inicio su comercio con apenas G. 3.000.000 ($ 700 aproximadamente), el cual fue ampliando con el correr de los años ya que rápidamente pudo contar con una amplia clientela, razón principal por la ubicación del negocio ya que es un lugar bastante concurrido inclusive por turistas.

Entre las mercaderías que Isabelino vende podemos encontrar lentes de sol, lentes para la vista, bifocales y artículos de electrónica como calculadoras, cd´s, linternas, relojes, entre otros.

Uno de sus aspiraciones es poder ampliar próximamente su negocio, y abrir en el futuro una empresa de importaciones y distribuidora de equipos de electrónica. Hoy el desea el crédito para comprar mercaderías en grandes cantidades y de mayor variedad.

loans.use: Purchase of glasses, sunglasses, calculators, cd’s, flashlights and watches.

loans.name: Ñanemba´ete Ete Group

texts.es:
The Ñanemba'eteete Committee (“Our Own Committee”, in the Guaraní language) is a fairly new committee within the Paraguay Foundation and consists of 16 members who are involved in diverse activities. Some of the women sell fruit, fruit salad, or general foodstuffs; some sell clothing; others have their own kiosks or “despensas” (typical Paraguayan mini-markets—often located in the owners’ homes). Still others sell medicinal herbs to drink in preparations such as tea, maté, and tereré, which is iced maté --a popular Paraguayan beverage.

All of the members are worthy women, dedicated to their families and to their children’s progress. One of these women, Dolly A., owns a small kiosk which she started six months ago with the help of her husband. Among other things, she sells snacks, juices, carbonated beverages and fast food. She joined the Committee of Women Entrepreneurs of the Paraguayan Foundation with the goal of obtaining credit and the training necessary to expand her small business.

This will be the first time that these women have taken out a loan, and they are very excited and eager to work. The loan they are asking for will be invested in the purchase of merchandise such as fruit, meat, flour, dairy products, vegetables, snacks, juices, carbonated beverages, clothes, recyclable cartons and plastic containers, and ingredients for meal preparation.

Translated by Melissa Hays, Kiva volunteer.

Este comité Ñanemba'eteete (Lo nuestro o propio en el idioma Guaraní) es un comité bastante nuevo dentro de la Fundación Paraguaya cuenta con 16 integrantes que se dedican a actividades diversas como venta de comidas, despensas, kioscos, venta de frutas y ensalada de frutas, otras venden ropas, o hierbas medicinales para tomar con infusiones como té, mate o tereré.

Todas las integrantes son mujeres de gran valor, que dedican sus vidas a sus familias y a lograr el progreso de sus hijos. De entre estas señoras tenemos a Dolly A. que posee un pequeño kiosco que inicio hace seis meses con la ayuda de su marido. Ella vende golosinas, jugos, gaseosas, comidas rápidas entre otros en su negocio, ella ingreso al programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras de la Fundación Paraguaya con el fin de lograr obtener los créditos y la capacitación necesaria para poder ampliar su pequeño negocio.

Este será el primer crédito que estas señoras retiren por lo que están muy emocionadas y con ganas de trabajar. El crédito que ellas solicitan lo invertirán en la compra de mercaderías como: frutas, carne, harina, lácteos, verduras, golosinas, jugos, gaseosas, ropas, cartones y plásticos para reciclaje, e ingredientes para preparar sus comidas.

loans.use: The purchase of merchandise such as fruit, meat, flour, dairy products, vegetables, snacks, juices, carbonated beverages, clothes, recyclable cartons and plastic containers, and ingredients for meal preparation

loans.name: Plan De Lucha Group

texts.en:
Ramona Cornelio is a 31-year-old woman who lives with her husband and three children (ages 14, 7, and 6) in a small community called Bejucal in the eastern province of Hato Mayor in the Dominican Republic. She began a small business selling undergarments two years ago and continues to increase her inventory with each loan. Ramona operates her business from her home and occasionally travels by bus from town to town. She has started this business so that she can provide her children with a good education and a comfortable home. In Ramona’s free time, she enjoys working with computers and spending time with her family.

Ramona is the leader of the 10-person micro-bank group, Plan de Lucha. In English, this means `fight plan´. Each of these unique Dominican entrepreneurs unite in solidarity, allowing them to access funding that they would otherwise never be able to receive on their own. On behalf of Ramona, the Plan de Lucha group, and the entire team here at Esperanza International, we thank you for your support with this micro loan!

loans.use: This group would like to improve their various businesses, like Ramona who would like to buy undergarments to sell from her home.

loans.name: Luz Y Esperanza- Group 1

texts.en:
Before I even opened my mouth to say hello to a group of associates the small community of El Rincon, Faustina F. was offering me some mango she was busy peeling before the start of the loan meeting. She is a kind and open 60-yr old lady who started her business six years ago with the help of loans from Esperanza. She is in the business of selling used clothing which she buys with her loans from larger towns and cities such as Samaná and Santo Domingo. She has one daughter who is 43 yrs old and lives in her own place. Mrs. F. is an evangelic Christian whose favorite food is arroz con vaca (rice with beef). She has hopes of seeing her business succeed to construct better living quarters and provide for herself and her husband.

Mrs. Faustina F. is a member of a 5 person group, Group 1, which is part of a larger micro-bank called Luz y Esperanza, "Light and Hope" in English. In the picture, Mrs. F. is second from the left. Her story is just one of a list of men and women who are improving their quality of life through the help of micro-credit loans of Esperanza. Together, this group has united with a common vision of a better life with faith and hope in their hearts and an unbreakable spirit. The concept of group lending is to have loans paid in a group to reduce the risk of a person defaulting, as others pick up where a person may lag to receive the next loan. Each of the associates in this bank has a similar business whether it is a gas station or the sale of clothing. Thank you for your support and awareness of this issue, and it is your concern and efforts that is able to bring a difference to the lives of people such as Mrs. F..

loans.use: This group would like to improve their various businesses like Faustina who would like to improve her clothing business.

loans.name: Manuela

texts.es:
Doña Manuela L. T. is 31 years of age, is married and works as a buyer and seller of traditional clothing. Her business is located in the community of Caserio Chilopizab, Aldea Palacal in the Nahualá, Sololá region of Guatemala. She is well known in the community for her participation in all types of activity, for her generosity with the people, and for being a hard worker. She has earned the trust of everyone in the community, and thanks to her daily efforts to make progress she has established her small business. Because of her growing clientele, Manuela does not have the capital to keep up with the demand for her products. She saw the need to go to the ASDIR offices for a loan so that she could continue to meet the needs of her customers. Manuela is known in the community as a responsible person with good principles. Currently she employs one person in her business.

Translated by Melissa Hays, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Manuela López T. tiene 31 años de edad, es Unida, de oficio Comerciante (Compra y Venta de Ropa Típica) su negocio se encuentra ubicado en el Caserío Chilopizab, Aldea Palacal, Nahualá, Sololá, y reside en la misma comunidad, actualmente es una persona muy conocida en la comunidad por su participación en todo tipo de actividad y su generosidad con las personas y por ser una persona muy trabajadora en la comunidad se ha ganado la confianza de toda la gente de su comunidad, y gracias a sus esfuerzos diarios por seguir adelante logro tener un pequeño negocio en Compra y Ventas de Ropa Típica, y con su buen comportamiento en la comunidad de Chuilopizab este negocio fue creciendo su demanda de clientes por tal razón que Doña Manuela López T. no cuenta con el capital necesario para poder satisfacer las necesidades de la clientela, se vio en la necesidad de acudir a las oficinas de la asociación ASDIR, para que su negocio siga creciendo y solo así las personas sigan percibiendo dicho beneficio que ofrece la señora Manuela López en su misma comunidad y tanto ella podrá mejorar sus condiciones de vida. A doña Manuela, se le conoce en la comunidad como una persona responsable y de buenas principios como su participación y generosidad con las personas actualmente cuenta con 1 trabajador en su negocio de compra de ropa típica, la cual esto ha generado oportunidades de trabajo.

loans.use: Increase inventory  for her business of buying and selling traditional clothing

loans.name: Rosa Mística Group

texts.es:
This group was formed thanks to Liliana Noemi S. V. who is a hairdresser in the Santa Domingo neighborhood of Lambaré. Since she was small, Liliana dreamed of having her own salon where every woman could go to become more beautiful. She tells the story of how, as a little girl playing with her dolls, she did their hair and make-up. Her dream has been realized thanks to her hard work and the loans she received to start up her business.

Liliana and her neighbors and friends formed the group named Rosa Mística, and together they took out a loan from Fundación Paraguaya through its program “Committee of Women Entrepreneurs”. Like Liliana, the other women in the group work at the same time as raising their families. Each is engaged in a different activity: some women work as traveling vendors, some sell food, and some own “despensas” (mini-markets), while others produce artisan textiles to sell.

Rosa Mística is a very united, hard-working group whose members, in addition to their work activities, perform community work and raise funds to invest in the betterment of their neighborhood.

These women would like a loan in order to buy merchandise to sell—merchandise such as meat, fruit, vegetables, drinks, cosmetics, stockings, fabric, thread, and knitting needles.

Translated by Melissa Hays, Kiva volunteer.

Este Comité se formo gracias a la Sra. Liliana Noemi S. V., quien es una peluquera en el Barrio Santo Domingo de la ciudad de Lambaré. Liliana desde pequeña soñó con tener su propio salón de belleza en donde todas las mujeres puedan ir a ponerse más bellas. Cuenta que cuando pequeña jugaba con sus muñecas y ella misma las peinaba y maquillaba. Ese sueño se cumplió gracias al arduo trabajo y créditos que recibió para iniciar su negocio.

Junto con sus vecinas y amigas del barrio formaron el grupo llamado Rosa Mística, y juntas retiran el crédito grupal de la Fundación Paraguaya através de su programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras. Al igual que Liliana, las otras señoras trabajan a la par de atender a sus familias. Todas poseen actividades distintas, algunas son vendedoras ambulantes, otras se dedican a la venta de comidas, otras poseen despensas o confeccionas tejidos artesanales para vender.

Es un grupo muy unido y trabajador, pues además de sus actividades, ellas también realizan trabajos comunitarios, y juntan fondos para invertirlos en la mejora de su barrio.

Estas señoras desean un crédito para poder comprar mercaderías para la venta como: carnes, frutas, verduras, cosméticos, bebidas, medias, maquillajes, telas, hilos y agujas para tejer.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise to sell such as meat, fruit, vegetables, drinks, cosmetics, stockings, fabric, thread, and knitting needles

loans.name: Creciendo Hacia El Futuro, Groups 1 And 2

texts.en: Anny Belkys T., 35, is married and the mother of three--aged 11, 9, and 5.  She is currently in her 6th loan cycle with her Esperanza Bank of Hope Creciendo Hacia el Futuro ("Growing Towards the Future"), of which she is a group leader. With her future loans she hopes to move her salon into a bigger shop and to one day be able to have paid employees.  Anny's primary goal is, however, to be able to improve the quality of life of her three children.

loans.use: This group would like to improve their various businesses, like Anny who would like to improve her salon.

loans.name: Hebreo, Group 1

texts.en: Francisca G., 36, is married and the mother of two, aged 2 and 13. She has used her four Esperanza loans to start her own clothing and accessory store, and hopes that her future loans will bring her business growth and her children everything they need. Francisca is a group leader in her Esperanza Bank of Hope, Hebreo.

loans.use: This group of women would like to improve their various businesses, like Fantasia who would like to improve her clothing and accessory business.

loans.name: Bienestar En Dios (Well-Being In God) Groups Ii-4 And I-6

texts.en:
Luz, whose name means “light” in Spanish, lives with her husband and four children, ages 15, 14, 13 and 5.  They live in a small house maD. of cement blocks with a cement roof and a cement floor.  She has a small business selling clothing out of her house. She buys clothing in bulk packs and then sells each piece individually. Luz has successfully repaid 3 loans to Esperanza International and is now requesting her fourth loan. She wants to be able to continue to buy more clothing and expand her business so that her kids can grow up with everything they need and get a good education.

Note: This is a group loan for 10 people.

loans.use: This group would like to improve their various businesses, like Luz who would like to sell more clothes to better support her two children.

loans.name: La Esperanza Group

texts.es:
The group “La Esperanza” (Hope) has been established for 1 year and 2 months. The group members participate in a program called Committee of Women Entrepreneurs which brings women together to carry out profitable work with the goal of increasing income and alleviating poverty.

In our country the majority of women are in charge of family finances. In addition to seeing to the education of their children, they also hold an extra job to help with household expenses.

The women belonging to this group devote themselves to various income-producing activities. They are using the loan to buy more merchandise, in some cases, or in the case of dressmakers and food vendors, to buy supplies for the manufacture of the products they sell.

The majority of the women yearn for a better future for their children and therefore redouble their efforts to increase their income so that they will be able to offer their children the chance to study and to have better job possibilities in the future.

Today these women are asking to renew their loan in order to obtain clothes, shoes, cosmetics, fabric, thread, and cleaning products as well as food items such as meat, dairy products, fruits, vegetables, soft drinks, snacks, oil, flour, noodles, etc.

Translated by Melissa Hays, Kiva volunteer.

El comité “La Esperanza” tiene1 año y 2 meses de formación, ellas participan de un programa llamado “Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras” que agrupa a mujeres que realizan una labor lucrativa con el fin de mejorar sus ingresos y aliviar la pobreza.

En nuestro país la mayoría de las mujeres son las encargadas de la economía de la familia, además de atender y velar por la educación de los hijos, las mujeres también poseen un trabajo extra con el que ayudan con los ingresos de la casa.

Las señoras pertenecientes a este comité se dedican a diversas actividades productivas y utilizan el préstamo para comprar más mercaderías, en algunos casos, o insumos para la elaboración de los productos que venden como en el caso de las modistas o las señoras que venden comidas.

La mayoría de las mujeres anhela un futuro mejor para sus hijos por eso se esfuerzan el doble para generar mas ingresos y poder brindarles posibilidades de estudiar y lograr que el día de mañana mejores oportunidades laborales.

Hoy ellas solicitan un nuevo crédito con el que podrán adquirir ropas, calzados, maquillajes, telas, hilos, productos de limpieza al igual que comestibles como carnes, lácteos, frutas, verduras, gaseosas, golosinas, aceite, harina, fideos, etc.

loans.use: To obtain clothes, shoes, cosmetics, fabric, thread, and cleaning products as well as food items such as meat, dairy products, fruits, vegetables, soft drinks, snacks, oil, flour, noodles, etc.

loans.name: Hortense Faster

texts.es:
Mrs. Faster D. B. is from the city of Bluefields and is 57 years old. For the past 39 years Mrs. D. has baked puddings and cookies. Her clients are the visitors and residents of the neighborhood who prefer her homemade products. Mrs. D. does not have the capital required to purchase the ingredients in bulk so it is necessary to buy: 5 pounds of butter at $2.00 a pound, 3 boxes of eggs at $4.00 a box, 25 pounds of flour at $ 1.00 a pound, 50 pounds of sugar at $ 0.42 per pound, 5 pounds of lard at $2.00 a pound and 1 box of milk at $ 22.00. With this investment it will be possible to increase her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Aimee Sostowski, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Hortense Faster D. B. es originaria de la ciudad de Bluefiedls, tiene 57 años de edad. Hace 39 años la Sra. D. horna pudines y galletas, sus clientes son los transeúntes y habitantes del barrio que la prefieren por ofrecer productos caseros. La Sra. D. no cuenta con el capital necesario para comprar en grandes cantidades los ingredientes de sus productos, por eso necesita comprar: 5 libras de Mantequilla a $ 2.00 dólares la libra, 3 cajillas de huevo a $ 4.00 dólares la cajilla,25 libras de harina a $ 1.00 dólar la libra, 50 libras de azúcar a $ 0.42 centavos dólar la libra,5 libras de manteca a $ 2.00 dólares la libra y 1 caja de leche a $ 22.00 dólares la libra con esta inversión podrá aumentar su ganancia.

loans.use: To buy butter, eggs, flour, sugar, lard and milk.

payments.comment: La cuota real de pago es de $ 12.50 dólares

loans.name: Bienestar En Dios (Well-Being In God) Groups Ii-3, I-4&5

texts.en:
Yuly R. R. lives in a Haitian batey, a housing community provided by the sugarcane companies for their poor field workers. In her little wooden house with a tin roof and cement floor, Yuly lives with her husband and two children, ages 4 and 6.

In order to contribute to the family income, especially in the sugarcane off season, Yuly has a small business selling clothing. She buys the clothing in the capital of Santo Domingo, about 2 hours away from where she lives, and sells the clothing in the touristy beach city of Bavaro, another two hours of travel in the opposite direction. When she travels for work, her mother cares for her two children.

Yuly has successfully repaid 3 loans to Esperanza International and is now requesting her fourth. With the money she hopes to continue growing her business so that she can one day afford her own house and send her children to college so that they can have professional careers.

Note: This is a group loan for 13 people.

loans.use: To be able to sell more clothing and care for her two kids.

loans.name: Comité San Miguel Group

texts.es:
The San Miguel group was formed thanks to María S. who is a fruit and vegetable vendor in the Cañada San Miguel neighborhood of Lambaré. María comes from a humble family and from the time she was very small she worked hard to survive. She had to leave school to work because she had many siblings and her parents could barely feed them. She sold fruit at traffic lights in order to earn their daily bread.

Today María continues to sell fruit and vegetables, going from house to house with her vending cart to offer her merchandise to her appreciative clients. In addition, she cares for her mother who is ill and is herself a single mother of three. She works hard so that her children will not have to follow in her footsteps.

María, in her search for progress, has gone back to school and attends classes at night. She is in the last phase of her studies for which her friends and neighbors admire her greatly. María succeeded in forming a group to enroll in the Paraguay Foundation program, which gives the members access to credit.

The women are involved in various businesses including the sale of fruits, vegetables, hamburgers, food items, soft drinks and other beverages, clothes, shoes, lingerie, and jewelry. Some women operate kiosks or “despensas” (mini-markets popular in Paraguay).

Translated by Melissa Hays, Kiva volunteer.

Este Comité se formo gracias a la señora María S., quien es vendedora de frutas y verduras en el Barrio Cañada San Miguel de la ciudad de Lambaré. María proviene de una familia muy humilde. Desde pequeña trabajo duro para sobre vivir y teniendo que dejar los estudios para trabajar ya que eran muchos hermanos y sus padres apenas los podían alimentar. Fue así que desde pequeña vendió frutas en los semáforos para poder ganarse el pan del día.

María hoy día sigue vendiendo frutas y verduras, recorre los barrios con un carrito casa por casa ofreciendo su mercadería que es muy apreciada por sus clientes, además cuida de su madre enferma y es madre soltera de tres; ella trabaja arduamente para que sus hijos no tengan que correr con su misma suerte.

María en busca de su progreso, ha retomado sus estudios y va al colegio por las noches y hoy día ya está en la última etapa para culminarlo, sus amigas y vecinas la admiran bastante. María logro formar un comité para ingresar al programa de la Fundación Paraguaya, con la que acceden a créditos grupales para invertir en sus negocios.
