Las señoras se dedican a distintas actividades, entre ellas venta de frutas, verduras, comidas, ropas, zapatos, lencerías, gaseosas, bebidas varias, despensas, kioscos, hamburguesas, joyas, entre otros.

loans.use: Purchase fruits, vegetables, meat, dairy products, breadmaking ingredients, hamburgers, snacks, soft drinks and other beverages, clothes, shoes, lingerie and jewelry

loans.name: Sabina

texts.es:
Sabina is 60 years old, was unable to attend school, speak the Aymará language but understands Castellano. She is married and has three children, none of whom are dependent on her and who live in the Parcialidad D. M., in the Centro Poblado D. Camicachi, District of Llave, Province of El Collao.

Sabina has been dedicated to the purchase and sale of sheep for the last ten years. She is a member of the Communcal Bank "22 D. Setiembre", where she was given an initial loan of S/. 300.00 Peruvian Soles, which she invested in the purchasing of 4 sheep. With this loan of S/. 500.00 Peruvain Soles ($ 200), which will be repaid in four months, she will purchase 4 sheep and 2 pigs, which will be sold later on in the markets of Llave.

She explains that being a member of the Communal bank has taught her to be responsible with her payments and the loan has helped her improve her business as well as her economic gains and she is very grateful.

Her vision for the future is to continue with the business and that her children all have good jobs.

Translated from [language] by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

Sabina tiene 60 años, no pudo estudiar, habla el idioma aymará y entienD. el castellano, es casada y tiene tres hijos, quienes ya no dependen D. ella y vive en la Parcialidad D. M., del Centro Poblado D. Camicachi, Distrito D. Ilave, Provincia D. El Collao. Sabina se dedica a la compra y venta D. ovejas, desD. hace diez años, pertenece al Banco Comunal “22 D. Setiembre”, donD. tuvo un crédito inicial D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, que lo invirtió en la compra D. cuatro ovejas. Con este crédito D. S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, el cual serà cancelado en 4 meses, comprarà 4 ovejas y 2 chanchos, que serán vendidos después en las ferias D. Ilave. Ella manifiesta que siendo socia del Banco Comunal aprendió a ser responsable en sus pagos y el crédito le ayudo a incrementar su negocio y a la vez su ingreso económico y esta muy agradecida. Su visión futura es seguir con el negocio y que sus hijos tengan un buen trabajo.

loans.use: Purchasing sheep and smaller animals

loans.name: Roxana

texts.es:
Roxana is 38 years old, studied until sixth grade, is married and has five children (1 girl and 4 boys) who are all dependent on her.

She is a member of the Communal Bank Andres Santa Cruz de Chuachua, in the Central village of the same name, in the district of Zepita, provice of Chucuito - Juli and the region of Puno. With the first loan she received of S/.300.00 Peruvain Soles, she invested in the purchasing of merchandise for the store she has had for the past three years. The money was only enough to purchase 1 bag of sufar, 1 bag of rice and three boxes of soft drinks.

With the loan of S/.2,500.00 Peruvian Soles ($ 900), which she will repay in four months time, she would purchase three or four boxes of soft drinks, one bag of rice, 1 bag of sugar and two crates of cookies/biscuits, among other things. Half of the money would be used to purchase a cow to fatten. Her children already help her in the businesses that she takes on.

She is very happy because the businesses she has are going well. Previously she had to ask her husband for money, currently she always has money in order to settle the food expenses of her children. Additionally, she is increasing her initial capital.

Her dream is to have a well equipped store, to continue to increase the amount of money she makes and for her children to become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

Roxana tiene 38 años de edad, estudió hasta sexto de primaria, es casada y madre de 5 hijos (01 mujer y cuatro varones), quienes aún depende de ella. Ella pertenece al Banco Comunal Andrés Santa Cruz de Chuachua, del Centro poblado del mismo nombre, del distrito de Zepita, provincia de Chucuito – Juli y Región de Puno. Con su préstamo inicial de S/.300.00 nuevos soles, invirtió en la compra de mercadería para la tienda que tiene hace tres años, el dinero solo alcanzó para 1 saco de azúcar, 1 saco de arroz y 3 paquetes de gaseosas. Con el préstamo de S/.2,500.00 nuevos soles, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará 3 paquetes de gaseosas, 1 saco de arroz, 1 saco de azúcar, 2 cajas de galletas, 4 paquetes de gaseosas, entres otros y con la mitad comprará una vaca para el engorde, ya que sus hijos le ayudan en los negocios que emprendió. Ella esta muy contenta porque en los negocios que tiene le va bien, antes ella miraba solo al esposo para que le diera el dinero, en la actualidad siempre tiene dinero para solventar sus gastos de alimentación de sus hijos. Además está incrementando su capital inicial. Su mayor sueño es tener una tienda grande bien equipada, continuar con el engorde de ganado vacuno y sean profesionales sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase diverse articles (groceries)

loans.name: Petrona

texts.es:
Petrona is 60 years old, married, and without an education. However, her business has allowed her to become more familiar with numbers and counting. She is a mother of seven children and in her care is a son, a daughter and an orphaned niece.

She is a member of the Communal Bank "Nueva Horizonte" of the Centro village of the Caritamaya sector Marquiri in the district of Acora, province and region of Puno. She decided to belong to this with the aim of launching a business that buys and sells sheep in the weekly Saturday markets in the city of Acora. This has, from the beginning, increased her capital and economic resources.

With the loan of S/. 500.00 Peruvian Soles ($ 200.00), which will be repaid in four months time, she will purchase sheep in order to sell them in the markets.

She is very happy, and being a member of the Communal Bank has taught her to be responsible, be happy, manage well her money and to support the other women. Her dream is to continue with this business, and see her children and niece become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

Petrona tiene 60 años D. edad, casada, no estudió pero sin embargo con el negocio logró conocer los números y firmar, es madre D. 07 hijos y a su lado están un hijo, una hija y una nieta huérfana. Es socia del Banco Comunal Nuevo Horizonte del Centro poblado D. Caritamaya sector Marquiri del distrito D. Acora, provincia y región D. Puno. Ella decidió pertenecer con fin D. emprender el negocio D. compra y venta D. ganado ovino en las ferias semanales del día sábado en la ciudad D. Acora, ya que con los primeros préstamos aumento su capital e ingreso económico. Con este préstamo D. S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, el cual serà cancelando en cuatro meses, comprarà ganado para luego venderlos en las ferias. Ella, está feliz, ya que en el Banco Comunal aprendió ser responsable, estar alegre, administrar bien el dinero y ser solidaria con las otras mujeres. Su deseo granD. es continuar con el negocio, sea profesional sus hijos y su nieta.

loans.use: Purchasing sheep

loans.name: Olga

texts.es:
Olga is 27 years old, she studied up to grade 9, she speaks "aymara" and Spanish, she lives with her partner and has two children that are studying. Her address is in the Marquiri sector, in Caritamaya, district of Acora, province and region of Puno.

Olga has had a small general store for five years, she also started buying and selling livestock (lamb and beef) at fairs in Ilave and Acora. In addition, she makes crafts (puppets, hats, scarves).

She belongs to the “New Horizon” community bank, where she received an initial loan of $115 USD (S/. 300) that was used to purchase six lambs to feed and sell when grown.

With savings and the loan of $375 USD (S/. 1000), which will be repaid in four months, she will buy a loom to make hats and puppets in large quantities and this way sell them in large quantities as well.

She is very thankful for the first loan because it helped her switch activities and increase her income, learning to be responsible with her payments. Her big dream is to purchase different types of looms and be able to offer a variety of products to increase her income and help with her children’s studies.

Translated from Spanish by Sofia Burt, Kiva volunteer.

Olga tiene 27 años de edad, estudió hasta tercero de secundaria, habla el idioma aymará y castellano, convive con su pareja y tiene dos hijos que están estudiando en la escuela, su domicilio esta ubicado en el Sector Marquiri, del Centro Poblado de Caritamaya, del Distrito de Acora, Provincia y región de Puno.

Olga tiene una pequeña tienda de abarrotes, hace cinco años, también se dedica a la compra y venta de ganado vacuno y ovino que los compra y vende en las ferias de Ilave y Acora a su vez se dedica a la producción de Artesanía (títeres, chullos, chalinas).

Pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nuevo Horizonte” donde tuvo un crédito inicial de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles con lo que pudo comprar seis ovejas para engorde y después ser vendidos.

Con este crédito de S/. 1000.00 nuevos soles, el cual pagará en cuatro meses, comprarà, junto a sus ahorros, una Maquina de tejer, para que pueda elaborar, chullos, títeres, en cantidad y poderlos vender por mayor.

Ella esta muy agradecida por el crédito por que le ayudo a cambiar de negocio e incrementar su ingreso económico; aprendiendo a ser responsable en sus pagos. El gran sueño que ella tiene es comprar mas variedad de maquinas de tejer para que pueda variar los productos y de esa manera incrementar su ingreso económico y poder hacer estudiar a sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase a loom to weave hats, puppets and scarves

loans.name: Claritas Group

texts.es:
The Claritas Group comes from a beautiful town that is situated in the mountains that surround Atitlán Lake. This is a very traditional town. Here, one can find the women walking through the streets wearing their traditional outfits and speaking Quiche, a Mayan language. The people from Santa Clara are friendly people and are respectful T. strangers.

Santa Clara is passing through an important time, especially for the women. For the last few years, the women in the community are being recognized as independent people that can make important economic decisions and be responsible for them. This attitude opens more doors for microfinance.

The members of Claritas are a group of incredible and warm women. They meet three times a week T. carry out their financial transactions with The Friendship Bridge.

The Claritas Group has been recognized by The Friendship Bridge as excellent clients. They continue working with a project for years, always repaying punctually and standing out as leaders within their communal banks. The success of this group is based on the fact that all of the members are very responsible and that they have confidence in each other. The members maintain that the money they earn is not T. be spent, but is T. be invested because only then will they get returns and generate profits.

Many of the clients that work in this communal bank invest their loan inT. bakeries. Santa Clara is known for the delicious bread that it produces. Some of the women make bread in their homes, then they bring the bread T. a neighboring village, San Juan la Laguna, and they sell it there. The interesting thing is that they put the bread inT. baskets that they carry on their heads and will sell it from house T. house! Other women work in the production of beaded belts. Also, there is a member who bought a dressmaking machine with her loans. Finally, there is a woman that breeds animals, such as chickens and pigs, for sale.

This is a special group, and we should accompany them on their journey and support them. With your support, you will be able T. give them the opportunity T. improve their lives.

Translated from Spanish by A. Shah, Kiva Volunteer.

Las Claritas provienen de un bello pueblo que está ubicado en las montañas que rodean el mágico lago de Atitlán. Este pueblo es muy tradicional. En este se puede encontrar a todas las mujeres caminando por las calles vistiendo sus trajes tradicionales y hablando el maya- Quiche. Un aspecT. muy bueno de los Santa Clareños es que son gente amigables y respetuosos con los extranjeros.

Santa Clara está pasando por un momenT. importante, especialmente para las mujeres. Desde hace unos años atrás, las mujeres dentro de la comunidad, están siendo reconocidas como personas indepedientes que pueden tomar decisiones económicas importantes y ser responsable de ellas. Para nuestro beneficio esa actitud le abre más puertas al micro- crédiT..

Las Claritas son un grupo de mujeres increíbles, en lo personal me quedé impresionado cuando entré al cuarT. donde este grupo de señoras se reunen tres veces por semana para efectuar sus transacciones financieras con The Friendship Bridge. Desde que llegué al cuarT. ellas fueron muy cálidas conmigo, fue una experiencia muy agradable.

Las Claritas han sido reconocidas por The Friendship Bridge como clientas de excelencia. Ellas llevan trabajando con el proyecT. por años, siempre pagando puntualmente y destacándose como lideres dentro de sus bancos comunales. El éxiT. de este grupo se base en que todas las clientes son muy responsables y se tienen confianza entre ellas. Durante la reunión le pregunte a una cliente sobre sus decisiones con respecT. al dinero y ella respondió que “el dinero no se gasta, solo se invierte porque sino no da vuelta y no se genera ganancia”

Un gran número de clientas que trabajan en este banco comunal invierten su crédiT. en panaderías. Santa Clara es conocido por el delicioso pan que produce. Algunas de las señoras producen el pan en sus casas, luego se lo llevan en un carro a la aldea aledaña, San Juan la Laguna, y lo van a vender ahí. Lo interesante es que ponen el pan en canastos que lo cargan en la cabeza y van a vender de casa en casa! Otras señoras trabajan en la elaboración de fajas de mostacilla. También hay una clienta que con sus préstamos se pudo comprar una máquina de confección. Finalmente, hay una señora que cría animales, pollos y cerdos para su venta.

Este grupo es especial y creo que debemos acompañarlos y apoyarlos, y ustedes con su apoyo van a poder darle la oportunidad de superarse.

loans.use: To buy supplies for a bakery, beads, animal feed, and fabric for dressmaking

loans.name: Juan Carlos

texts.es:
Juan Carlos is married and has two children, and he and his spouse are expecting a third child. He started his business 15 years ago. Before that, his father taught him how to do electrical and plumbing work, and he worked for 15 years in construction and architecture. Today he has the opportunity to rent a spot in a market, but he has to build his own stand because his location is outside the main entry.

Juan Carlos needs a loan of US $500, which he will pay back in six months, to set up his stand, and he is already thinking about hiring a clerk to mind it when it gets going because people who don’t know Juan Carlos now soon will thanks to his new location, and those who do will have to be able to find him whenever he is out.

Translated from Spanish by Ian Harvey, Kiva Volunteer.

Juan Carlos, es casado tiene 2 hijos y esta en espera del tercero, inicio su negocio hace 15 años ya que su papa le enseño el oficio de plomero y electricista , desde hace mas de 15 años el trabaja en esto para diferentes constructoras, arquitectos, entre otros hoy tiene la oportunidad de que le renten un pedacito en un mercado, solo que el tiene que construir su propia caseta , pues es afuera de la entrada principal.

El necesita un credito por US $500 que pagara en 6 meses para instalar su propio loca, ya que piensa emplear a un muchacho que le cuide el negocio mientras el esta en servicio, porque ahora las personas que no lo conocían lo conocerán y las que lo conocen tendrán donde buscarlo.

loans.use: Setting up market stand

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business #58468

loans.name: Chuiquisis Group

texts.es:
The women of Chuiquisis Group come from a rural town in the area of Sololá called Concepción. This place is known in the area for the great agricultural production that it has. Many merchants come to Concepción to buy vegetables, for the most part, biweekly. The peasants plant onions, carrots, and cabbage among other vegetables. Because of the work that they put in to the land, the peasants have designed strategies to maintain the fertility of the soil. For example, in Concepción, the practice of rotating the type of vegetable to be planted in the same space of land for much of the year is widely used. Basic techniques like those mentioned minimize the risk of farming for the group members.

The Chuiquisis group has been together for almost four years. They have already had four loans with this institution. This group is very good with re-payments, since the members are very responsible. If this is not the case, at the end of the loan, the group separates from the person that has not been responsible. In this way, the reputation of the group has remained intact. The women say that the success of the group lies in the responsibility of each woman and in the fact that they choose well at the time of making the group.

All of the women in this group work in the agricultural sector. In their plots, the women plant the traditional vegetables of the area. They use their loan to buy seeds, fertilizer, and to rent the land.

Another positive aspect that this female group has is that all the women believe in the power of education. The members try to send all of their children to school, at least to primary school. This attitude is very positive, since it demonstrates a great improvement between the generations of the parents and the children.

The Chuiquisis Group is made up of a group of working women that want to go forward with their families. As a result, we have to extend them a hand by means of a loan that will help them to drive their businesses and to generate more profits that will allow them to invest in their children.

Translated from Spanish by A. Shah, Kiva Volunteer.

Las mujeres Chuiquisis provienen de un pueblo muy rural en el departamento de Sololá llamado Concepción. Este lugar es conocido en el medio por la gran producción agrícola que tiene. A Concepción llegan muchos comerciantes a comprar verduras al por mayor quincenalmente. Los campesinos siembran cebollas, zanahorias, repollo entre otras verduras. Los campesinos debido a la presión que ejercen a la tierra han diseñado estrategias para mantener la fertilidad de la tierra. Por ejemplo, en Concepción es ampliamente practicada la técnica de rotación de cultivo así como varíar el tipo de vegetales que van a sembrar en un mismo espacio de tierra a lo largo del año. Técnica básicas como las mencionadas minimizan el riesgo del cultivo para las clientes.

El grupo Chuiquisis lleva junto por casi cuatro años. Ellas ya han trabajado cuatro créditos con la institución. Este grupo ha sido de muy buena paga ya que las integrantes son muy responsables, y cuando no lo son, al final del crédito separan a la persona que ha faltado con la institución. De esta manera la reputación del grupo se mantiene intacta. Las señoras comentaron que el éxito del grupo yace en la responsabilidad de cada mujer y que se escogieron muy bien a la hora de formar el grupo.

Todas las señoras de este grupo trabajan en el sector agrícola. En sus terrenos ellas siembran los vegetales tradicionales del área. Ellas utilizan su crédito para la compra de semillas, abono, fertillizante y algunas lo utilizan para el alquiler de la tierra.

Otro factor muy positivo que tienen este grupo de señoras es que todas ellas creen en el poder de la educación. Las clientes tratan de envíar a todos sus hijos a la escuela, por lo menos a la escuela primaria. Esta actitud es muy positivo ya que demuestra una gran mejora generacional entre padre e hijos.

El grupo Chuiquisis está conformado por un grupo de mujeres trabajadoras que quieren salir adelante junto con sus familias, es por eso que nosotros tenemos que extenderles una mano por medio de un préstamo que las va a ayudar a impulsar sus negocios y generar mayores ganancias que las puedan invertir en sus hijos.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and tools for cultivation and vegetables.

loans.name: Maria De Lourdes

texts.es:
Lourdes is a single mother of five daughters. Only three of them live with her as the other two live with their grandmother. She was unable to support all of them and her mother helped her with the others. Today her finances are better but her children do no want to come back to her. She tries very hard to give them what she could not give them before. Five years ago she started her business selling skin creams which she has kept afloat together with her family, as two of her daughters help her with sales.

She needs a loan of US$400, which she will pay back in 6 months, in order to repair her car. She has no other method of transport to use to visit her clients to offer them products and to collect payment. For this reason it is urgent that it is repaired, and with your help her business will stay afloat.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne, Kiva volunteer.

Lourdes es mama soltera que tiene 5 hijas, solo 3 viven con ellas ya que las otras 2 viven con su abuelita a ella no le alcanzaba para mantenerlas a todas y su mama le ayudo con las demás, hoy su economía es mejor pero sus hijas ya no quieren regresar con ella. Se esfuerza mucho para darles lo que en su tiempo no pudo darles. Hace 5 años inico su negocio de venta de cremas para la piel lo que le ha ayudado a salir adelante junto con su familia, ya que 2 de sus hijas le ayudanm a vender.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $400 que pagara en 6 meses para reparar su auto ya que no tiene otro medio de transporte para como visitar a sus clintes para ofrecerles productos y para cobranza por lo que le urge repararlo, con tu apoyo ella saldra adelante.

loans.use: Repairs to her car which is necessary for her work

loans.name: Clareñas Group

texts.es:
The members of Clareñas Group come from a beautiful town called Santa Clara. This town is situated among the green mountains that surround Atitlán Lake. Santa Clara is known for the production of beautiful baskets and bread.

Clareñas is a long-standing group. They have been working with the same communal bank for almost nine years. The values that The Friendship Bridge tries to communicate to all of its clients have already been internalized for the members of Clareñas.

The members of this group are involved in a variety of businesses. For example, one client is a baker. She has an oven inside her house where she makes the bread that she will sell at the store and in neighboring towns. Two others work as animal breeders. They breed chickens and pigs for sale. Another woman is known for producing natural hams, which, surprisingly, are black. The group also includes a merchant, who buys and sells rice and beans. Both foods are considered to be essential in the diet of the indigenous population in rural Guatemala. Finally, one woman sells tamales in the market.

The truth is that these businesswomen are very versatile. The women pursue more than one activity; when they notice that the sale of one good is low, they invest their loan into other activities. For example, the women that breed animals realized that the price of animal feed had risen, so they began to embroider pretty flowers on traditional blouses in Santa Clara.

The members of the Clareñas Group have been receiving training as part of their association with The Friendship Bridge. They paid a great deal of attention to the training that dealt with how to manage money, since the women could learn some tools that to help their businesses grow.

The group members feel comfortable working with The Friendship Bridge and with the methods of communal banks because they don’t have many requirements for clients seeking a loan. In addition, the installments of the loans also designed to satisfy the needs of this sector of the market. Finally, one of the clients commented that she appreciates that their group only includes women, because they feel more comfortable to express themselves and be more open in their group.

Translated from Spanish by A. Shah, Kiva Volunteer.

Las Clareñas provienen de un bello pueblo llamado Santa Clara la laguna. Dicho pueblo queda entre las verdes montañas que rodean el lago Atitlán. Santa Clara es conocido por la producción de bellas canastas y la producción de pan.

Las Clareñas es un grupo ya consolidado. Ellas han venido trabajando en el mismo banco comunal ya por casi nueve años gracias a esto, los valores que The Friendship Bridge trata de transmitir a todas sus clientas ya han sido interiorizado por ellas.

En este grupo uno puede encontrar una variedad de empresarias. Por ejemplo una cliente es panadera. Ella tiene un horno dentro de su casa donde ella produce el pan que va a vender al mercado y a pueblos aledaños. Otras dos trabajan en la crianza de animales. Ellas crían pollos y cerdos para la venta. Otra señora es conocida por producir jabones naturales, lo sorprendente es que son de color negro. También podemos encontrar una clienta comerciante, ella compra y vende maíz y fríjol. Ambos alimentos son considerados esenciales en la dieta de los pobladores indígenas de las áreas rurales de Guatemala. Finalmente, una señora se encargada de vender tamales en el mercado.

La verdad es que estas empresarias son muy versátiles. Ellas no solo se dedican a un solo negocio, cuando las señoras notan que la venta está baja tienden a invertir su crédito en otras actividades. Por ejemplo, las señoras que crían animales se dan cuenta que el precio del alimento para animales ha incrementado, ellas empiezan a bordar bellas flores en las blusas tradicionales de Santa Clara.

Las Clareñas han venido recibiendo una variedad de capacitaciones de parte de la institución. Las capacitaciones que más le llamaron la atención fue la de “cómo administrar mi dinero”, ya que las señoras pudieron aprender algunas herramientas que van a hacer que su negocio crezca.

Las Clareñas se sienten cómodas trabajando con The Friendship Bridge y la metodología de bancos comunales porque a la hora de solicitar un crédito se les pide a las clientes muy pocos requisitos. Además los plazos de los préstamos están diseñados para satisfacer las necesidades de este sector del mercado. Finalmente, una de las clientes comentó que les gusta trabajar bajo esta metodología porque son solo mujeres y de esa manera ellas se sienten más cómodas de expresarse y desenvolverse en grupo.

loans.use: To buy rice and beans, supplies to produce ham, flour and yeast, and animals and food.

loans.name: Trixana Group

texts.es:
The majority of the women that make up the Trixana Group come from a beautiful town called San Andrés Semetabaj. San Andrés is situated in the Atitlán region. The people of this beautiful place are fortunate enough to wake up every day and admire the beauty of Atitlán Lake. San Andrés is also known for being a traditional town that conserves its values, but is also developing.

The members of Trixana are a group of women who are learning to manage credit. This is the second loan that they have requested. They are asking for this loan for many reasons. First, this is the first time that they have access to a loan so easily; for them to qualify, it is enough that they are a group of women, that they agree to stick together to repay the loan, and that they have a photocopy of a government-issued identity document. Second, they are requesting another loan because they benefitted from the first one. They said that thanks to the previous loan, they were able to buy more raw materials, which permitted them to make more profits.

Apparently in the micro-finances, especially with new clients, being able to buy a more merchandise and generating more profits is something that rarely happens. Because of this, their success is remarkable.

The members of Trixana work in different industries. Most of the women work in the textiles industry; they knit traditional blouses called “huililes.” Also, two women have a tortilla shop. This business has profits because tortillas have an inelastic demand in rural Guatemala. There are also women that work in a variety of businesses, such as cultivating flowers and corn, selling beans and rice, and looking after a store. A plot of land, that 8 years ago cost Q250.00 to rent, now costs Q800.00, according to Alicia C..

América C. said that she likes working with The Friendship Bridge because of the training that she receives, especially that of her rights as a woman. Now, thanks to this training, she knows her rights as a woman. We feel very satisfied with this. Your support will contribute enormously with the development of this Guatemalan town.

Translated from Spanish by A. Shah, Kiva Volunteer.

Las mujeres que conforman el grupo Trixana en su mayoría provienen de un bello pueblo llamado San Andrés Semetabaj. San Andres queda en la región de Atitlán. Los pobladores de este bello lugar tienen la fortuna de levantarse todos los días y admirar la belleza del lago Atitlán. San Andrés también es conocido por ser un pueblo tradicional que conserva sus valores pero que también está desarrollando.

Las Trixanas son un grupo de mujeres que está aprendiendo a manejar el crédito. Este crédito que van a solicitar es el segundo en su vida. Ellas están solicitando este crédito por muchas razones: primero, es la primera vez que tienen acceso a un préstamo tan fácil, solo basta un grupo de mujeres, una garantía solidaria y una fotocopia del documento nacional de identidad. Segundo, porque les fue bien en su crédito anterior. Ellas comentaron que gracias al préstamo anterior fueron capaces de comprar una mayor cantidad de materia prima lo cual les permitió generar más ganancias.

Al parecer en las micro finanzas, especialmente con clientes nuevas, lograr poder comprar un poco más de mercadería y generar un poco más de ganancias es un evento que las clientes nunca esperaron lograr. Es por eso, en parte, porque las microfinanzas es un éxito alrededor del mundo.

Las Trixanas trabajan en distintas industrias. En su mayoría las mujeres trabajan en el área textil, ellas tejen blusas tradicionales llamadas huipiles. Luego, dos mujeres tienen una tortillería. Este negocio no tiene pierde, ya que las tortillas tiene una demanda inelástica en el área rural de Guatemala. Luego, hay mujeres que trabajan en una variedad de negocios como el cultivo de flores, maíz, venta de frijol y maíz y atienden una tienda. Hace ocho años alquilar cinco cuerdas de tierra (25m x 25m) costaba Q250.00 el día de hoy alquilar la misma cantidad de tierras cuesta Q800.00 según comentaba Alicia C..

América C. comentó que le gustaba trabajar con The Friendship Bridge por las capacitaciones que recibía, especialmente la de los derechos de la mujer. Ahora, gracias a estas capacitaciones, ella está segura de sus derechos como mujer. Nosotros como institución nos sentimos muy satisfechos con esto y usted gracias a su apoyo van a contribuir enormemente con el desarrollo del pueblo Guatemalteco.

loans.use: To buy thread, corn to make tortillas, supplies for the stores, and rice and beans.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Friendship Bridge - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: San Roque Group

texts.es:
The San Roque association is part of the Los Andes business center. With the help of their credit advisor, they work very responsibly in all their group activities. Almost all married with large families, they tell us that the daily expenses of their homes exceed the income from their business, because of their large families and the increasing requirements of growing children.

Most of the group is in business selling various products by mobile sales. For example, Mrs. Monica sells candies and chocolates and Mrs. Delia sells cleaning products. They also sell school supplies, fruit, and other things. They say that with this type of sales, the products are handled and become battered and sometimes they have to throw them away. Therefore they want to invest capital in order to obtain fixed stands in the markets or on the principal streets where they will have steady sales and maintain their products in the best condition. In this way they will improve their income and the economic stability of their homes.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva volunteer

La asociación San Roque pertenece al centro focal de Los Andes, con la ayuda de su asistente de créditos trabajan muy responsables en todas sus actividades de grupo. Casi todas casadas, con familias numerosas nos cuentan que los gastos diarios que tienen en sus hogares sobrepasan al ingreso que obtienen en sus negocios ya que su familia son numerosas y sus hijos van creciendo y necesitan mayores necesidades. La mayor parte del grupo se dedica a comercio, de variados productos, venta que la realizan de forma ambulante, por ejemplo, la señora Mónica vende golosinas y chocolates, La señora Delia vende productos de limpieza, también se dedican a la venta material escolar, fruta y otros. Afirman que este tipo de venta, por el manipuleo hace que los productos se maltraten y en ocasiones deben desecharlos por lo que ellas desean invertir capital para poder obtener puestos fijos en mercados o en principales calles donde obtengan ventas seguras y mantengan sus productos en optimas condiciones. De esta manera mejorarían sus ingresos y estabilidad económica en sus hogares

loans.use: Capital to buy or rent fixed stands or shops

loans.name: Carlota Del Carmen

texts.es:
Mrs. Carlota del Carmen L. is a 50-year-old single woman with three children. The two eldest help her in the business, the other is 21 years old and studying to finish his course in Systems Engineering. The father of her children is a builder who helps her when he can. Her business is the sale of carbonated drinks and natural fruit drinks, she also sells pork with prepared manioc. At Christmas time she sells fruits such as apples and grapes in order to survive since there is no other steady income in the house.

Her loan proposal is to inject a little capital into her business so she can offer her products every day. Her greatest desire is to open a cafe-style drinks stand and increase her business. Her dream is to have her own premises for her business since in wintertime she gets so wet she even loses her merchandise or has to stop selling other products. If she had her own premises she could stop paying rent.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva volunteer

la señora carlota del Carmen L., es soltera tiene 50 años de edad tiene tres hijos, dos mayores de edad que le ayudan en el comercio y el otro tiene 21 años de edad estudia esta por finzalizar la carrera en ingenieria en sistema, el padre de sus hijos es albañil, le ayuda cuando puede, sus actividad economica es la venta de gaseosas y frescos naturales, tambien vende chancho con yuca ya preparada, y en epoca de navidad ofrece frutas como manzanas y uva, para poder sobrevivir ya que no hay otros ingresos fijos en el hogar. El proposito de solicitar prestamos es para poder inyectarle un poco de capital a su negocio de esta manera poder ofertar su producto a diario. Su mayor deseo es llegar a instalar una refresqueria tipo cafetin y agrandar mas su negocio . Su mayor sueño es tener un local propio donde instalar su negocio ya que en epocas de invierno se moja al punto de llega a perder incluso mercaderia o deja de vender otros productos, que al tener su propio local dejaria de pagar alquiler.

loans.use: Working capital for additional merchandise

loans.name: 24 De Enero- De Panamericana Group

texts.es:
The "24 de Enero- De Panamericana" (Panamerican January 24th) association consists of 12 active members who work next to the Pro-Mujer family in the center of the Panamerican city of El Alto. The day starts very early for the association, since they make their living selling vegetables and fruits in the La Ceja Street Market in El Alto. They obtain products from wholesalers, and then sell them retail. In general they generate sufficient income to cover their daily expenses, but now they wish to invest in order to provide an additional variety of products, to expand their businesses, generate increased income, and improve their quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva volunteer

La asociación 24 de enero de Panamericana esta formada por 12 miembros activos que trabajan junto a la familia de Pro-Mujer en el centro focal de Panamericana de la ciudad de El Alto. Muy temprano comienza el día para la asociación 24 de Enero, ya que se dedican a la venta de verduras y fruta en la feria de la Ceja de El Alto, adquieren productos de mayoristas, para luego vender éstos al por menor por lo general ellas generan ingresos suficientes para sus gastos diarios , pero ahora quieren invertir para proveerse de otra variedad de productos para ampliar sus negocios y asi les permita generar mayores ingresos y mejorar su calidad de vida.

loans.use: Capital for purchasing products

loans.name: Olga

texts.es:
Olga is 29 years old and she completed her education up to primary school level. She has two daughters and one son, is married and lives in the El Collao province of the Puno region.

She is an active member of the communal bank “22nd of September” in M.. With the first loans she received, she started a business buying and selling sheep at the street market in Ilave. With later loans, she and her husband decided to also raise livestock. In addition, they began buying and selling regional products such as potatoes, potato flour, geese, and tunta (derived from potatoes) at the weekly markets in the cities of Camiachi and Punto.

They would use half of this loan of 2,000.00 soles, to be repaid in 4 installments, to buy a young bull. The other half would be used to buy regional products such as potatoes, chuño and tunta (potato derivatives) to sell at the Puno market on Saturdays. They hope to increase their sales and, therefore, generate greater income to help them financially. The loan would be repaid over a period of four months.

Her dream is to augment her income enough to buy a house in the city of Ilave and start up a workshop making skirts/petticoats and to continue raising livestock. Her goal is for her children to continue their studies and become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Olga tiene 29 años de edad, su nivel educativo es primaria completa, es madre de dos hijas y un varón, es casada y domiciliada en la parcialidad de Alpacuyo del Centro Poblado de Camicachi, del distrito de Ilave, provincia El Collao y Región de Puno. Ella es socia activa del Banco Comunal de 22 de Setiembre de la parcialidad de M., con los primeros créditos que recibió emprendió el negocio de compra y venta de ovinos en la feria dominical del distrito de Ilave, después con los posteriores préstamos decidieron junto con su esposo realizar el engorde de ganado y además realizar la compra y venta de productos de la zona como: papa, chuño, oca y tunta en las ferias semanales del Centro Poblado de Camicachi y Puno. Con este crédito de S/. 2,000.00 nuevos soles, el cual serà pagado en 4 cuotas, la mitad serà utilizada para comprar 01 torete y con la otra parte adquirirá productos de la zona como: papa, chuño, tunta y oca para vender en feria del día sábado en la ciudad de Puno, ya que de esa manera garantiza mayores ingresos económicos para incrementar su capital. El préstamo estará pagando durante cuatro meses. Su sueño mayor es incrementar más su capital, para comprar una casa en la ciudad de Ilave para poner el taller de confección de enaguas, continuar con el engorde de ganado vacuno y que estudien sus hijos y sean profesionales.

loans.use: Purchase of a bull as well as other regional products.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Manuela Ramos / CrediMUJER - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Nicolasa

texts.es:
Nicolasa is 38 years old, and she completed her education up to the first year of secondary school. She speaks Aymará and understands Spanish. She is married with four children, one of whom is grown and lives independently. Her other three children are still in school. Her house is located in the Maquera section of the El Collao province.

She dedicates herself to buying and selling sheep at the markets in Ilave on Sundays, and on Fridays in the city of Camiachi. She also travels to Arequipa twice a month, carrying sheep meat and potato products and quinoa, which she sells at the various markets within that city. She takes advantage of her trips to Arequipa to see her children, who live there.

She belongs to the communal bank “22nd of September” which granted her an initial loan of 300 soles, which she invested into the purchase of three sheep. With this loan of 1,000 soles, to be repaid over four months, she will buy ten sheep to raise and sell. She has dedicated herself to this business since she was a youngster, starting with the sale of products such as chuño (a potato derivative), potatoes, and beans.

She tells us that, being a member of a communal bank, she has learned to be punctual and responsible about her loan payments. Her dreams are to buy a house in Arequipa, for her children continue their studies and to continue successfully with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Nicolasa tiene 38 años, estudio hasta primero D. secundaria, habla el aymará y entienD. el castellano, es casada y tiene cuatro hijos, uno D. ellos ya es independiente y tres están estudiando en la escuela, su casa queda en la Parcialidad Maquera D. la provincia D. El Collao. Ella se dedica a la compra y venta D. ovejas, en las ferias D. Ilave los domingos y los viernes en Camicachi. También viaja a la Región D. Arequipa dos veces al mes, llevando carne D. ovino, productos como chuño, papa, quinua, que los venD. en los diferentes mercados D. la ciudad y a su vez aprovecha en visitar a sus hijos que se encuentran en esa ciudad. Pertenece al Banco Comunal “22 D. Setiembre” donD. tuvo un crédito inicial D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles que lo invirtió en la compra D. tres ovejas. Con este crédito D. S/.1000.00 nuevos soles, el cual será pagado en 4 meses; comprarà diez ovejas D. engorD., las cuales serán vendidas; ella se dedica a esta actividad desD. muy joven, inicio con la venta D. productos como chuño, papa, habas. Ella nos cuenta que siendo socia del Banco Comunal aprendió a ser puntual y responsable en sus pagos. El sueño que ella tiene es comprar a una casa en Arequipa, que sus hijos sigan estudiando y trabajen y ella pueda seguir con el negocio.

loans.use: Purchase of sheep.

loans.name: Nimia Rosalia

texts.es:
Nimia belongs to the communal bank “22nd of September”, located in the Ilave district, El Collao province of the Puno region. She dedicates herself to raising livestock (bulls). With the previous loans she received, she dedicated herself to raising sheep. Her earnings have helped her to purchase more animals to raise, which she does over a period of three weeks. At one month’s time, she sells them in the city of Ilave at the Sunday market. For this reason, she decided to request a loan of 2,000 soles, to be repaid over four installments, to purchase two bulls. She is very content with her work because, together with her husband, she carries out her enterprise and her dreams include buying food for her livestock and providing an education for her children. She is 35 years old, studied until the third year of primary school, and is married with five children.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Nimia pertenece al Banco Comunal 22 de Setiembre de la Parcialidad M. del Centro Poblado de Camicachi, del distrito de Ilave, provincia El Collao y Región Puno. Ella se dedica al engorde de ganado vacuno (toros de dos a cuatro dientes). Con los anteriores créditos que recibió se dedicó en el engorde de ovejas, ahora en la actualidad con los últimos prestamos esta realizando engorde de ganado vacuno y compra de concentrados para el ganado, esta actividad económica le está generando más ganancia para poder incrementar más ganado vacuno para el engorde, el engorde lo hace durante 3 semanas y a un mes y la venta lo realiza en la feria del día domingo en la ciudad de Ilave. Por ello, ella decidió seguir con el préstamo de S/. 2,000.00 nuevos soles, la cual cancelará en cuatro cuotas y adquirirá dos toros para el engorde. Ella esta contenta con su trabajo, ya que junto con el esposo emprende este negocio y su mayor sueño es adquirir una picadura de alimentos para el ganado y hacer estudiar a sus hijos. Tiene 35 años de edad, estudió hasta tercer de primaria es madre de cinco hijos y es casada.

loans.use: Purchase of livestock.

loans.name: Mery

texts.es:
Mery is 31 years old and completed her education through the third year of secondary school. She is married and the mother of three children who still rely on her support. She belongs to the communal bank “Lupakas” of the Huariquisana community, located in the Piculyo district of the Puno region. With her first loan of 300 soles, she invested in the purchase of materials for making rope. She has done this activity for ten years, with the help of her husband and son. With the loan of 2,000 soles, to be repaid over four months, she will purchase 3 packages of hemp material, 2 packages of raffia, and other items. This business is generating more income, but she still needs additional capital to meet the demand in the markets of Ilave and Juliaca both wholesale and retail. Mery is very content because over the past few years she has grown her business as well as her income. Her biggest dreams include the purchase of a means of transportation to move from market to market, and to have children who become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Mery tiene 31 años de edad, estudió hasta tercero de secundaria, es casada, madre de tres hijos que aún depende de ella. Ella pertenece al Banco Comunal Lupakas de la comunidad Huariquisana, del distrito de Pilcuyo, provincia de EL Collao Ilave y Región Puno. Con su préstamo inicial de S/.300.00 nuevos soles, invirtió en la compra de material para la elaboración de sogas. Esta actividad ha emprendido hace 10 años con el apoyo de su esposo e hijo. Con el préstamo de S/.2,000.00 nuevos soles, que pagará en 4 meses, comprará 3 paquetes de material tipo cáñamo, 2 paquetes de material tipo rafia entre otros. Este negocio esta generando más ganancia, pero ella aún necesita más capital para cubrir la demanda en los mercados de Ilave y Juliaca por mayor y menor. Mery esta contenta, por que en los últimos años esta creciendo su negocio e ingresos económicos y su mayor sueño es adquirir una movilidad para traslado de mercadería y tener hijos profesionales.

loans.use: Purchase of supplies/raw materials.

loans.name: Martina

texts.es:
Martina is 60 years old, was not able to go to school, speaks the Aymará language and understands Spanish. She is married and has five children, four of whom live on their own and one who still resides with her. She lives in the Ilave district in the El Collao province. Martina dedicates herself to the purchase and sale of sheep, pigs and cows which she buys and then sells at the market in Pilcuyo on Thursdays and at the Ilave market on Sundays. Her husband makes the purchases in the morning, and she sells them within a few hours. She belongs to the communal bank “22nd of September”, where she took an initial loan of 300 soles with which she purchased four sheep and two pigs. With this loan of 3,000 soles, to be repaid in four months, she will buy two bulls to raise and then sell. She tells us that being a member of the communal bank has taught her to run a business, has increased her income and she is very thankful for having been extended credit and is punctual about her payments. Her dream is to buy a car and to have a better quality of life with her husband.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Martina tiene 60 años, no pudo estudiar, habla el idioma aymará y entiende castellano, es casada y tiene cinco hijos de los cuales cuatro ya son independientes y uno de sus hijos esta a su lado, ella vive en la Parcialidad de M. del Centro Poblado de Camicachi, Distrito de Ilave, Provincia de El Collao. Martina se dedica a compra y ventas de ovejas, chanchos y vacas que los adquiere y vende en las ferias de los jueves en Pilcuyo y en Ilave los domingos. Su esposo los compra, por la mañana y ella los vende después de un par de horas. Pertenece al Banco Comunal “22 de Setiembre” donde tuvo un crédito inicial de S/.300.00 nuevos soles con lo que pudo comprar cuatro ovejas y dos chanchos; Con este crédito de s/. 3000.00 nuevos soles, el cual será pagado en cuatro meses, comprarà dos toros para engorde que posteriormente serán vendidos. Nos cuenta siendo socia del Banco Comunal aprendió a trabajar, incremento su ingreso económico y esta muy agradecida por el crédito que se le dio y es muy puntual en sus pagos. El sueño que ella tiene es comprar un carro, para que pueda recoger la chacra y vivir mejor con su esposo.

loans.use: Purchase of livestock (bulls).

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Manuela Ramos / CrediMUJER - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
Martha belongs to the “August 1st” community bank, in the district of Zepita, province of Chucuito – Juli and region of Puno. She is 37 years old, lives with a partner, has a daughter and a son that depend on her, she went to university. Her initial loan was of $115 USD (S/.300), this money was invested in starting a store of school supplies, the store is located in the panamericana avenue, across from the Andres Avelino Caceres de Zepita School.

She currently has a bookstore that grew from being a snack shop thanks to the community bank loans. With the new loan of $200 USD (S/.500) that will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy 3 packages of 4A paper for photocopies, 6 hundred cardboards, a box of notebooks, etc.

Martha started this business 8 years ago when her father passed away, because she didn’t know what to work on back then, furthermore, she had just returned from Cochabamba, La Paz, Bolivia; if she had wanted to work in her profession, her degree would not have been valid in Peru. Now she is very happy because she has her own business and with the loans she has been able to add merchandise, which is increasing her income.

Her biggest dream is to have a fully equipped bookstore, a printing-house and see her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Sofia Burt, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Martha pertenece al Banco Comunal Primero de Agosto, del distrito de Zepita, provincia de Chucuito - Juli y Región de Puno. Tiene 37 años de edad, conviviente, madre de una hija y un hijo que aun depende de ella, su estudio alcanzado es superior universitaria. Su crédito inicial fue de S/.300.00 nuevos soles, este dinero invirtió para implementar su tienda escolar que está ubicada en avenida panamericana s/n al frente al colegio Andrés Avelino Cáceres de Zepita.

Actualmente tiene una tienda tipo librería, ya que antes era una pequeña tienda de golosina, esto fue creciendo gracias a los préstamos que recibió del Banco Comunal. Con este préstamo de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprarà 3 paquetes de papel 4A para fotocopias, 6 cientos de pápelo grafos, una caja de cuadernos, etc.

Martha emprendió este negocio hace 8 años cuando falleció su padre, ya que ella no sabia en que trabajar en ese entonces, además recién había regresado de Cochabamba La Paz Bolivia, si ella quería trabajar como profesional no valía su título en el Perú. Ella ahora se encuentra muy feliz por que ya tiene su negocio y además con los créditos incrementó más mercadería, por ello esta mejorando sus ingresos económicos.

Su sueño mayor es tener una librería equipada, poner imprenta y sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: Purchase a variety of school supplies for store.

loans.name: María Mercedes

texts.es:
Maria Mercedes belongs to the Andres Santa Cruz de Chuachua community bank, district of Zepita, province of Chucuito – Juli and region of Puno. She is 35 years old, and has a son and a daughter that depend on her. She finished grade 5. Maria decided to invest the first loan of $115 USD (S/.300) in the purchase of five lambs, but this business generated little profit.

Currently, she has a general store that she was able to implement thanks to the loans provided by the community bank. With the next loan of $600 USD (S/.1,700) which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy a small bull and will invest the rest in a sack of rice, a sack of sugar and a bag of pasta; with the purpose to obtain more income.

Maria Mercedes works in the store in the mornings and afternoons. During the day she also takes care of her cattle and small farm. She is very happy because she is making it on her own but with the support of her oldest daughter and husband; he can’t work because he has been sick for the past 7 months.

Her dream is to have a fully supplied store in a central town and see her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Sofia Burt, Kiva volunteer.

María Mercedes pertenece al Banco Comunal Andrés Santa Cruz de Chuachua, del distrito de Zepita, provincia de Chucuito - Juli y Región de Puno. Tiene 35 años de edad, madre de una hija y un hijo que aun depende de ella, su estudio alcanzado es quinto de primaria. María con el inicialmente accedió a un préstamo de S/.300.00 nuevos soles, decidió invertir en la compra de cinco ovejas criollas para el engorde y este negocio genero poca ganancia.

Actualmente cuenta con una tienda de abarrotes, este pudo implementar gracias a los créditos que recibió del Banco Comunal. Por eso con este préstamo siguiente de S/. 1,700.00 nuevos soles, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará un toro pequeño y las demás invertirá en compra de un saco de Arroz, un saco de azúcar, una bolsa de fideos, para tener más ingresos económicos.

María Mercedes se dedica a vender en su tienda por las mañanas y tardes, y de día cuida sus ganados y hace su chacra, ella se siente muy contenta porque sola esta sobresaliendo adelante con el apoyo de su hija mayor, y su esposo ya que el no puede trabajar porque está mal de salud hace 7 meses.

Su sueño es equipar su tienda de abarrotes en el Centro Poblado y sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for general store and a bull.

loans.name: María Elvira

texts.es:
Maria Elvira is 56 years old, she widowed 20 years ago, has two sons and one daughter, she finished grade nine. She lives in #151 Jiron San Martin, district of Zepita, province of Chucuito – Juli and region of Puno.

She is a member of the “August 1st” community bank in the district of Zepita. With the first $115 USD (S/.300) loan, she bought 1 sack of rice, 1 sack of sugar and a bag of pasta for the general store she has had for many years.

With this loan of $550 USD (S/.1,500) which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy 2 sacks of rice, 2 sacks of sugar, 3 sacks of flour, 1 sack of broken rice, 2 bags of pasta and basic need items to prepare food in her restaurant, located next to the general store.

Maria Elvira states that since she belongs to the community bank, she has increased the merchandise and is slowly stocking the store, which makes her really happy.

Her vision is to fully equip the store, build a house in her lot and see her children find a job after raising them with a lot of effort.

Translated from Spanish by Sofia Burt, Kiva volunteer.

Doña María Elvira tiene 56 años de edad, es viuda hace veinte años, madre de dos hijos y una hija, ella estudió hasta tercero de secundaria, vive en jirón san Martín Nº 151 en el distrito de Zepita, provincia de Chucuito - Juli y Región de Puno.

Es socia del Banco Comunal Primero de Agosto del distrito de Zepita, con el primer préstamo de S/.300.00 nuevos soles compró 1 saco de arroz, 1 saco de azúcar, 1 bolsa de fideos, para su tienda de abarrotes que tiene hace muchos años.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,500.00 nuevos soles, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprarà 2 sacos de arroz, 2 sacos de azúcar, 3 sacos de harina, 1 saco de arroz granillo, 2 bolsas de fideos y artículos de la primera necesidad para la preparación de la comida en su restaurante que funciona al lado de su tienda de abarrotes.

María Elvira, indica que desde que entro al Banco Comunal pudo incrementar su mercadería y está equipando poco a poco tienda de abarrotes, por todo ello ella está muy contenta.

Su visión futura es equipar más la tienda y construir su casa al interior de su terreno y que sus hijos encuentren trabajo a los que educó con mucho esfuerzo.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: María Elena

texts.es:
Maria Elena belongs to the “September 22nd” community bank, in Maquera, Camicachi, district of Ilave, province of El Collao and region of Puno. Guillermina Ortega Chura encouraged her to become a member of the bank.

Once a member, and with the first loan she purchased 3 lambs to raise, and with the next loan she bought beef cattle to raise, which resulted more profitable.

With the $200 USD (S/.500) loan, to be repaid in 4 months, she will purchase a bull to raise and will sell it in the weekly fair of the Ilave district. In addition to raising livestock, she started designing and making embroidered cloths, pillows, handbags, etc. With this, she ensures her interest is covered even if she is not able to sell any livestock.

She is very happy for learning to work with a loan, increasing her income and living at home with her husband, who works in the livestock activity with her.

Maria Elena is 45 years old, she didn’t finish elementary school, she has 2 children, she is married and her wish is to purchase a feed grinder for her livestock, be a better artist and see her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Sofia Burt, Kiva volunteer.

La señora María Elena, es socia del Banco Comunal 22 de Setiembre de la parcialidad de Maquera del Centro Poblado de Camicachi del distrito de Ilave, Provincia El Collao y Región de Puno. Para que sea parte del Banquito le animó la señora Guillermina Ortega Chura de la misma Parcialidad.

Ella siendo parte del Banco Comunal, con el primer préstamo que adquirió compró 3 ovejas mejoradas para engordar, y con el siguiente préstamo compró ganado vacuno para el engorde, ya que ello le resultó más rentable.

Por ello con este préstamo de S/ 500.00 nuevos soles, el cual será pagado en cuatro meses, comprará nuevamente un torete para el engorde y la venta lo realizará en la feria semanal del distrito de Ilave.

Además ella ha emprendido a parte del engorde de ganado vacuno, la confección de bordados de bayeta, cojines, bolsas, etc., con el cual garantiza pagar los intereses cuando no vende su ganado.

Ella está muy contenta, ya que aprendió a trabajar con el préstamo y incrementó sus ingresos para vivir en su hogar y además con el esposo comparten la actividad de engorde.

María Elena tiene 45 años de edad, su nivel educativo es primaria incompleta, madre de dos hijos, casada y su deseo de futuro es adquirir una maquina Picadura de Alimentos para el engorde de ganado, Ser una mejor artesana y sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: Purchase a bull

loans.name: María

texts.es:
Maria is 56 years old, she wasn’t able to finish elementary school, she is married and has 6 children.

She belongs to the Zepita community bank, she decided to became a member of the bank due to the need of capital to prepare “chicharron” (fried pork) and sell at the market of Zepita on Thursdays. She also joined the bank to make friends and share her problems with them; she doesn’t have family living close to the area. Her first loan of $115 USD (S/.300) was used to purchase 50 pounds of corn, 75 pounds of freeze-dried potato and 100 pounds of potatoes.

She increased her capital with the previous loans, now she raises the pork she uses to prepare chicharron. With the $200 USD (S/.500) loan, to be repaid in 4 months, she will buy 3 pigs that she will raise.

Maria indicates that her business is getting better and by being with the bank she learns to be responsible and punctual. Her future dream is to expand her business and support her children to have their own business.

Translated from Spanish by Sofia Burt, Kiva volunteer.

María tiene 56 años de edad, su nivel educativo es primaria incompleta, es casada y madre de seis hijos.

Ella pertenece al Banco Comunal Zepita, decidió ser socia del Banco Comunal por falta de capital, para preparar chicharrón de chancho en el campo ferial de Zepita los días jueves y además quería tener amigas para compartir sus problemas, ya que ella no tiene familiares en la zona. De esa manera su crédito inicial fue de S/.300.00 nuevos soles, con ello compró 2 arrobas de maíz, 3 arrobas de chuño, 1 quintal de papa.

Con todo sus préstamos anteriores aumento su capital, ya que ahora realiza el engorde de chanchos para degollar y preparar chicharrón de chancho, por ello con el crédito de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, el cual pagará en 4 meses, invertirá en comprar 3 chanchos que engordará.

María, manifiesta que esta mejorando su negocio y además estando en el Banco aprende ser responsable y puntual, su sueño a futuro es ampliar su negocio y apoyar a sus hijos hasta que tenga sus negocios propios.

loans.use: Purchase 3 hogs

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita, 56, has a first-graD. education. She is married and has 3 children, with only one of them still at home. Their home is in Centro Poblado D. Chuachua in the Zepita district, Chucuito Province.

She belongs to the Andrés Santa Cruz D. Chuachua Communal Bank. She first joined the bank to increase her capital and support her business. She started by borrowing 300 soles to purchase 3 sheep to raise. Her capital increased with the profits from the sale of these sheep.

Margarita is now requesting 1000 soles to invest in the purchase of 5 blackface sheep, which she will sell at the Zepita and Huapaca fairs. She will pay back the loan in 4 installments.

Margarita tells us that her net weekly profit is 50 soles. This makes makes her happy and gives her motivation to continue working hard on her business.

Her dream is to buy land to keep a larger number of sheep, and that her youngest son has a college education.

translated by Maria B., Kiva volunteer

Margarita tiene 56 años D. edad, estudió hasta primero D. primaria, es casada, madre D. tres hijos 02 ya son independientes, viven en el Centro Poblado D. Chuachua, del distrito D. Zepita, Provincia D. Chucuito – Juli y Región D. Puno. Ella pertenece al Banco Comunal Andrés Santa Cruz D. Chuachua, decidió pertenecer a este Banco Comunal por falta D. capital, para mantener su negocio D. compra y venta D. ganado ovino; por ello con el primer préstamo D. S/.300.00 nuevos soles compró 03 ovejas mejorados, vendiendo estos animales tuvo ganancias y incremento su capital. Con el préstamo D. S/. 1,000.00 nuevos soles, el cual pagará en 4 meses, seguirá invirtiendo en la compra D. 3 ovejas cara negras, las que venderá en días D. la feria del distrito D. Zepita y feria D. Huapaca del distrito D. Pomata. Margarita, manifiesta que cada semana tiene una ganancia líquida D. S/. 50.00 nuevos soles, por eso se encuentra muy feliz y seguirá trabajando con su negocio. Su sueño es comprar terreno para realizar más engorD. D. ganados y su último hijo sea profesional.

loans.use: Purchase of sheep

loans.name: Sadiq

texts.en:
Sadiq U. is young and married. This resident of the Ningarhar has three children; they are small and don’t go to school yet. Sadiq and his family have returned from two decades of living as refugees in neighboring Pakistan. The young man studied in Pakistan in a private school and his father used to work in a general store.

Upon repatriation the family has faced various financial problems, pushing the young man to leave off the pursuit of his education and help his father to support their family. Unfortunately, his father has been getting weaker day by day, as he has had some serious illnesses. Sadiq U. had to take the responsibility for supporting his family and has started a small business in his village.

With a little family fund, Sadiq purchased some basic goods and put them in his shop. Due to his friendly behavior, he became a popular shopkeeper in the village, attracting more customers day by day. Besides the store, he grows some vegetables on his land to sell them in his own shop. He enrolled his small brother in a public school and some other private courses. Now Sadiq is very happy with his life, and he is attempting to start his remaining education once again. For that purpose, he first needs to expand his business to increase his income from about US$8 a day to US$ 16 per day. With this goal in mind, he is requesting a loan in the amount of 50,000 Afghanis (US$ 1100).

Sadiq U. hopes to make a brighter future for himself and his brother. And he says that everything is possible if we have a strong will.

loans.use: To buy seeds, etc. for his land

loans.name: Marciana

texts.es:
Marciana, 42, has a fifth-grade education. She has 6 children, with five of them still at home. Their home is in the Porteno neighborhood in the Zepita district, Chucuito Province.

Marciana has been raising sheep to sell for the last seven years. She belongs to the Zepita District Communal Bank "Primero de Agosto". As member of the communal bank, she was able to increase her capital by borrowing 300 soles to purchase 5 sheep to raise. Her income improved and this motivated her to take advantage of increasing loans from the communal bank.

Marciana is now requesting 1000 soles to invest in the purchase of 4 blackface sheep. With these sheep she will spend less in fodder and she will make a higher profit. She will pay back the loan in 4 installments.

Marciana is happy because her income is increasing and she is saving money for her children's support and education.

Her dream is to open a small grocery store across from the Andrés Avelino Cáceres school in Zepita, and that her children have a college education.

Translated from Spanish by Maria B., Kiva volunteer

La señora Marciana tiene 42 años de edad, estudió hasta quinto de secundaria, es casada, madre de seis hijos, cinco dependen de ella, su domicilio queda en el barrio Porteño, del distrito de Zepita, Provincia de Chucuito – Juli y Región de Puno. La actividad que realiza es engorde de ovejas para la venta, que viene desarrollando hace siete años. Ella es parte de Banco Comunal Primero de Agosto del distrito de Zepita, con el fin de incrementar más su capital y su crédito inicial que recibió es de S/. 300.00, este dinero invirtió en la compara de 5 ovinos para el engorde y cuando obtuvo un poco más de ingreso económico, la cual siguió motivando para seguir escalando con los créditos del banquito. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,000.00 nuevos soles, comprará 4 ovejas cara negras, ya que con ello tiene mayor ganancia y además para el engorde gastará menos forraje. Este su crédito serà cancelado en 4 cuotas. Marciana, esta contenta, por que está incrementando su capital y esta asegurando dinero para los gastos de estudios de sus hijos y alimentación. Su sueño mayor es poner una tienda de abarrotes al frente del colegio de Andrés Avelino Cáceres de Zepita y algún día sean profesionales sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase of sheep

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Mrs. Kong S., 42, sells groceries out of her house in Roteang Village, Siem Reap Province. She earns around $3 per day. Her husband, Mr. Hiem Lay, is a fisherman who earns around $4 per day. He has been fishing since 1998. They have four children, all of whom are young and in school. With a view to growing her business and based on increasing customer demand , S. is requesting a loan of US$ 750 to purchase more groceries to sell. In order to increase the family’s income, she will use the remainder of the loan to purchase small fish to breed for sale. The loan will allow her to improve her family's living conditions.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Marhabo

texts.en:
Marhabo A. is 53 years old, married and the loving mother of four children. She makes a living selling items in the local market. She started out 20 years ago with only a few products, but over the years her business has grown larger and more stable. Today, Marhabo sells fruits such as watermelons, melon and other produce in season. Her sons help with the business. In the market, Marhabo is well-known for being friendly and having low prices. This allows her business to generate considerable income for her family.

This is the time of year when demand for fruit is greatest. That's why Marhabo would like to expand her store by restocking it with new, fresh items to sell. To make this possible, she has applied for a loan of $950 which she will repay in nine months. She hopes this loan will raise her income so she can pay for her children’s university fees. With your help, this will be possible. Marhabo would like to thank everyone who supports her and her family

loans.use: To buy more fruit to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Karima

texts.en:
Karima E. is 54 years old, married and has four adult children. She is well known as an energetic woman, and started her business 21 years ago when good jobs were not available and she wanted to make sure that her family had enough money. Karima works in the local market, selling fruits such as watermelons and melons. Her stand is popular because it has attractive prices. Her success allows Karima to generate considerable income for her family.

Karima is planning to buy more fresh fruit to fulfill the needs of a growing number of customers. To make this possible, she has applied for a loan of $950 for nine months. Karina has a positive credit history with IMON, and promises to repay this loan as promptly as she has all previous ones. The well-being of her family depends on getting this loan, and Karima wants to thank you for contributing to the growth of her business and the well-being of her children.

loans.use: To buy more fruit to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Uguloy

texts.en:
Uguloy K. is 51 years old, married and the loving mother of three children. For the last seven years, she has made a living selling cottonseed oil in the local market. Her son helps Uguloy with this business. In traditional Tajik cuisine, most meals are fried or cooked using cottonseed oil, especially the national dish known as Oshi palov, which needs a lot of cottonseed oil to be especially delicious. So Uguloy's goods are high demand among local people.

Uguloy is working hard to increase the size of her business. To make this possible, she has applied for a loan of $1,000 which she will repay in four months. She will use the loan to buy additional cottonseed oil to sell to her customers. Uguloy is counting on your help and wishes to thank you for your support.

loans.use: To buy cottonseed oil to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Mayram

texts.en:
Mayram S. is 45 years old, married and has three adorable children. Her oldest son is studying at university while the others attend local schools. Mayram makes a living selling perfum and cosmetics in a store which she rents. She has been in this business for six years, and her dream is to expand her business, open her own store and establish contacts with steady suppliers of well-known products.

Mayram and her husband work hard to make sure they have sufficient funds to educate their children so they can succeed in life. To help make this dream possible, Mayram has applied for a loan of $1,000 to buy new perfumes and cosmetics, including hair color, nail polish, lipstick and other items. She would like to thank everybody who supports her and promises to pay the loan in four months and make payments in a timely manner.

loans.use: To purchase a wider range of goods to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Florian's Wema Group

texts.en:
Florian is a single woman. She began selling beans in 2004. Each day, she works from 8:00 am to 12:00 pm at her business, and doing so enables her to generate a monthly profit of approximately $250 from her sales.

Florian is hereby requesting a loan to buy more beans for her business. Notably, she will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses relating to tailoring and milk sales.

loans.use: To expand and improve their respective businesses by purchasing additional goods (e.g., beans, milk, and tailoring materials) in order to increase their stock.

loans.name: Kosar's Group

texts.en:
Kosar baji is the wife of N. A. and lives in the city of Borewala, Pakistan, where she has lived for the last 17 years. She is the mother of six children: four sons and two daughters. She is a housewife and enjoys taking care of her children. Her husband has a business making plastic bottles. Her eldest son helps her husband with the work. The other children are enrolled in a local school in a neighboring area. She is applying for a loan to buy more material (plastic) for her husband’s business.

Kosar baji is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Bushra baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk business. Tasneem baji wants a loan to buy masonry tools (beams, hammer, etc) for her husband. Salamat baji wants a loan to buy more fruit for her fruit business. Amna baji wants a loan to buy more materials for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in their own business. The members mutually guarantee each other's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Ieng

texts.en:
Mrs. Ieng S., 37, is a fish seller as well as selling vegetables. She buys fish from fishermen and sells them in the market for profit. She earns around $4 per day. Her husband, Mr. Tav Pov, 37, is a fisherman and earns around $5 per day. They have three children and all of them are young and in school. They live in Roteang Village, Siem Reap Province.

Because of her fish and vegetable-selling business, Mrs. S. is requesting a loan of US$ 1,000 to purchase more fish and vegetables to sell. With the remainder of the loan, she will fix her husband's fishing boat. The loan will allow her to increase the family’s income and improve living conditions. The picture is Mrs. S. and her husband.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase more fish and vegetables to sell and fix her husband's boat

loans.name: Mukhtaran's Group

texts.en:
Mukhtaran baji is the wife of A. R.. She has lived in the city of Borewala, Pakistan, for the last 5 years. She is the mother of three sons. Her youngest son has an electronic shop. Her husband sells wheat and has been in this profession for the last 6 years. Mukhtaran baji is a housewife and prefers to do domestic chores at home in the two bedroom brick house that she owns. She is applying for a loan to buy more wheat for her husband to resell.

Mukhtaran baji is joined in her loan group by a few other members. Bashiran baji wants a loan to repair an auto-rickshaw (local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Parveen baji wants a loan to buy iron to resell. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy vegetables to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in their own business. The members mutually guarantee each other's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Mrs. Chea V. and her husband are fisher who living in Roteang Village, Siem Reap Province. Their income is of $5 per day and care for seven children. Two of their children help him for fishing to generate family’s income. Their main income is fishing and they need to sustain and expanding her business. Because of growing her fishing business, they need a loan of $750 to purchase fishing tools and remainder of loan she will use to fix their boat. Their loan allows them increase income and improving living condition.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase fishing tools and remainder of loan she will use to fix their boat

loans.name: Mir Abdul Woli

texts.en:
M. Abdul Woli is married. He has the responsibility for his family. He has a gas shop. He is new in his business. Woli was in Pakistan with members of his family. When he came back, he opened up a shop selling gas in Kabul. He is working hard but still he is unable to enlarge his shop.

So Woli has requested an individual loan to complete his stock and expand his business to make good monthly income for his family to help them do better in Kabul.

He is very happy with this process of small loans in Afghanistan. He would like to thank both AFSG and Kiva that help people who are hard workers.

loans.use: To expand his business and complete his stock

loans.name: Anonymous
