loans.use: To invest in new bedspread styles for her small business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of beauty soap, shampoo and also cakes and sweets for a small business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her small busines of selling jewelry and shoes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase a variety of goods to operate her small hair salon.

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen baji is the wife of M. A.. She has lived in the city of Borewala, Pakistan, for the last 4 years. She is the mother of four children: two sons and two daughters. All of her children are in kindergarten (in Pakistan the age at which children start school varies). Her husband is a university graduate who teaches in a school and also has a livestock business. Nasreen baji does domestic chores and sells milk. She is applying for a loan to buy another buffalo for her husband to resell.

Nasreen baji is joined in her loan group by a few other members. Sakina baji wants a loan to buy more materials for her grocery shop. Ruqaiya baji wants a loan to buy medicine to resell. Kaneez baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart. Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in their own business. The members mutually guarantee each other's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 38-year-old, married woman with 3 children (ages 16, 12, and 8). In addition, she cares for another individual, who is 20 years old. She owns a small shop where she sells soft drinks. Each day, she works from 6:45 am to 6:00 pm at her business, and as a result she earns a monthly profit of approximately $250 from her sales.

In the past, Mary received and successfully repaid a loan from Akiba bank in order to open her shop. Currently, Mary is seeking another loan to buy more soda for her business in order to increase her inventory and to thereby generate greater revenue.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional crates of soda to thereby increase her inventory and profits

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Mrs. Chea V. and her husband are fisherpeople who live in Roteang Village, Siem Reap Province. Their combined income is about $5 per day and they care for seven children. Two of their children help with the fishing to generate the family’s income. Their main source of income is fishing and so Mrs. Chea V. needs to sustain and expand their business. Because of growing their fishing business, Mrs. V. needs a loan of US$ 750 to purchase fishing implements and to fix their fishing boat. The loan will allow her to increase the family's income and improve living conditions.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase fishing implements and fix their boat

loans.name: Asha's Amken Group

texts.en:
Asha is a 22-year-old, married woman with 2 children (ages 4 and 5). She began selling charcoal and fruits in 2002, and she proudly states that she works every day from 9:00 am to 8:00 pm at her business. Accordingly, she is able to generate a monthly profit of approximately $110 from her sales.

Asha now seeks a loan to buy more charcoal for her business. Importantly, she will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses relating to vegetable (e.g., beans and maize) sales, fruit sales, and clothing sales.

loans.use: To expand and improve their respective businesses by purchasing additional goods (e.g., charcoal, vegetables, fruit, and clothes) to thereby increase their inventory.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase clothing to add to her stock.

loans.name: Tahira's Group

texts.en:
Tahira baji is the wife of I. A.. She lives in the city of Borewala, Pakistan, where she has resided for the last 20 years. She is the mother of four children: two sons and two daughters. Tahira baji sews clothes for her neighbors and takes care of her children. Her husband sells clothes in different cities and has been in this profession for the last 10 years. She is applying for a loan to buy more clothes to resell and expand the business.

Tahira baji is joined in her loan group by a few other members. Tahmina baji wants a loan to buy fruit for her fruit business. Jamila baji and Hazoran baji each want a loan to buy a buffalo for their milk businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in their own business. The members mutually guarantee each other's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Abdul Ghabar

texts.en:
A. Ghabar lives with his own family. He is married. He works in business that sells cars. He has been involved in this business for more than 5 years. He doesn't have enough money to further his business; he needs money. When he saw the advertisement about AFSG on Tolo TV, the most popular television station in Afghanistan, he thought that it is very useful for everyone.

Now he has requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani (US$ 1100) with a term of 12 months to complete his stock and continue his business with more success and become more powerful in his business. He is certain that he can repay the money with no problem.

He is a happy man. He wishes to open his own car sales business in the next few years and he hopes to be a good business dealer in the future. He is happy with this loan.

loans.use: To complete his stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To start of a small business selling clothing in her neighborhood.

loans.name: Sum

texts.en:
Mrs. Sum L., 61, raises fish to sell. She has been raising fish since 1993 and she earns around $5 per day. Her husband, Mr. Chan Sem, 62, is a fisherman in the Tonle Sap Lake. The two of them have six children, two of whom are married. The other four are young. They live in Tachraneang Village, Siem Reap Province. The main income of the family is fish-raising and L. needs to sustain and expand her business. In order to grow her business, she is now requesting a loan of US$ 1,000 to purchase more small fish to raise and to purchase fish food. The loan will allow her to expand the fish-raising business and increase the family’s income.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase more small fish to raise and to purchase fish food

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Salma is a 29-year-old, married woman. She started her business of selling clothes in 2006. Ever since, she has worked on a daily basis from 8:00 am to 6:00 pm at her business. Consequently, she earns a monthly profit of approximately $50 from her sales.

Salma now requests a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional clothes to sell to her customers.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Theresia

texts.en:
Theresia is a widow with 4 children (ages 23, 20, 18 and 10). She started her food-selling business in 2007. Each day, she works from 7:00 am to 6:00 pm at her business. As a result, she is able to generate a monthly profit of approximately $250 from her sales.

Theresia is now seeking a loan to buy more food items such as rice and millet for her business.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional food items (e.g., rice and millet) to sell to her customers.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Sakina's Group

texts.en:
Sakina baji is the wife of N. A. and lives in the city of Borewala, Pakistan. She has lived in the city for the last 21 years. She is the mother of six sons. Her eldest son has a tea business. The next eldest works in an iron shop. Her younger sons are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Her husband is a fruit seller by profession. Sakina baji is a housewife and prefers to do domestic chores. She is applying for a loan to buy more fruit to expand the business.

Sakina baji is joined in her loan group by a few other members. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy fruit to resell. Hamida baji wants a loan to buy animal food. Allah Rakhi baji wants a loan to buy more material for her grocery shop. Rukhsana baji wants a loan to repair her vehicle.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in their own business. The members mutually guarantee each other's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Irshad's Group

texts.en:
Irshad baji is the wife of M. M.. She lives in the city of Borewala, Pakistan, where she owns a two room brick house that she has lived in for the last 30 years. She is the mother of three sons. Her two eldest sons make decorative embroidered dresses. The youngest son works in a workshop. Her husband is a milk seller and has been in this profession for the last 20 years. Irshad baji is a housewife who takes care of her children and does domestic chores. She is applying for a loan to buy more milk to expand the milk business.

Irshad baji is joined in her loan group by a few other members. Zubaida baji wants a loan to buy material for her decorative embroidery business. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in their own business. The members mutually guarantee each other's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Aisha's Sakina Group

texts.en:
Aisha is 36-year-old, single woman with 2 children (ages 9 and 6). She began her career in tailoring in 1992. Each day, she works from 8:00 am to 12:00 pm at her business, and she generally earns a monthly profit of approximately $250 from her sales.

Aisha now seeks a loan to buy more tailoring items for her business. Notably, she will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses relating to clothing sales and vegetable sales.

loans.use: To expand and improve their respective businesses by purchasing additional materials (e.g., more tailoring items, clothing, and vegetables).

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a married woman with 2 children (the first is 4 years old and the second is a 1-year-old). She owns and operates a small shop, which she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 8:00 am to 6:00 pm at her business, and she typically earns a monthly profit of approximately $140 from her sales.

Judith now requests a loan in order to buy more cement for her business.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional cement.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Ruach

texts.en:
Ruach is a 45-year-old married woman with 2 children, who are 12 and 16 years old, respectively. In addition, she takes care of 2 other people, who are 48 and 68 years old, respectively. She began her tailoring career in 1998. On a daily basis, she works from 9:30 am to 6:00 pm at her business. As a result, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $40 from her sales.

Ruach now seeks a loan to buy more tailoring items and clothes for her business.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional tailoring items and clothes.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Anna's Vumilia Group

texts.en:
Anna is a 27-year-old married woman with 2 children who are 8 and 11 years old, respectively. She began selling bananas in 2001 and to this day she works everyday from 7am to 8pm at her business. As a result, she generates a monthly profit of approximately $40 from her banana sales.

Anna now seeks a loan to buy more bananas for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who has vegetable-selling business.

loans.use: To expand and improve their respective businesses by purchasing additional fruits and vegetables

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Hakimali

texts.ru:
Hakimali T. lives in Yavan city. He is married and supports his family by producing and selling chewing tobacco. He produces his tobacco from raw materials which he hopes to buy with a loan. This would help him develop his business, as it is his only source of income for his family. In addition, his product is in great demand. He plans to pay back the loan in 12 months. With this loan, he could increase the volume of his production and attract new customers.

Тиллоев Хакимали живет в городе Яван. Женат . Обеспечивает семью путем производство и продажи жевательного табака. Производит табак из сырья , для приобретения которых он планирует получить кредит. Это поможет ему развивать бизнес , так как он является единственным источником дохода его семьи. Кроме того , данного вида продукция пользуется большим спросом у населения. Погасить кредит он сможет в течении 12 месяцев.Занимается этим видом бизнеса уже 10 лет. Получив кредит он сможет увеличить объем производства и привлечь новых клиентов.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials

loans.name: I Made

texts.id:
I Made S. has a motorcycle repair shop in Denpasar. His shop provides services such as motorcycle maintenance works, oil changes, replacing the tires etc. His average earning is IDR 850 thousand per week (approximately of USD 105/ week).

He sets aside a part of his proceed for expansion of his shop. He uses the rest of the proceed for his family and to pay school fees for his kid who is in Junior High School. The school fees is IDR 100 thousand/ month (around USD 12/ month).

He hopes to get the loan money to enable him to expand his motorcycle repair shop.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva volunteer.

Usaha yang dijalani I Made S. adalah membuka bengkel sepeda motor. Bengkelnya melayani servis kendaraan bermotor seperti ganti oli, ganti ban dan juga menjual bensin eceran. Rata-rata penghasilan per minggunya mencapai 850.000. Dengan harus membiayai sekolah anaknya yang saat ini duduk dibangku SMP sebesar 100.000 perbulan, dia harus bisa menabung dari usahanya. Selain itu dia juga harus menyisihkan untuk biaya hidup sehari-hari. Made sangat berharap dia diberi pinjaman utnuk mengembangkan usaha bengkelnya. Saat ini, bersama istrinya, Kadek Dahlia mereka tinggal dirumah sendiri di Denpasar.

loans.use: To add working capital (Menambah Modal Usaha)

loans.name: Ilhom

texts.ru:
Ilhom O. is a resident of Yavan city. He is 29 years old, married, and has one child. He graduated from the institute and works in a middle school. In addition, he also has a business repairing computers. To develop his business, he would like to purchase a computer, which would help him expedite his services as well as create new jobs. To do so, he would take out a loan, which he plans to pay back the loan within six months.

Translated from Russian by Josh Machleder, Kiva Volunteer.

Олимов Ильхом житель города Яван. Возраст 29 лет. Женат , имеет одного ребенка. Закончил институт. Работает в средней школе. Кроме того занимается ремонтом компьютеров. Для развития бизнеса хочет приобрести компьютер. Это поможет ему увеличить скорость обслуживания , а так же создать новые рабочие места. Погасить кредит планирует в течении 6 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of a computer

loans.name: A.

texts.id:
S., 36 year old, live together with his wife Sulastri and their daughters, Dewi and Diana at Patih Jelantik Street. They rent a room to live.

S. has been in the business of collecting garbage/ used goods for quite a while. He doesn't have any skill to do other jobs except for collecting goods.

He walks around Kuta area everyday and collects goods/ garbage. He usually collects goods made of plastic material, iron, used newspaper etc. Once a week he sells these collected stuffs to a collector depot. He can earn up to IDR 250 thousand per week (approximately of USD 31/ week).

He hopes he can get loan money to add his capital to buy more used goods so he can increase his earning.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva volunteer.

Sudah lama S. menjalani usaha sebagai pemulung. Diusianya yang ke-36 saat ini, dia tidak memiliki keahlian lain selain mencari barang bekas dan rongsokan. Sehari-harinya dia berkeliling di sekitar Kuta mencari barang bekas menggunakan gerobak miliknya. Barang yang sudah dikumpulkan, nantinya akan dijual seminggu sekali kepada penadah yang akan menjualnya lagi ke Jawa. Adapun yang dikumpulkan seperti plastik, besi bekas, karon dan kertas Koran. Setiap jenis barang bekas harganya berbeda-beda, tetapi yang paling mahal adalah besi. Tetapi karena dia kesulitan untuk mencari, dia berharap bisa diberi pinjaman untuk dijadikan modal membeli barang bekas lalu nanti dia menjualnya lagi. Diharapkan pengahasilannya yang sekarang 250.000 per minggu bisa meningkat. Saat ini, bersama istrinya Sulastri dan kedua anaknya Dewi dan Diana, mereka tinggal di Jl.Patih jelantik dengan menyewa sebuah kamar.

loans.use: To add working capital (Menambah Modal Usaha)

loans.name: Jamshed

texts.ru:
Jamshed A. lives in Yavan city. He recently got married, but he still lives with his parents. He is a teacher. He is the only breadwinner for his family. He provides services repairing computers, as well as burning discs and producing photographs. To improve his business, he'd like to take out a loan to purchase a color printer. He plans to pay back the loan within six months.

Translated from Russian by Josh Machleder, Kiva Volunteer.

Алиев Джамшед проживает в городе Яван. Недавно женился , но живет еще со своими родителями. По образованию – учитель. Единственным кормильцем семьи является он сам. Занимается услугами по ремонту компьютеров , а так же монтажем дисков и производством фото. Для того , чтобы усовершенствовать свою деятельность, он планирует получить кредит, чтобы купить цветной принтер. Погасить кредит планирует в течении 6 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of a printer

loans.name: Khalil

texts.en:
Khalil is married. He is educated. He has a photo shop in a good area in Kabul. He started this business 5 years ago, and it is still going very well, but a explosion that happened near his shop damaged it. So he decided to take out a loan to solve his problem.

Khalil has requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani (US$ 1075) with a term of 18 months to enlarge his shop and complete his stock to make his shop ready to become more popular in his business.

Khalil hopes that this loan process will be open in all the provinces of Afghanistan because people have been damaged in explosions and the past wars in Afghanistan. They need a loan to get back on their feet. Khalil wishes to open one or two new shops in the future. He would like to thank Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To enlarge his shop and complete his stock

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama owns and operates a retail business whereby she sells goods in Zanzibar. She is 45 years old, married, and has five children (ages 7, 17, 20, 23, and 25). On a daily basis, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business. Consequently, she can generate a monthly profit of approximately $180.

Salama is currently requesting a loan to buy more materials for her business.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional materials

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Sayaad Agha Ali

texts.en:
S. Agha is a shopkeeper. He has a retail shop. He works together with his brother. Now he wants to open another shop for himself to work alone and start a new business. He has a good number of customers in the area where his shop is located. He would love to grow his business more.

Agha has requested an individual loan in the amount of 50000 Afghani (US$ 1075) with a term of 18 months. He wants to complete his stock and buy more goods to retail like baskets, shampoo, chocolate. He is sure that he can further his business and repay the loan.

Agha is very happy with this loan. He hopes that he will become stronger in his business to become one of the great business dealers in the future.

loans.use: To complete his stock and buy more goods to retail

loans.name: Amadou

texts.fr:
Mr. Amadou W. is 41 years old and lives with his two children in his father’s house with his extended family in the Massablacoura quarter in the city of Bougouni (Bougoni Prefecture in Mali). Coming from a Diawanbe family (an ethnic group which is very skilled in business in West Africa), he never went to school because his father was always moving. After a period of apprenticeship in the techniques of business, he decided to start a business selling hooved animals, notably cattle. Mr. W. has been doing this for 15 years and is an expert in this field. In order to obtain additional financial help, he visited the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, where he just got his first individual loan. With this loan he plans to buy 15 head of cattle. He buys cattle in the villages surrounding Bougouni from cattle farmers, but he also goes to the main livestock markets in the region (Siékorolé, Niéna, Koumantou, Massigui, Bougouni, etc.). His client base is comprised mostly of butchers from the market in Bougouni, but also families who are holding ceremonies (marriages, baptisms, funerals). He hopes to make a profit of 60,000 FCFA (about $142) per cycle which will be used to pay the interest on the loan, reinvested in his business, and used to take care of his family’s expenses.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Monsieur Amadou W. est âgé de 41 ans et vit avec ses 2 enfants chez son père dans une grande famille élargie au quartier Massablacoura de la ville de Bougouni.(Préfecture de Bougouni République du Mali) Ussie d’une famille Diawanbé (ethnie très habile dans les négoces en Afrique de l’Ouest) il ne fréquenta pas l’école en raison des déplacements fréquents de son père. Après une phase d’apprentissage des techniques de commerce et de négoce, il décida de méner l’activité d’achat vente d’animaux sur pied notamment des bouefs. Monsieur W. exerce cette activité depuis 15 ans et a une maîtrise parfaite de activité. Afin d’obtenir une ressource financière complémentaire il démarcha l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso où il vient d’avoir son premier prêt indivuduel. Avec ce pret il compte acheter 15 bouefs. Il s’approvisionne en boeufs dans les villages environnants de la ville de Bougouni auprès des éléveurs mais fréquente aussi les principaux marchés à bétail de la localité (Siékorolé,Niéna,Koumantou,Massigui, Bougouni etc). Sa clientèle est composée essentiellement de bouchers exerçant au marché de Bougouni mais aussi de familles ayant des céremonies (Mariage, Bapteme ou déccès). Il espère réaliser un bénéfice par cycle de 60.000FCFA qui servira à payer les intêrets de prêt, renforcer le fonds de commerce et subvenir aux dépenses de la famille.

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Mshikamano Group

texts.en:
Saada owns and operates a business whereby she cooks and sells food in Zanzibar. She is 46 years old, married, and has seven children (ages 4, 6, 8, 14, 16, 20, and 22). On a daily basis, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business. In doing so, she is able to earn a monthly profit of approximately $100.

Saada is now seeking a loan to buy more materials for her business. In addition, she will share this loan with her subgroup member, who also has a business in the food production/sales industry.

loans.use: To improve and expand their respective businesses by purchasing additional materials

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Ousmane

texts.fr:
Mr. Ousmane H. is 37 years old and lives with his wife and six children in a monogamous family in the Hérémakono quarter, north of the city of Bougouni (in the Bougouni Prefecture of the Sikasso Region of Mali). Having not gone to school and in order to weave himself into the economic fabric of society, Mr. Ousamne H. has managed several income-generating activities with no success. He decided to apprentice as a woodworker next to one of his cousins, who is very respected and well known in woodworking in Côte d’Ivoire. With proven experience of 15 years, he now has an unmatched reputation in Bougouni as a woodworker. In order to obtain additional financial resources to satisfy the needs of his customers, which are becoming greater and more demanding, he decided to get involved with the Soro Yiriwaso loan program with which he is on his first individual loan. He plans to buy 20 planks of wood, two boxes of glue, 10 bags of nails, five sheets of plywood, and one electric plane. He often buys supplies in Bougouni, Bamako (capital of Mali), sometimes in Guinea, and in Côte d’Ivoire where wood is of a higher quality and at a good price. His workshop situated in the Hérémakono quarter receives many orders for furniture, office furnishings, etc. for government buildings and from masons who work for private individuals. Mr. H. hopes to make a monthly profit of 75,000 FCFA (about $178) which will be used to equip his workshop, take care of his family’s expenses, and pay the interest on the loan.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Monsieur Ousmane H. est âgé de 37 ans et vit avec sa femme et ses 6 enfants dans une famille monogame avec épouse enfants dans le quartier Hérémakono nord de la ville Bougouni (Préfecture de Bougouni Région de Sikasso République du Mali). N’ayant pas eu à fréquenter le système scolaire,et afin de s’inserrer dans le tissu économique Monsieur Ousmane H. ména plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus sans succès. Il décida d’aller se former en menuiserie auprès d’un de ses cousins très reputé et apprécié en menuiserie installé en République de le Côte D’ivoire. Avec une expérience averée de 15 ans, il jouit aujourd’hui d’une notoriété sans pareil à Bougouni dans la menuiserie. Pour obtenir des ressources financières complémentaires afin de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante et exigeante, il décida d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec lequel il est à son premier pret indivuduel. Il compte acheter 20 planches de bois, 2 boites de colle, 10 sachets de pointes, 5 feuilles de contre plaquets et 1 rabot électrique Il s’approvisionne habituellement à Bougouni, Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali), quelques fois en Guinée et en Côte d’ivoire où le bois est de meilleure qualité et à bon prix. Son atelier situé dans le quartier Heremakono reçoit beaucoup de commandes de meubles, des mobiliers de bureau etc de la part de maçons de particuliers et des strutures étatiques. Monsieur H. compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000FCFA.qui sera utilisé pour équiper l’atelier, assurer les dépenses de la famille et payer les intérêts du prêt.

loans.use: Purchase of wood, glue, and an electric plane

loans.name: Alimata

texts.fr:
Mrs. Alimata C. is 35 years old and lives in a polygamous family with her four children, her husband, her co-wife, and other relatives in Pélengana, one of the quarters of the city of Ségou in Mali. From a very young age, she got involved with income-generating activities of all sorts, but she finally decided to specialize in the selling of various items, focusing on food products, and has been doing so for the past three years. Her shop, “Une Munie Alimentation” is easily accessible, being situated near the main street of the city, linking Bamako to Burkina Faso. Mrs. C. has been involved with Soro Yiriwaso for three years. After having taken out four group loans with an association from her quarter, she is on her second individual loan, and all her previous loans were repaid with no problems. She stocks up on site in Ségou and sometimes in Bamako. With a client base comprised of people of all ages and both sexes, she sells her goods for cash and on credit, spread out on shelves. She plans to use this loan to buy 10 sacks of sugar, 1 refrigerator, 5 crates of beverages, 10 bags of carbonated beverages of the brand “American Cola”, and she hopes to make a profit of 200,000 CFA (about $475) with she will use to pay the interest on the loan as well as invest in her business. She hopes to open a larger store someday.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Madame Alimata C. est âgée de 35 ans, et vit dans une famille polygame avec ses 4 enfants, son mari sa coépouse et d’autres parents à Pélengana un des quartiers de la ville de Ségou République du Mali. Depuis sa tendre enfance elle commence les activités génératrices de revenus de toutes sortes, mais décide finalement de se spécialiser dans la vente d’articles divers avec un accent pour les produits alimentaires il y a de cela trois (3 ans). Sa boutique (une munie alimentation) est d’accès facile située près de l’artère principale de la ville, reliant Bamako à la République du Burkina Faso. Elle est en relation avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis 3 ans. Après 4 prêts solidaires avec une association de son quartier elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel et tous les précédents ont été remboursés sans difficulté. Elle s’approvisionne sur place à Ségou et quelques fois à Bamako. Avec une clientèle composée de tous âges et sexes, elle vend ses marchandises au comptant et à crédit sur des étagères. Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour l’achat de 10 sacs de sucre ; 1 réfrigérateur ; 5 casiers de boissons ; 10 sachets de boissons gazeuses de marque « American Cola »et espère réaliser un bénéfice 200 000 CFA qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt et investir dans l’activité. Elle envisage ouvrir un super marché c'est-à-dire une boutique plus grande.

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Hafiza

texts.en:
Hafiza is 30-year-old woman living in Stanić Rijeci, a small community outside the town of Doboj. She is married and has one 4-year-old son. Her husband works full-time as a baker, while she has a job as a cook in a local restaurant. Like many Bosnian families, they practice subsistence farming, growing crops to feed their family and their livestock.

Hafiza is taking this, her first loan, in the amount of 1200 KM (US$ 975) to help renovate part of their home in order to create storage space for corn. Right now they do not have enough space to hold all their corn over the winter, so Hafiza plans to buy some supplies to complete the renovation, and also buy some tools to help with the harvesting process. She hopes that the good weather will continue and that she will have plenty of food for the winter months.

Hafiza also plans to buy some chickens, and will use this corn to feed them through the winter as well.

loans.use: To buy tools for farming and to renovate crop storage space

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Mrs. Aminata C. is 41 years old, married, and has five children. She lives in a polygamous family with her husband, children, and two co-wives in the Hamdallaye quarter in the city of Ségou in Mali. Having never gone to school due to social reasons, she got involved in income-generating activities very early on in life, particularly the selling of charcoal and fruits and vegetables, which she has been doing for three years. Wanting to satisfy the winter needs of her customers, she got involved with the Soro Yiriwaso loan program, and she is on her first individual loan with them. She usually stocks up in Tona, Fahina, (surrounding villages of Ségou) and from the farmers who supply the city of Ségou. She sells her goods for cash and on credit to a client base comprised of men, and especially housewives who have a specially-designed area where they store sacks of coal. During the rainy season her profit margin is very high. She hopes to buy 10 sacks of coal and 10 sacks of zaban, (an exotic fruit that is highly-valued in West Africa) and she hopes to make a monthly profit of 25,000 FCFA (about $59). In the future, she hopes to become a major merchant by being involved in other professions besides the selling of charcoal.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Madame Aminata C. est âgée de 41 ans, mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle vit dans une famille polygame avec son mari, ses enfants et ses 2 coépouses dans le quartier Hamdallaye de Ségou République du Mali. N’ayant jamais fréquenté l’école pour des raisons sociales elle s’intéressa très tôt aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment la vente du charbon de bois et des fruits et légumes depuis 3 ans. En vue de satisfaire les demandes hivernales de ses clients elle intégra le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est à son premier prêt individuel. Elle s’approvisionne très généralement à Tona, à Fahina (villages environnants de Ségou).et auprès des paysans ravitaillant la ville de Ségou. Elle vend ses marchandises au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et surtout de femmes à domicile où un endroit est aménagé pour stocker les sacs de charbon. Pendant la saison des pluies la marge bénéficiaire est très élevée. Elle compte acheter 10 sacs de charbon, 10 sacs de Zaban (fruit exotique très prisée en Afrique de l’Ouest) et espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 25 000 FCFA. Elle souhaite dans l’avenir devenir une grande commerçante en menant d’autres activités différentes de la vente de charbon de bois

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal and other various items

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Soro Yiriwaso, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Mkorofi Si Mwenzitu Group

texts.en:
Mariam sells charcoal and firewood in Zanzibar, and she has been in this business since 2006. Her business enables her to generate a monthly profit of approximately $30. She is currently hoping to expand her business and to thereby increase her profits by buying more materials (i.e., charcoal and firewood) to then sell to her customers. She is a single mother of seven children who are between the ages of 9 and 19.

Mariam will share the proceeds of this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses selling goods.

loans.use: To expand and improve their respective businesses by purchasing additional materials to sell to their customers.

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Mrs. Aminata D. is 47 years old and lives with her eight children and her husband in a monogamous family in the Pelengana quarter, south of the city of Ségou (fourth largest economic region in Mali). In the beginning she used to send her servants out to search for firewood for her own personal use, but when her neighbors saw the bundles of wood, they would always come and ask her to sell them some of it. Therefore, she decided to get involved in the firewood business and has been involved in it for 13 years. She makes all her sales at home, for cash or credit to her customers, who are mainly comprised of women as well as bakers. She sells firewood year-round. After having taken out five group loans, she is on her second individual loan and all previous loans were correctly repaid. With this loan she hopes to buy 20 loads of firewood from the surrounding villages of Ségou from farmers who are legally established in the firewood business, and she hopes to make a monthly profit of 12,000 FCFA (about $29), which she hopes to reinvest into her business.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Madame Aminata D. est âgée de 47ans et vit avec ses 8 enfants et son mari dans une famille monogame dans le quartier Pelengana sud de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région économique de la république du Mali). Au début elle envoyait ses domestiques chercher du bois de chauffe pour usage personnel, ses voisins voyant les tas de fagots, venaient toujours lui demander de leur en vendre une partie. C’est ainsi qu’elle a pris l’initiative de faire ce commerce et cela depuis 13 ans. Elle effectue toutes ses ventes à domicile au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée à majorité de femmes et également de boulangers. Elle mène cette activité toute l’année. Apres 5 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe), elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt 20 chargements de bois de chauffe dans les villages environnants de la ville de Ségou auprès des paysans légalement établis pour cette activité et espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 12 000 FCFA. Elle compte renforcer son commerce avec ce bénéfice.

loans.use: Purchase of firewood

loans.name: Arakiyé

texts.fr:
Mrs. Arakiyé Traoré is 58 years old and lives with her husband and their five children in a monogamous family in the first quarter of Ségou (fourth largest economic region in Mali). Having not gone to school for social reasons, she got involved very quickly in income-generating activities, most notably the firewood business as well as that of dyed damask (a highly-valued cloth in West Africa), and has been doing so for 10 years. She has been working with the Soro Yiriwaso institution for four years. After having taken out six group loans with an association from her neighborhood, she is on her second individual loan and all previous loans have been correctly repaid. She travels to Bamako to stock up on damask from one of the best-known suppliers in the capital, if not the entire country of Mali, Gagni Lah. She also purchases firewood on site from farmers who are officially recognized in the firewood business. She sells her goods from her house, night and day (because she has access to a specially-designed area where her wood is stored, sheltered from the rain). With a client base that is mostly female, she sells her dyed cloth on credit which is repayable monthly (for those who are employed) or for cash. She plans to buy 27 loads of firewood and 10 rolls of white damask. Mrs. Traoré hopes to earn a monthly profit of 40,000 FCFA (about $95) which will be reinvested into her cloth dying business and used for repaying the interest on the loan.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Madame Arakiyé Traoré est âgée de 58 ans et vit avec son mari et ses 5 enfants dans une famille monogame au premier quartier de Ségou (quatrième région économique du Mali). N’ayant pas été à l’école pour des raisons sociales, très vite elle commença les activités génératrices de revenus notamment le commerce du bois de chauffe et des tissus bazins teints (tissus très prisé en Afrique de l’ouest), depuis maintenant 10 ans. Elle est en relation avec l’institution Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 4 ans. Après avoir bouclé 6 prêts solidaires avec une association de son quartier, elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Elle s’approvisionnera à Bamako pour les bazins auprès d’un des célèbres fournisseurs de la capitale sinon du Mali à savoir Gagni Lah et sur place pour le bois de chauffe auprès des paysans officiellement reconnus de la profession. Elle vend à la maison nuit et jour (car dispose d’un endroit aménagé où les bois sont stockés à l’abri de la pluie.) Avec une clientèle essentiellement féminine elle vend les habits teints en crédit remboursable mensuellement (aux salariés) ou au comptant. Elle compte acheter 27 chargements de bois de chauffe et 10 rouleaux de bazin blancs. Madame Arakiyé envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40.000 FCFA. qui sera utilisé essentiellement au renforcement l’activité de teinture et pour payer les intérêts du prêt.

loans.use: Purchase of firewood and white damask

loans.name: Khursheed's Group

texts.en:
Khursheed baji is the wife of Muhammad Afzal. She has lived in the city of Borewala, Pakistan, for the last 16 years. She is the mother of three children: two sons and a daughter. Her sons have a furniture business. Her husband has a cigarette shop. Khursheed baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She successfully completed her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). She is now applying for a loan to buy more cigarettes for her husband’s shop.

Khursheed baji is joined in her loan group by a few other members. Sugran baji wants a loan to expand her wheat business. Sakina baji wants a loan to buy wood to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in their own business. The members mutually guarantee each other's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Nyota Njema Group

texts.en:
Ana owns a small retail business in Zanzibar. She is 42 years old, married, and has four children (ages 15, 16, 17, and 22). Each day, she works from 6am to 8pm at her business. She earns a monthly profit of approximately $80.

Ana is now seeking a loan to buy more materials for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses of their own.

loans.use: To expand and improve their respective businesses (e.g., by purchasing additional materials)

loans.name: Mejra

texts.en:
Mejra is a 55-year-old woman living in a small village near the town of Gracanica. She is a widow and has 2 grown children, ages 32 and 35, who have since left home. Mejra receives a small monthly pension, but otherwise needs to support herself by farming.

Mejra has a cow and sells milk and milk products. She wants to use this loan to buy some more food for her cow, to be sure that she has enough for the long winter. And given the high cost of food these days, Mejra believes this will be the best investment for her. She hopes she can buy some nutritious organic food so that her cow will produce high quality milk, and she can then sell this milk at a good price.

Mejra's future goal is to eventually buy another cow, but as of now she does not have enough money. She hopes to earn enough from these milk sales to help finance additions to her livestock for the future.

loans.use: To buy food for her cow

loans.name: Khalida's Group

texts.en:
Khalida baji is the wife of M. S.. She has lived in the city of Borewala, Pakistan, for the last 20 years. She owns a two room brick house. She is the mother of five children: three sons and two daughters. Her eldest daughter is in 10th standard (level). The other children are enrolled in a local school in the neighborhood. Her husband is a wood seller and has been in this profession for the last 5 years. Khalida baji successfully completed her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). She is now applying for a loan to buy more wood for her husband.

Khalida baji is joined in her loan group by a few other members. Nasira baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart. Naziran baji wants a loan to buy thread to resell. Naseem baji wants a loan to repair an auto-rickshaw (three-wheeled motor vehicle). Rabia baji wants a loan to buy car seat covers to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in their own business. The members mutually guarantee each other's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Ramzana's Group

texts.en:
Ramzana baji is the wife of N. A.. She has lived in the city of Borewala, Pakistan, for the last 9 years. She is the mother of four children: three daughters and a son. Her daughters are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Her son is a driver by profession. Ramzana baji has an animal food business and she also takes care of her children. Her husband has a soft drink business. Ramzana baji successfully completed her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). She is now applying for a loan for her new business which is a cloth selling business.

Ramzana baji is joined in her loan group by a few other members. Kaniz baji wants a loan to buy animal food (wheat fiber). Safia baji wants a loan to buy more garments for her garment business. Zahida baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine. Roma baji wants a loan to buy a chopping machine for her sugarcane business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in their own business. The members mutually guarantee each other's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Najma's Group

texts.en:
Najma baji is the wife of T. H. and has been living in this city Borewala, Pakistan for the last 15 years. She owns a six-room brick house. She is the mother of four children: two daughters and two sons. Her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Najma baji and her husband weave carpets and sell them to different shops. They have been in this profession for the last 5 years. Najma baji successfully completed her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is requesting a loan to buy cloth for her carpet business.

She is joined in her loan group by 4 other members. Anayat baji requests a loan to buy fertilizer for her land. Kanizan baji requests a loan to buy bangles to resell. Maqsoodan baji requests a loan to buy car seat covers to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Chausiku

texts.en:
Chausiku owns and operates her own shop in Zanzibar. She is 40 years old and divorced with one 18 year old child. Every day, she works from 8am to 4pm at her store. She can earn a monthly profit of about $50.

Chausiku has been in business since 2002 and now hopes for a loan to buy more materials for her business to increase her profit.

loans.use: To buy more materials to expand her businesses.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Mediha

texts.en:
Mediha is a 30-year-old woman living in Gračanica. She is married and has one 3-year-old daughter. Her husband works in construction and finds work when he can during the summer season. He typically doesn't work in the winter, so they try to save what he makes in the summer to last them the whole year. Other than his salary they do not have many other sources of income right now.

This is Meiha’s first loan with Žene za Žene, which she has requested in the amount of 1200 KM (US$ 975). She plans to use this money towards cultivating her fields for growing more eggplants, a very popular vegetable here in Bosnia. She will need to purchase some pesticides to protect her plants over the next months, and also hopes to buy a sprinkler system for the fields. Mediha is pictured here by her land, part of which is already sown. She hopes to make a good profit here and use their earnings to make finishing touches on the home she and her husband have built for their family.

loans.use: To use towards cultivating field for eggplants

loans.name: Zuhra's Group

texts.en:
Zuhra baji is the wife of Muhammad Amin and has been living in this city called Borewala, Pakistan for the last 14 years. She owns a two-room brick house. She is the mother of six children: four sons and two daughters. Her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Her husband sells sugarcane syrup and has been in this profession for the last 5 years. Zuhra baji successfully completed her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is requesting a loan to buy another juicer machine to expand the business.

She is joined in her loan group by 3 other members. Nazia baji requests a loan to buy a shopper maker machine. Zahidan baji requests a loan to buy fertilizer for her land. Parveen baji requests a loan to buy more beams for her rental beams business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Hajia

texts.en:
Hajia has owned and run a shop in Zanzibar since 2001. She can earn a small profit from her business. Now, she is looking for a loan so that she can expand her business and increase her profit. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her shop.

Hajia is 25 years old. She is married with one two year old child.

loans.use: To buy more materials to expand her business.

loans.name: Benkadi (L’Union Fait La Force) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Benkadi Group are all married and average 41 years of age and five children. They live in large traditional families that are mostly monogamous in the village of Dagala Wèrè, in Ségou Prefecture, the Republic of Mali. They essentially work in small-scale commerce: dried couscous and grains, kitchen utensiles (calebasses), and condiments.

Connected by ties of community and friendship, the women of the Benkadi Group have mutual trust in each other. So they decided as a group to request a collaboration with the the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They generally get their supplies in Cinzana, Gare, Ségou, and locally in town. Millet seeds are pounded, sifted, and steamed before being dried in the sun and protected from flies and contamination. Next, the finished product is placed into a calebasse (a bowl made from a gourd) for selling. Sales are generally made either with cash or credit, in the home or door-to-door, in Ségou and in Soro Wèrè. The customers are composed of all social categories: men, women, and sometimes children.

With this loan, they each intend to buy two sacks of grain, sixty calebasses, and a large quantity of condiments. They each hope to realize a monthly profit of 7,500 francs CFA, which will serve to cover the loan interest, and the rest will be invested in the business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Les membres du groupe Benkadi sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 41ans et 5 enfants. Elles vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles à majorité monogames dans le village Dagala Wèrè Préfecture de Ségou République du Mali. Elles exercent essentiellement le petit commerce : de couscous séché, de grains de céréales, d’ustensiles de cuisine (calebasses) et de condiments.

Etant liées par des liens de voisinage et d’amitié, les femmes du groupe Benkadi se font mutuellement confiance. Alors elles décidèrent ensemble de solliciter la collaboration de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles s’approvisionnent généralement à Cinzana gare, Ségou, et sur place au village. Les graines de mil sont pilées, tamisées, mis sous vapeur d’eau avant d’être asséché au soleil à l’abri des mouches et des saletés. Ensuite le produit fini est mis dans une calebasse pour la vente. Les ventes se font généralement au comptant ou à crédit, à domicile ou en ambulant à Ségou et à Soro Wèrè. La clientèle est composée de toutes les catégories sociales : hommes, femmes et quelques fois des enfants

Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter chacune deux sacs de grains de céréales, 60 calebasses, une quantité importante de condiments alimentaires. Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 7 500 FCFA qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans l’activité.

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Laiifa

texts.en:
Laiifa owns her own shop in Zanzibar. She hopes to expand her business to increase her profit. This is her second loan for her business through BRAC Tanzania. The first one was paid off successfully and helped her as she grew her business.

Laiifa is 25 years old. She is married and has two children ages 7 and 6.

loans.use: To buy more goods to expand her business.

loans.name: Mwadawa's Group

texts.en:
Mwadawa has owned a firewood business in Zanzibar since 2005. She works every day from 7:00am to 8:00pm and makes a monthly profit of about $40. She would like to take out a loan in order to expand her business and increase her profit.

Amina is married with three children. Her children are ages 7, 5, and one and a half.

She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more supplies to increase her business.

loans.name: Danaya (La Confiance) Group

texts.fr:
The women of the Danaya Group are all married and average 41 years of age and four children. They generally live in polygamous households in the Sokala district of Zambougou Fouta (Ségou Prefecture, Republic of Mali) with their husbands, co-spouses, and children.

Linked by ties of professional relationships, friendship, and community, they do commerce in condiments and foodstuffs. They generally buy their goods locally (in Zambougou) and in the surrounding villages (such as Teisserela et Ganssola) in order to store them per the allotted family plots. In contrast, condiments are purchased at the grand market of Ségou from wholesalers at the weekly markets.

They resell these items retail, cash or credit accepted, on market days either door-to-door or from home. The customers are generally made up of women and men. In order to meet the needs of their burgeoning customer base, the members of the Danaya Group have decided to ask for a group loan from the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they are on their first loan.

They intend to use this loan to buy one sack of rice, 250 liters of milk, 6 sacks of peanuts, 10 boxes of smoked fish, and one sack of beans. These goods are sold retail. They hope to realize an average monthly profit of 7,500 francs CFA, which will be used for covering the loan interest, for bolstering working capital, and for assisting with family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Les femmes du groupe Danaya sont toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 41 ans avec 4 enfants et vivent généralement dans des foyers polygamiques dans le quartier Sokala de Zambougou Fouta (Préfecture de Ségou République du Mali) avec leurs époux coépouses et enfants.

Liées par des relations professionnelles, d’amitié et de voisinage, elles exercent le commerce de condiments et de denrées alimentaires. Elles achètent généralement les denrées alimentaires sur place (à Zambougou) et dans les villages environnants (tels Teisserela et Ganssola) pour les emmagasiner au niveau de la concession conjugale. Par contre les condiments sont achetés au grand marché de Ségou auprès des grossistes fréquentant les foires hebdomadaires.

Elles revendent ces articles en détail au comptant et à crédit les jours de foires de façon ambulante ou à domicile. La clientèle est généralement constituée de femmes et d’hommes. Afin de satisfaire les besoins de leurs clientèles de plus en plus croissantes, les membres du groupe Danaya ont décidé de demander un prêt de groupe à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur premier prêt.

Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt un sac de riz ; 250 litres de lait ; 6 sacs d’arachide ; 10 cartons de poissons fumés et 1 sac de haricot. Ces produits son vendus en détail. Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 7.500 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, renforcer les fonds de commerce et aider dans les charges de la famille.

loans.use: To buy condiments and foodstuffs

loans.name: Amy

texts.fr:
Amy S. is a 47 year old woman who lives in the Cite Lamy district of Thies with her family. She has run a small business for more than 5 years, selling breakfasts near her house. With the goal of strengthening her working capital, she is asking for this loan.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

AMY S. EST UNE FEMME AGEE DE 47ANS ET QUI VIT AU QUARTIER CITE LAMY DE THIES AVEC SA FAMILLE .ELLE FAIT DU PETIT COMMERCE DEPUIS PLUS DE CINQ ANS ET VEND DU PETIT DEJEUNER PRES DE CHEZ ELLE.C'EST DANS LE BUT DE RENFORCER SON FONDS DE ROULEMENT QU'ELLE DEMANDE CE PRET.

loans.use: To increase working capital

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for UIMCEC, a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Mwanabaraka

texts.en:
Mwanabaraka has sold food and perfume in Zanzibar for one year. She makes a profit of about $30 per month and is looking to take out a loan now in order to increase her profit. She will use the loan to increase the inventory in her store.

Mwanabaraka is 27 years old and is married. She has one eight-month old child.

loans.use: To buy more inventory to expand her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Songnonyé (Soumission Mutuelle) Group

texts.fr:
The seven members of the Songnonyé Group average 39 years of age and four children. They live for the most part in monogamous households in the Bagadadji district of the city of Ségou (Republic of Mali).

The members of the group are brought together around their work and have been collaborating for five years now. The leader of the group, having benefited from training (through the support of the Ségou Dept. of the Promotion of Women) in how to dye fabrics and to make soap, has by turns trained the other members of her group and her association. Besides working with dyes and making soap, they sell firewood, rice, condiments, and clothing, etc....

In order to obtain further financial resources, the women of the Songnonyé Group have decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they are on their first loan. With this loan, they intend to buy one role of white damask (very popular fabric in West Africa) that will be dyed before being sold; six lengths of Wax pagnes (traditional print cloth); two cart loads of firewood; and one sack of rice. They generally get their stock from neighboring villages (such as Zambougou) for the firewood; from the Office of Niger in Niono for the rice (the biggest management and production organization for rice in West Africa); and from the grand marketplace of Ségou for the clothing, tubers, and condiments.

Sales are made locally in Ségou (in the district marketplaces) and generally at the retail level, with cash and sometimes credit. Sales are also accomplished in the home and at the weekly markets of the surrounding villages. They hope to realize an average monthly benefit of 20,000 francs CFA and wish to be better organized to perfect their training, notably in working with dyes and in making soap, in order to offer quality products.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Les sept (7) membres du groupe Songnonyé ont une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans, 4 enfants et vivent la plupart dans des foyers monogamiques au quartier Bagadadji de la ville de Ségou (République du Mali).

Les membres du groupe se sont regroupés autour de leurs activités économiques et collaborent depuis maintenant 5 ans. La responsable du groupe ayant bénéficié d’une formation (à travers un appui du département de la Promotion Féminine de Ségou.), en teinture et en fabrication de savon a tour à tour formé les autres membres de son groupe et de son association. En plus de la teinture et de la fabrication de savon, elles vendent aussi le bois de chauffe, le riz, les condiments, les habits etc…..

Afin d’obtenir une ressource financière complémentaire les femmes du groupe Songnonyé ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur premier prêt. Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter 1 rouleau bazin blanc (tissu très prisé en Afrique de l’ouest) qui sera teint avant la vente, 6 pièces de pagnes wax, 2 chargements de charrette en bois de chauffe et 1 sac de riz. Elles s’approvisionnent généralement dans les villages voisins (tel Zambougou) en bois de chauffe, en riz à l’office du Niger à Niono (la plus grande structure d’encadrement et de production de riz de l’Afrique de l’Ouest) et au grand marché de Ségou pour les habits, les tubercules et les condiments.

Les ventes sont faites sur place à Ségou (dans les marchés de quartiers) généralement en détail au comptant quelques fois à crédit. Les ventes sont également effectuées à domicile et dans les foires des villages environnants. Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20.000 FCFA. et souhaitent s’organiser davantage pour parfaire leurs formations notamment en teinture et dans la fabrication du savon afin d’offrir des articles de qualité.

loans.use: To buy cloth, pagnes, rice, and firewood

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en:
Riziki has a business in Zanzibar selling juice, ground nuts, and oil. Every month she makes a profit of about $25 but she is hoping that this loan will allow her to increase her profit. She will use the loan to buy more materials to sell.

Rizika is married and has six children. Her children are ages 2, 5, 6, 14, 15, and 28.

loans.use: To buy more materials in order to expand her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Cheikh

texts.fr:
Mr. Cheikh D. has been a builder by profession for more than ten years. He is married and has three children. He has been a member of this funding organization for two years, and is asking for this loan with the aim of buying wooden boards, which will help him in his building tasks.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

MR CHEIKH D. est un maçon de profession depuis plus de dix ans.il est marié et père de trois enfants .il est membre de la caisse depuis deux ans et demande ce pret dans le but d'acheter des planches qui vont l'aider davantage dans ses chantires de maçonnerie.

loans.use: To buy wooden planks

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for UIMCEC, a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: María Dolores

texts.es:
María Dolores has had her general store in the neighborhood where her home is located for approximately 20 years. She tells us that what she sells the most of are beverages, such as sodas and juices, given that in her country it is warm a great deal of the time.

Despite the fact that competition from supermarkets is great, she says that she always tries to have her store well-stocked with basic needs so that customers always find what they are looking for. Several months ago, a residential unit with several buildings opened in her neighborhood. This brought many families to the area, greatly benefiting María’s business with additional customers.

For this reason, María sees a great opportunity to bet on her business and supply it with a greater variety of merchandise so she can slowly expand her enterprise.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña María Dolores tiene su despensa en un barrio su casa desde hace 20 años aproximadamente, ella nos cuenta que lo que más vende son bebidas como gaseosas y jugos ya que en nuestro país la mayor parte del año hace calor.

A pesar de que la competencia con los supermercados es grande, ella dice que trata siempre de tener todo lo básico en su despensa de modo a encuentren siempre lo que buscan. Hace unos meses se habilitó en su barrio un complejo habitacional que comprende varios edificios con departamentos en donde muchas familias se han mudado, esto trajo a María un gran beneficio pues ahora consta con mayor cantidad de clientes.

Debido a esto, María ve como una buena oportunidad apostar a su negocio y abastecerlo de mayor cantidad y variedad de mercaderías pues así ella podrá ir ampliando el negocio de a poco.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her store such as dairy products, bread, sodas, juices, fruits, vegetables, flour, pastas, cleaning products and other items for the home.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha has owned a small business in Zanzibar since 2002. She is hoping to take out her first loan in order to increase her inventory. Right now, she earns a monthly profit of about $50, but she hopes the loan will help her increase her profit. She works every day from 7:00am to 6:00pm.

Asha is 29 years old and is married. She has two children, ages 2 and 8.

loans.use: To increase her inventory and expand her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en:
Tatu has owned a small business in Zanzibar for one year. She works from 8:00am to 8:00pm every day and usually makes a profit of about $50 per month. She is looking to take out her first loan in order to buy more materials and increase her profit.

Tatus is married and has one two year old child. She is 22 years old.

loans.use: To buy more materials and expand her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Kazya

texts.en:
Kazye has had a charcoal business in Zanzibar for four years. She works every day from 8:00am to 8:00pm and makes a monthly profit of approximately $50. By taking out a loan, she hopes to purchase more inventory, expand her business, and increase her profits.

Kazye is 50 years old. She is divorced and has no children.

loans.use: To buy more inventory and expand her  charcoal business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth Zeneyda S. used her Esperanza Bank of Hope loans to open her salon, Salon Belleza Grismary, two years ago.  Because of her loans and the help of her cousins, the salon is now able to offer both hair and nail services.  Ruth's ultimate dream is open more branches of her salon so that she can give her three children (aged 9, 13, 19) the best life possible.

loans.use: Salon Belleza Grismary (beauty salon)

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Esperanza International, a partner of HOPE International - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Braudelina

texts.en: Braudelina F., 83, is a widowed mother of six, aged 62, 50, 48, 46, 43, and 41.  She has used her Esperanza Bank of Hope loans to expand the selection of her home-run candy business offerings.  Her main motivation for continued expansion are her sons and daughters: though not dependent on her, Braudelina says that they are poorer than she is, and that she specifically needs to help one son who has heart problems.

loans.use: Homemade candy sales

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Esperanza International, a partner of HOPE International - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Restauración Group

texts.en:
Eduvijes C. is a 26-year old woman who lives in a very poor community called Villa Ortega in the eastern province of Hato Mayor in the Dominican Republic. Eduvijes lives with her husband and three children, ages 6, 4, and 3, in a small home. She started her business two years ago buying bread in a town called La Romana and then selling the bread to people in her rural community.  She is requesting a loan so that she can buy larger quantities of bread, allowing her to reduce transportation costs to La Romana.  It is Eduvijes´ hope that she will one day expand her business to include other baked goods.  Until then, she will continue providing for her family in order for her children to receive a quality education.  In her free time, Eduvijes enjoys going to church and reading the Bible.

Enduvijes is the leader of the 5-person micro-bank group, Restauración.  In English, this means `restoration.´  Each of these unique Dominican entrepreneurs unite in solidarity, allowing them to access funding that they would otherwise never be able to receive on their own. 

On behalf of Enduvijes, the Restauración group, and the entire team here at Esperanza International, we thank you for your support with this micro loan!

loans.use: To buy additional quantities of bread

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Esperanza International, a partner of HOPE International - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: La Esperanza Group

texts.es:
This group was formed thanks to Lucia G. and Marta Domínguez, who contacted the foundation interested in the program Committee of Enterprising Women. They are from the La Conquista settlement within the La Lomita neighborhood.

These women, along with the other ladies who make up the group, comprise part of a faction of people denominated as “without roofs”. These people have nowhere to live (neither a house or land) and, together with hundreds of other people in the same situation, joined together to fight for their rights. Today, they live in a settlement which they created a year ago which the government subsequently bought to be able to build them homes so they could live there legally.

In this settlement live several families looking to get ahead. The women play an important role since, in many cases, they are the head of household. It’s in this way that 15 women from the settlement gathered together to form the group called La Esperanza (which means “hope”). They carry out a variety of activities: the sale of garlic, medicinal herbs, food sales, some have stores, others sell blankets, sheets, clothing, toys, housewares, cleaning products, etc.

Given that the settlement is in a remote area, they must travel to get to the nearest clinics. It’s for this reason that Marta decided to take courses in medicine and it is she who gives injections, takes blood pressure readings and provides immediate medical care for those who need it.

It is a very unified group and the women, in addition to dedicating themselves to their particular activities, also carry out extra tasks to earn more funds to help improve the neighborhood.

Today they need a loan to invest in their businesses, especially to buy merchandise to offer for sale.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Este Comité se formo gracias a la señoras Lucia G. y Marta Domínguez, quienes llamaron a la fundación interesadas en el programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras, ellas son del Asentamiento “La Conquista” del Barrio “La Lomita”.

Estas señoras, al igual que las demás mujeres que comprende este comité, forman parte de un grupo de gente denominado “sin techo”. Estas personas no poseían un lugar (ni casa ni tierra) donde vivir, y que unidos entre cientos de personas en igual situación, lucharon por su derecho y hoy día viven en un asentamiento que tomaron juntos el año pasado y que posteriormente el estado adquirió compro para poder construirles casas para que vivan ahí de forma legal.

En ese asentamientos existen varias familias que también buscan su progreso, las mujeres cumplen roles importantes pues son, en la mayoría de los casos, cabeza de familia. Es así como 15 mujeres de este asentamiento se unieron y formaron un comité que llamado “La Esperanza”. Ellas realizan distintos tipos de actividades entre ellas: venta de ajo, hierbas medicinales, venta de comidas, otras tienen despensas, otras poseen mercerías en donde venden colchas, sabanas, ropas, juguetes, artículos para el hogar, productos de limpieza, etc.

Debido que el asentamiento queda en un lugar retirado, ellas deben viajar hasta los puestos de salud más cercanos, es por eso que Marta, decidió hacer cursos de enfermería y ella es quien aplica inyecciones, hace nebulizaciones para niños, toma de presión y primeros auxilios para todas las personas que necesiten.

Es un grupo muy unido, ellas además de dedicarse a sus actividades particulares, también realizan actividades extras con el fin de obtener fondos para realizar mejoras en el barrio.

Hoy ellas necesitan de un crédito que podrán invertirlo en sus negocios, especialmente comprando mercaderías para vender.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing such as socks, gloves, hats, scarves, etc.  Those who sell food, to purchase items such as fruits and vegetables, dairy products, meats, flour, oil, noodles and frozen items.  Others wish to buy natural medicines, cosmetics, creams, coal, etc.

loans.name: La Esperanza Group

texts.es:
Este Comité se formo gracias a la señoras Lucia G. y Marta Domínguez, quienes llamaron a la fundación interesadas en el programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras, ellas son del Asentamiento “La Conquista” del Barrio “La Lomita”.

Hoy ellas necesitan de un crédito que podrán invertirlo en sus negocios, especialmente comprando mercaderías para vender.

loans.use: Compra de ropas como, lencería, medias, guantes, gorras, bufandas, etc. Las que se dedican a la venta de comestibles frutas y verduras, lácteos, carnes, harina, aceite, fideo y productos enlatados. Otras compraran remedios naturales, maquillajes, cremas, carbón, etc.

loans.name: Pilar

texts.en: Pilar, a single mother of two (aged 5 and 25), sold clothing and food before she took out her first Esperanza Bank of Loan two cycles ago, but she says that her experience has allowed both parts of her business to grow, because she can now offer a much wider selection.  Also, the opportunities that Esperanza have been offered have taught her much about God and getting through hard times.

loans.use: Comedor Nena (Restaurant and clothing sales)

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Esperanza International, a partner of HOPE International - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Reinalda

texts.es:
Reinalda C. is a modest, hardworking woman who lives in one of the most humble neighborhoods in the city of Asunción. She has worked hard since she was little to earn a living. She has been a widow for about a year now, and she tells us that during this time she has had some very difficult moments – both emotionally and financially.

She struggles as always to get ahead, and lives in an unassuming house together with her grandchildren who stayed with her to keep her company. Reinalda supports her household by selling food. She cooks starting at dawn, and leaves in the mornings and afternoons to travel the city selling her wares from her cart. At midday, she serves lunches from her house to the workers in the area who place their orders with her.

She uses the loan as a means to supply her business with the necessary ingredients to cook her meals. Today, she seeks a new loan to purchase meat, noodles, flour, oil, condiments, eggs, fruits and vegetables, all of which are key ingredients she needs to make her delicious food.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Reinalda C., persona humilde, trabajadora, vive en uno de los barrios más humildes de la Cuidad de Asunción. Desde pequeña trabajo duro para ganarse la vida. Ella es viuda, hace aproximadamente 1 año, y cuenta que desde entonces a pasado por momentos muy difíciles tanto emocionales como económicos.

Ella lucha igual que siempre para salir adelante, ella vive en una humilde casa junto con sus nietos que se quedaron con ella para hacerle compañía en la casa y no sentirse tan sola. Reinalda mantiene su hogar con la venta de comidas. Cocina desde tempranas horas de la madrugada y sale por las mañanas y las tardes a recorrer la ciudad vendiendo comidas típicas en su canasto. Al medio día sirve almuerzos en su casa a los trabajadores de la zona, que hacen sus pedidos de comida.

Ella utiliza el crédito como un medio de ayuda para abastecerse de los ingredientes necesarios para preparar sus comidas. Hoy ella solicita un crédito nuevo para comprar carne, fideo, harina, aceite, condimentos, huevos, vegetales y frutas que son necesarios para elaborar sus ricas comidas.

loans.use: For the purchase of meat, noodles, flour, oil, condiments, eggs, fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en: Before her Esperanza Bank of Hope loan, Daisy had a business selling water in her Boca Chica community.  Now, just two loans later, she runs a school for children of the community.  It currently teaches 40 students 6 days a week.  The school has the help of 6 volunteers, who help with preparing juice and conducting lessons, but Daisy would like to expand the business by hiring employees with future loans.  Her school is a prime example of the improvements microlending can bring to communities as well as to individual borrowers.

loans.use: Refugio Infantil Comunitari Tia Daisy (school)

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Esperanza International, a partner of HOPE International - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Nji Jacob

texts.en:
Nji Jacob was born on the 3rd of January 1971; he is married and the father of three children. Things have not been going well for him since childhood. His parents were poor and were unable to educate him; things became more difficult for him when his mother died, and as if that was not enough, his wife died mysteriously. He had to struggle as a man until  he became a member of GHAPE; he was trained on how to start with life without money. Thereafter he took his first loan and invested it in pig farming; he learned how to ride okada (motorbike) in the year 2004. Since then he has been managing well. 
If given a loan he will buy his personal motorbike, get a driving license, and pay all necessary documents. He is quite sure his business is going to be successful because he started it from the day he became a member of GHAPE which implies he has a lot of experience in the business, moreover, he will be the owner of the bike which is going to give him more benefit.
He has 18 months to repay the loan. The first installment of the repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of a two-wheel motorbike

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of freezer, provisions, and drinks

loans.name: Tiéssiri (Courage) Group

texts.fr:
The nine members of the Tiéssiri Group are all married and average 32 years of age and three children.
