They generally live in polygamous households with their husbands, co-spouses, and children in the Sokala district of Zambougou Fouta , Ségou Prefecture (Republic of Mali). This group of women, who are linked by ties of community, age, and clan, does trading in agricultural products and other goods of small-scale commerce. In order to meet the stronger and stronger demand, this group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program, which just allocated the members their first loan.

They resupply their inventory locally in Zambougou and in surrounding villages (Teisserela et Ganssola) from pilot growers for agricultural products. The supply of the various goods is gotten from Ségou from wholesalers of the grand marketplace. These women each have storage space on the allotted family plots for keeping their inventory. They each intend to use this loan to buy: one sack of beans, a sack and a half of rice, 15 sacks of millet, and 250 liters of milk.

Sales are made at the retail level, cash and credit accepted, from home most of the time and at the public square and in the marketplaces of nearby villages. The customers are generally made up of city inhabitants and of specialists in the stocking up and selling of agricultural products. The projected profits are estimated at 8,000 francs CFA and will serve to cover the loan interest and to bolster working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Les neuf (9) femmes du groupe Tiéssiri sont toutes mariées et ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, 3 enfants. Elles vivent généralement dans des foyers polygamiques avec leurs maris, coépouses et enfants dans le quartier Sokala de Zambougou Fouta préfecture de Ségou (République du Mali). Ce groupe de femmes lié par des relations de voisinage de groupe d’âge et de parenté, exerce le commerce de produits agricoles et d’autres articles de petit commerce. Afin de satisfaire la demande de plus en plus forte, ce groupe a décidé d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso qui vient de leur octroyer leur premier prêt.

Elles se ravitaillent sur place à Zambougou et dans les villages environnants (Teisserela et Ganssola,) auprès de paysans pilotes pour les produits agricoles. Pour les articles divers l’approvisionnement se fait à partir de Ségou auprès des grossistes du grand marché. Ces femmes disposent toutes d’un lieu de stockage au niveau de la concession familiale pour la garde des produits avant la vente. Elles comptent acheter chacune avec ce prêt, 1 sac de haricot, 1 sac et 1 /2 de riz, 15 sacs de petit mil ; 250 litres de lait.

La vente se fait en détail au comptant et à crédit à domicile la plupart du temps et sur la place publique et dans les foires de villages non éloignés. La clientèle est généralement constituée de citadins et des spécialises du stockage et vente des produits agricoles. Les bénéfices prévisionnels estimés à 8 000 FCFA. serviront à payer les intérêts du prêt et renforcer le fonds de commerce.

loans.use: To buy grains and fresh cow's milk

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Soro Yiriwaso, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Américo

texts.es:
Americo, 36, and Silvia, 33, have been living together for seven years. They have a six-year-old daughter. Silvia, who is a teacher, helps with the household expenses.

Americo has a small dairy farm where he raises milk cows that produce an average of 50 liters of milk per day. He sells the milk in different places around the town.

Three years ago Americo used to make plant pots, but the sale of the pots became less and less profitable. At that time he already had a cow, so he started selling the milk until he was able to save enough to buy another cow. Slowly but surely his dairy business grew.

Americo also has a small plot of land where he grows grass and sugar cane, which in turn are used to feed the cows. Americo does not have to spend as much in commercial feed for the cows.

Through Fundacion Paraguaya, he previously received a loan, which he paid promptly after investing it in buying one more cow. This time is is requesting another loan to buy another cow and increase his dairy farm milk production, and well as his income.

Translated from Spanish by Maria B., Kiva volunteer

Américo tiene 36 años, vive en pareja con Silvia de 33 años de edad. Hace 7 años que viven juntos y tienen una pequeña hija de 6 años de edad.

Américo posee un pequeño tambo en donde cría vacas lecheras que le dan un promedio de 50 litros de leche diarios. Luego sale a vender dicha producción hacia distintos lugares de la ciudad.

Comenta que anteriormente se dedicaba a la fabricación y venta de planteras de cemento (macetas), pero que dicha actividad le iba generando cada vez menos ganancias. Como ya contaba con una vaca lechera, comenzó vendiendo la leche que ésta le producía, hasta que pudo juntar el importe necesario para la compra de otra vaca más. Y fue así que su negocio fue creciendo. Desde ese entonces ya han transcurrido tres años.

Su pareja, que se dedica a la docencia, le ayuda con los gastos del hogar. Américo tiene una pequeña chacra en donde cultiva pastos y caña dulce que luego son utilizados para alimentar a sus vacas, es por eso que ahorra bastante debido a que no tiene necesidad de comprar gran cantidad de balanceados.

Ya recurrió anteriormente a la Fundación Paraguaya para acceder a un préstamo el cual invirtió en la compra de una vaca lechera más, abonando en forma excelente todas sus cuotas. Es por eso que solicita un nuevo crédito para la compra de otra vaca de manera a ir aumentando su producción y por consiguiente sus ingresos.

loans.use: purchase of a milk cow

loans.name: Joel Agwe

texts.en:
Born on the 30th of April 1975, Mr. T. is a single man who lives in a four-room apartment in the Tunebeng–Ku Bome neighborhood in Bome. Orphaned at an early age because his impoverished parents could not afford medication, Mr. T. did not have the privilege of even basic education or training to learn a trade. Since his parents’ death, he has been responsible for his junior siblings. Wishing to escape poverty and start a business, he joined GHAPE in 2001. Since then, he has borrowed and successfully repaid three loans, worth US$ 230 in total, and the profit from these loans has helped him to maintain himself and his family, and pay for the school needs of his junior brothers.

Given this loan, he plans to buy 50 bags of pig feed, petrol, and colors for weaving. He will use the profit from this loan to continue to educate his junior brothers and part will be re-invested in his business. He thinks his business will succeed because he has been doing this business for five years and because his neighbors will provide a ready market for his pigs. 
	
He plans to repay his loan in 18 months. The first installment of the repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of 50 bags of pig feed, petrol, and colors for weaving

loans.name: Asteria

texts.es:
Asteria, 45, is happily married to Nestor, her husband of 27 years. The couple has raised 6 children; the oldest is 24 years old, while the youngest just turned 10.

Asteria tells with sadness that her oldest two children are living, working and studying in the neighboring country of Argentina, because they do not have the same opportunities in Paraguay. The younger four children go to school in Paraguay.

Asteria owns the only grocery store in the neighborhood, and she keeps it well stocked. She also distributes coal to various small stores all over the city, and drives her own truck to do so.

Asteria has an established customer base, and her business does very well, because she has no competition. Her husband Nestor is a policeman, and both take care of the household expenses.

Asteria needs a loan to buy more merchandise such as flour, rice, pasta, bread, oil, etc, to stock up her grocery store.

Translated from Spanish by Maria B., Kiva volunteer

Asteria, que hoy día cuenta con 45 años de edad, está felizmente casada hace 27 años con Néstor. La pareja ha logrado criar a 6 hijos, el mayor tiene 24 años de edad y la menor ha cumplido 10 años.

Asteria cuenta con tristeza que sus dos hijos mayores se encuentran viviendo en la Argentina, (país vecino del Paraguay) donde trabajan y estudian, ya que aquí no han tenido la oportunidad de hacerlo. Sus demás hijos siguen estudiando aquí.

Asteria es propietaria de una despensa muy bien surtida y que además es la única del barrio, además vende carbón vegetal que reparte a otros pequeños almacenes de distintas compañías de la ciudad. El reparto lo hace en una camioneta de su propiedad.

Comenta que tiene una clientela muy bien formada y que le va muy bien debido a que no tiene competencia. Su esposo es policía y le ayuda con los gastos del hogar.

Necesita de un crédito para la compra de distintas mercaderías como: harina, arroz, fideos, panificados, aceite, etc. a fin de surtir mejor su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise: flour, rice, bread, oil

loans.name: Wendy

texts.en: Wendy B. R., aged 34 and the mother of 2, used her Esperanza Bank of Hope loan to start her business of selling crafts and general home products.  Some of the products she makes at home, like candles and Christian novelties, and others she orders, like cleaning products and children's vitamin syrup.  The choice of merchandise may seem odd, but Wendy's business experience has taught her what her customers want.

loans.use: General Store

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Esperanza International, a partner of HOPE International - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Ms. Mariam S., age 42, is married and the mother of four. She lives in a monogamous family with her shepherd husband and her children in the Sido Sonicoura district of the city of Ségou. Not having had the opportunity to attend school, she very early on started working to earn an income with the help of her mother. Ultimately, she has been devoting herself to commerce in firewood and condiments for ten years now.

Associated with Soro Yiriwaso for three years, she has already benefited from five solidarity loans (group loans) and is on her first individual loan. Each of the preceding loans has been correctly repaid. This loan will be used to buy 20 loads of firewood, 400 kg of onions, and 300 kg of karité oil (from the shea nut).

She gets her stock exclusively at the grand marketplace of the city of Ségou for her supply of condiments and from small farmers specializing in cutting firewood, in the surroundings of Ségou. The wood is thus purchased and stocked at an equipped spot located in the courtyard of the allotted family plot. It is sold, particularly at the retail level, for cash to a customer base composed of women and men in the district. She intends to realize a profit of 70,000 francs CFA and dreams of becoming a wholesaler.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Madame Mariam S. âgée de 42 ans est mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle vit dans une famille monogame avec son époux pasteur et ses enfants dans le quartier Sido Sonicoura de la ville de Ségou. N’ayant pas eu la chance de fréquenter l’école, elle a très tôt commencé les activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa maman pour finalement se consacrer au commerce de bois de chauffe et de condiments alimentaires depuis maintenant 10 ans.

En relation avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis 3 ans, elle a déjà bénéficié de 5 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) et est à son premier prêt individuel. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter 20 chargements de bois de chauffe, 400 kg d’oignon, 300 Kg d’huile alimentaire à base de karité.

Son approvisionnement se fait exclusivement au grand marché de la ville de Ségou en condiments et auprès des paysans spécialisés dans la coupe de bois de chauffe aux alentours de la ville se Ségou. Le bois ainsi acheté est stocké dans un endroit emménagé dans la cour de la concession familiale et vendu à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes du quartier en détail surtout et au comptant.. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice 70 000 FCFA. et rêve de devenir grossiste.

loans.use: To buy firewood, onions, and karité butter

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Ma Esther is a widow whose husband died about five years ago. They were blessed with six children, two of whom are still below the age of fifteen. She has suffered from poverty throughout her life: she had to drop out after primary school because her parents could not afford school fees; and after her husband’s death she has struggled to maintain six children single-handedly. She regrets that she has not been able to allow all her children to study freely and that they have had worries about food and money, as she did in her youth. 

In 2002, Ma Esther was motivated to become a member of GHAPE by other members. Since then, she has successfully borrowed and repaid loans four times, allowing her to expand her crop farm. The profit from her farming has helped her to pay school fees for her younger children and to provide some basic needs like food for the family.

Given this loan, she plans to buy corn and bean seedlings, and pay for labor to clear her farm. She knows her business is going to succeed because she has acquired some basic training on finance management and agriculture from GHAPE, which has added to her lifetime of farming experience. She plans to repay her loan in 24 months. The first installment of the repayment shall be done on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of corn seeds, beans, clearing, and labor

loans.name: Daniela

texts.es:
Daniela is 45 years old, and has been living with Manuel for 28 years. They had seven children, but Daniela says with sadness that two of them died; the other five still live at home.

Daniela sells several kinds of meat and drinks. She works very hard: she gets up at 4am every morning to buy wholesale meat that she later sells door to door. She sells the drinks out of her home; she has a freezer to keep the drinks cold.

Her greatest dream is one day to open a small grocery and butcher store. She knows it will not be easy, but she is applying great determination and effort to achieve her dream.

Her request this time is for a loan to buy more meat and drinks to keep up with her customers' growing demand.

Translated from Spanish by Maria B., Kiva volunteer

Daniela tiene 45 años de edad, vive en pareja hace 28 años con Manuel. Juntos tuvieron siete hijos y Daniela comenta con tristeza que dos fallecieron mientras que los cinco restantes aún viven con ellos.

Daniela se dedica a la venta de carne y bebidas de todo tipo. Es una mujer muy sacrificada ya que todos los días se levanta a las 4:00 a.m. para ir a comprar carne al por mayor que luego sale a vender casa por casa. Las bebidas las vende en su hogar y para ello cuenta con una congeladora en donde las pone a enfriar todos los días.

Su mayor sueño es montar algún día una despensa y carnicería. Sabe que no será fácil lograrlo pero mientras tanto está poniendo todo el empeño y esfuerzo para conseguirlo.

En esta oportunidad necesita de un préstamo para la compra de más carnes y bebidas ya que tiene mucha demanda y desea cumplir con toda su clientela.

loans.use: purchase of meats and drinks

loans.name: Oumou

texts.fr:
Ms. Oumou B. is 38 years old and lives with her four children and her husband in a monogamous family in the Angoulême district of the city of Ségou (Republic of Mali). At a young age, she started working to earn an income that she was obliged to put on the back-burner for school purposes. Privileged with a masters degree in elementary school instruction, she returned to commerce by specializing in the sale of Wax-brand pagnes (traditional print cloth), beauty products, and women's jewelry. She has been associated with Soro Yiriwaso for two years now. After having wrapped up an initial group loan with an association in her district, she is on her second individual loan, and each of her preceding loans has been properly repaid. She intends to use this loan to buy 40 lengths of Wax pagnes (very popular cloth among women), 20 pairs of shoes, 25 pairs of earrings, and 20 boxes of beauty products.

She gets her stock of goods exclusively from Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali) from wholesalers renown in the domain of her specialization, namely beauty products and Wax pagnes. Her boutique, located in the Darsalam district, is easy to reach. She sells at the retail level, accepting cash or credit, payable monthly particularly for salaried workers. Her customers are composed mostly of women. She hopes to realize a monthly profit of 50,000 francs CFA, which will serve to cover the loan interest and to initiate the construction of her house.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Madame Oumou B. est âgée de 38 ans, vit avec ses 4 enfants, son mari dans une famille monogame au quartier Angoulême de la ville de Ségou. (République du Mali) Dès son jeune âge elle commença les activités génératrices de revenus qu’elle fut obligée de mettre en veilleuse pour des raisons d’études. Nantie d’un diplôme de maître de l’enseignement fondamental, elle reprend les activités économiques en se spécialisant dans la vente de pagnes wax, des produits de beauté et des bijoux pour femmes. Elle est en relation avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir bouclé un premier prêt de groupe avec une association de son quartier elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 40 pièces de pagnes wax (tissu très prisé par les femmes), 20 paires de chaussures ; 25 paires de boucles d’oreilles et 20 cartons de produits de beauté.

Elle s’approvisionne exclusivement à partir de Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) auprès de grossistes reconnus du domaine de sa spécialisation à savoir les produits de beauté et les pagnes wax. Sa boutique située au quartier Darsalam est d’accès facile. Elle vend en détail au comptant et à crédit payable mensuellement surtout aux salariés. Sa clientèle est composée en grande majorité de femmes.. Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000 FCFA qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt et à commencer la construction de sa maison.

loans.use: To buy jewelry, beauty products, shoes, and pagnes

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Soro Yiriwaso, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Luis

texts.es:
Luis is 36 years old, and has been living with Juana, 35, for the last ten years. They do not have children.

Luis comes from a poor family; his family's bad financial situation forced him to start working to support himself and help his family right after finishing secondary school.

Now Luis offers delivery and moving services using his small truck. His services take him to different places in town. He also uses his truck to sell all kinds of merchandise, from breads to cold meats and cooking oil. Juana is a housewife.

He began this business 15 years ago while helping his mother with her own traveling sales business. He used to travel to different cities offering different products. Little by little he made his own customers and began working on his own.

This time Luis is requesting a loan to repair his vehicle, and to buy a camper for the back of the truck to work more comfortably.

Translated from Spanish by Maria B., Kiva volunteer

Luis tiene 36 años de edad, vive en pareja hace 10 años con Juana que tiene 35 años. A pesar de la cantidad de tiempo que ya tienen viviendo juntos no han podido tener hijos.

Como Luis provenía de una familia humilde, sólo logró terminar la secundaria, debiendo a partir de ese momento salir a trabajar para lograr el sustento diario.

Actualmente posee una camioneta que utiliza para realizar fletes hasta distintos puntos de la ciudad ya sea para mudanzas o envío de mercaderías. También, cuando tiene oportunidad, sale a vender todo tipo de mercaderías en la misma: desde panificados hasta embutidos y aceites. Su pareja se dedica a los quehaceres del hogar.

Hace 15 años que Luis se dedica a tales actividades. Cuenta que comenzó ayudando a su madre que realizaba viajes a distintas ciudades del interior ofreciendo todo tipo de mercaderías. Con el tiempo él fue ganando su propia clientela y logró hacerse camino por cuenta propia.

En esta oportunidad necesita de un préstamo para realizar algunas reparaciones a su vehiculo y para la compra de cubiertas a fin de ponerlo a punto para trabajar más cómodamente.

loans.use: Pay for truck repair

loans.name: Danaya(La Confiance) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Danaya group are married women, most of whom live in polygamous households. Their average age is thirty, with an average of two children per family. They live in the Médine neighborhood of the city of Sikasso (Republic of Mali). They are known as local figures in their neighborhood. They trade in fabrics, peanut and palm oils, grains, tubers, beauty products, various other foodstuffs, and incense. In the interest of widening the scope of their activities the women of the Danaya group decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso, who agreed to grant them an initial loan. With this loan, they intend to buy ten pieces of wax-printed fabric (a highly prized commodity in Western Africa), twenty liters of cooking oil, five sacks of yams, five boxes of beauty products and five kilograms of incense. Typically, they restock in Sikasso and in the surrounding villages, and sell their goods wholesale or retail in Sikasso, accepting cash or credit payment. Their merchandise is displayed either spread out on tables at market, or put in carts and sold door to door. Their customers are mainly female, although they occasionally have male clients as well. They expect to realize a profit of 20,000 CFA francs, which will serve to provide for the daily needs of their households, pay off the interest on their loan and reinvest in their business.

Translated from French by Jonah Durning-Hammond, Kiva Volunteer.

Les membres du groupe Danaya sont des femmes mariées vivant en générale dans des foyers polygames avec un âge moyen de 30 ans, 2 enfants et qui résident dans le quartier Médine de la ville de Sikasso.(République du Mali). Elles se sont connues dans le quartier en raison du voisinage. Elles font généralement le commerce de tissus, d’huile d’arachide et de palme, des céréales, des tubercules, des produits de beauté, de divers articles alimentaires et de l’encense. Dans le souci d’augmenter la taille de leurs activités les femmes du groupe Danaya ont décidé ensemble de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso qui accepta de leur octroyer leur un premier prêt. Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt 10 pièces de pagnes Wax (Tissus très prisé en Afrique de l’ouest), 20 litres d’huiles de cuisson, 5 sacs d’ignames , 2 catons de produits de beauté et 5 kg d’ensences . Généralement, elles se ravitaillent à sikasso et dans les villages environants pour les revendre sur place à Sikasso en détails ou en gros au comptant ou à crédit. Les marchandises sont soit étalées sur des tables(au marché) ou mises dans des tasses pour les vendre de porte en porte. La clientèle est composée de femmes et quelques fois des hommes. Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice de 20. 000FCFA, lequel sera utilisé pour subvenir aux dépenses quotidiennes des familles, payer les intêrets du prêt et investir le reste dans leurs activités.

loans.use: Purchase of fabrics, foodstuffs, beauty products and incense

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Soro Yiriwaso, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Finesse Group

texts.fr:
The Finesse group is made up of married women, mostly from polygamous households. Their average age is 28; each has, on average, two children. They live in the Médine neighborhood of the city of Sikasso, in the third economic region of Mali. These women buy and sell wax-printed fabric (highly prized in West Africa), food oils, potatoes, sweet potatoes, yams, and beauty products (creams, pomades, and baby powder), as well as various other commodities. Linked by family relations and by this business partnership, they decided to pursue their first loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. With this loan they intend to buy five units of wax-printed fabric, ten liters of oils, twenty sacks of yams, and ten cartons of beauty products. They typically buy their stock from wholesalers at the central market in Sikasso, as well as from peasants who grow fruits and vegetables in the surrounding areas. Then, they resell their commodities at their market stall. Most of their clients pay in cash, although sometimes they pay with credit. The clientele is principally female. They expect to turn a monthly profit of 22500 CFA francs, which will be used to pay the interest on their loan and to reinvest in their business. Each woman hopes to become a wholesaler of fabric or of fruits and vegetables.

Translated from French by Jonah Durning-Hammond, Kiva Volunteer.

Le groupe Finesse es composé de femmes mariées vivant en générale dans des foyers polygames avec une moyenne d’âge de 28 ans, 2 enfants et résidant dans le quartier Médine de de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région économique du Mali) Ces femmes exercent le commerce de pagnes wax (tissus très prisé en Afrique de l’ouest), d’huiles de consommation , de patates douces, de pommes de terre, d’ignames, de produits de beauté (crèmes laits pommades et poudre pour enfant) et divers autres articles. Unies par relations de parenté et d’alliance, les femmes du groupe décidèrent d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur premier prêt. Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter 5 pièces de pagnes, 10 litres d’ huiles, 20 sacs d’ignames, 10 cartons de produits de beauté. Elles s’approvisionnent généralement au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso auprès des grossistes attitrés et dans les localités environantes auprès de paysans producteurs de fruits et légumes. Ensuite elles viennent revendre ces articles dans les quartiers de façon ambulante, dans les marchés avec une place fixe sous des hangars. Les ventes sont en majorité au comptant et quelques fois à crédit. La clientèle est composée essentiellement des femmes . Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 22.500FCFA, lequel sera utilisé pour payer les intêrets du prêt et investir le reste dans leurs activités. Chacune d’elle compte devenir une commerçante grossiste de tissus ou de fruits et légumes.

loans.use: Purchase of foodstuffs and beauty products

loans.name: Elena De La Cruz Group

texts.es:
The group Elena de la Cruz comes from a beautiful town on the shores of Lake Atitlan called Santa Cruz la Laguna. The residents of Santa Cruz have the good fortune of waking up each day and experiencing the beauty of the lake at first sight. This town is divided between the indigenous residents, who live their lives in a very traditional way, and a group of expatriates who are currently investing a great deal in the tourism industry.

The women of Santa Cruz used to live in absolute poverty and without much hope of getting ahead, until a few years ago when “Gringa Lil” began to organize women together to request loans from microfinance institutions. Thanks to the efforts of this industry the town began to grow. This is how the Friendship Bridge began operations in Santa Cruz.

All of the women work with textiles. Half of the group work as weavers of huipiles (typical blouses) and rebosos (scarves), while the other half work as embroiderers. They embroider the huipiles or beautiful colorful blouses. They reinvest their profits in the purchase of threads to weave or embroider their fabrics.

The Elenas de la Cruz sell their products in the market of their town. They also sell in neighboring towns. The interesting thing is that from Santa Cruz to other potential markets like Jaibalito and Tzununa, one can only reach them by boat. The ladies load their baskets with merchandise and then proceed to carry the baskets on their heads to the boats which carry them to neighboring towns.

This group of women would like to continue investing in their businesses, because they want their businesses to grow in order to continue helping their families. They dream that their children will be able to continue going to school all the way to graduation. You can help them reach their dreams. Support them!

Translated from Spanish by Kristy Placido, a Kiva volunteer.

El grupo Elena de la Cruz proviene de un bello pueblo a las orillas del lago Atitlán llamado Santa Cruz la laguna. Los pobladores de Santa Cruz tienen la fortuna de poder levantarse todos los días y experimentar la belleza del lago a primera vista. Este pueblo está dividido entre los pobladores indígenas, los cuales viven sus vidas de una manera muy tradicionales y un grupo de expatriados que actualmente están invirtiendo mucho en la industria del turismo.

Las mujeres de Santa Cruz vivían en la pobreza absoluta y sin mucha esperanza de salir adelante, hasta que hace unos cuantos años la “gringa Lil” empezó a juntar a mujeres para que solicitaran préstamos a las instituciones de microfinanzas. Gracias a este esfuerzo esta industria empezó a crecer en este bello pueblo. Así fue como The Friendship Bridge empezó operaciones en Santa Cruz.

Todas las mujeres trabajan en el área textil. La mitad del grupo trabaja como tejedoras de huipiles (blusas típicas) y rebosos (pañuelos), mientras que la otra mitad trabaja como bordadoras. Ellas bordan los huipiles o bellas blusas de colores. Ellas invierten su crédito en la compra de hilos para tejer o bordar sus tejidos.

Las Elenas de la Cruz venden sus productos en el mercado de su pueblo. Ellas, también venden sus productos en los pueblos aledaños. Lo interesante es que de Santa Cruz a los otros mercados potenciales como Jaibalito y Tzununa solo se puede llegar por lancha. Las señoras arman sus canastos con mercadería y proceden a cargar los canastos en sus cabezas hasta las lanchas las cuales la llevan hasta los mercados de los pueblos aledaños.

Este grupo de señoras quieren seguir invirtiendo en sus negocios porque ellas quieren que sus negocios puedan seguir creciendo para seguir ayudando a sus familias. Ellas sueñas con que sus hijos puedan seguir estudiando hasta terminar una carrera. Ustedes pueden lograr que ellas cumplan con sus sueños, ¡apóyenlas!

loans.use:
The purchase of threads to weave or embroider their textiles.

Ellas invierten su crédito en la compra de hilos para tejer o bordar sus tejidos.

loans.name: Sindiya (La Fraternité) Group

texts.fr:
United by geographical proximity and business partnership, the members of the Sindiya group are married women, mostly from polygamous households. Their average age is 38, and most have two children. They live in the Médine neighborhood of the city of Sikasso, in the third economic region of Mali. The group buys and sells wax-printed cloth (a favorite of Malian women) and food products (oils, bananas, eggs). This is their first foray into microfinance, and are collaborating with Soro Yiriwaso. The women of the Sindiya group want to use their loan to buy ten units of wax-printed cloth, a 25-liter drum of oil, ten sacks of yams, one hundred bunches of bananas, a supply of chicken eggs, etc. They purchase food products exclusively in the villages surrounding Sikasso, while they buy cloth and oil from wholesalers in the city market. They then sell their goods retail and wholesale in Sikasso, selling door-to-door and often on credit. The merchandise is sold from carts or from their stall in the Médine marketplace. Their clientele includes members of all social levels. They foresee a profit of 20,000 CFA francs, which they will use in part to support their families and pay off the interest on the loan; they will reinvest the remainder in their business.

Translated from French by Jonah Durning-Hammond, Kiva Volunteer.

Liées par des liens de voisinage et des liens professionnels, les membres du groupe Sindiya sont des femmes mariées vivant en générale dans les foyers polygames avec en moyenne d’âge de 38 ans, et 2 enfants. Elles résident dans le quartier Médine de Sikasso(troisième région économique de la république du Mali). L’activité principale de ce groupe est le petit commerce de pagnes wax (tissus preférés des femmes du Mali) et de produits alimentaires (huiles, bananes, ouefs de volailles). Elles sont à leur prémière expérience de collaboration avec une institution de micro finance notamment Soro Yiriwaso. Les femmes veulent acheter avec ce prêt 10 pièces pagnes, 1 bidon de 25 litres d’huiles,10 sacs d’ignames, une centaine de régimes de bananes, 10 alvéoles d’oeufs de poules etc.) Elles se ravitaillent exclusivement dans les villages environants pour les produits alimentaires. Par contre l’huile et les pagnes wax sont achetés auprès des grossistes du grand marché de Sikasso. Elles revendent dans la ville de sikasso en détails, en gros et au comptant très souvant en ambulant. Les marchandises sont souvent mises dans des tasses pour les vendre de porte en porte ou etalées sur des tables sous des hangars au marché de Médine. La clientèle est constituée de toutes les catégories sociales de cette ville. Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice de 20.000FCFA, quelles utiliseront en partie pour subvenir aux dépenses familliales, à payer les intêrets du prêt et investir le reste dans leurs activités.

loans.use: Purchase of foodstuffs and printed cloth

loans.name: Koura

texts.fr:
Madame Koura B. is a 61-year-old widow who lives with her three children (one boy, two girls) in the home of her late husband in Médine, a working-class neighborhood in Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali. Having been unable to attend school for social reasons, and wishing to be economically active, she explored without success various occupations as ways to earn income. Being very enterprising and courageous in commercial matters, she decided to specialize in the production and sale of biscuits. She began this occupation twenty years ago; today, she enjoys a good reputation and a loyal and growing client base. To meet this growing demand, she approached the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution to obtain additional financial resources. With this loan, she intends to purchase five sacks of wheat flour, four drums of oil and three sacks of sugar. The flour is mixed with water and sugar in a cup; this dough is then rolled into balls and cooked in oil. She purchases her raw materials from shopkeepers at the central market in Sikasso, and sells her wares retail in the same market, for cash and occasionally on credit. Her clientele is made up mainly of women, of stallkeepers and of other people working in the market. Madame Koura B. foresees a monthly profit of 30,000 CFA francs. Since circumstances have made her the head of her family, she intends to use a large portion of this profit to provide for her children’s needs.

Translated from French by Jonah Durning-Hammond, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame Koura B. est une veuve de 61 ans qui vit avec ses 3 enfants (1 garçon et 2 filles) dans la maison de son feu époux à Médine, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). N’ayant pas eu à fréquenter l’école pour des raisons sociales, et dans le souci de s’intégrer dans la vie économique elle ména plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus sans réussite.Très entreprenante et courageuse dans les activités commerciales, elle décida de se spécialisesr dans la fabrication et vente de galettes à base de farine de blé depuis maintenant 20 ans. Madame Koura B. Jouit d’une grande réputation et d’une clientèle fidèle et en nette croissance. Pour faire face à cette demande, elle s’adressa à l’Institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso pour obtenir des ressources financières additionnelles. Avec ce prêt, elle compte acheter 5 sacs de farine de blé, 4 bidons d’huile et 3 sacs de sucre. La poudre de farine est mélangée avec de l’eau et du sucre dans une tasse pour ensuite être cuite par boulette dans de l’huile de cuisson. Pour les matières prémières, elle se ravitaille exclusivement à Skasso auprès des boutiquiers du grand marché et effectue ses ventes en détail au comptant et quelques fois à crédit au même marché. Sa clientèle est composée essntiellement de femmes, de forains et des employers travaillant au niveau du marché. Madame Koura B. envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30.000 FCFA. Etant chef de famille par la force des choses, elle compte utiliser une grande partie du bénéfice pour subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants.

loans.use: Purchase of wheat flour, sugar and oil

loans.name: Maïmouna

texts.fr:
Madame Maïmouna T. is twenty-seven years old and lives with her two children and her husband in a monogamous household in the Bougoulaville neighborhood in downtown Sikasso, in the third administrative district of Mali. For economic reasons, she did not attend school, but quickly took interest in income-generating activities. Since 2004, she has been particularly focused on the purchase and sale of clothing, baby powder and various other commodities.

Due to her lack of personal funds and a growing demand for her services, she sought the help of the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, which is coordinating this loan. She intends to buy ten dozen bottles of baby powder, twenty handbags, twenty pairs of women’s shoes and two boxes of beauty products.

She restocks monthly in the city of Bobo Dioulasso, in neighboring Burkina Faso. She sells her wares in her home as well as at the central market in Sikasso. Her business caters mainly to young women and new mothers. Most of her sales are retail and paid in cash. She has a loyal client base.

The profit from this loan, which is estimated at 100,000 CFA francs, will help cover the costs of family life, pay the interest on the loan, and provide further funds for her business.

Translated from French by Jonah Durning-Hammond, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame Maïmouna T. a 27 ans et vit avec ses 2 enfants et son époux dans une famille monogame au quartier Bougoula-ville au centre ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Pour des raisons économiques elle n’a pas fréquenté l’école et s’est très vite interessée aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat vente d’habits, de poudre pour enfants et d’articles divers depuis 2004. En raison de l’insuffissance de son fonds propre et en raison de la demande croissante, elle décida de solliciter la collabration de Soro Yiriwaso qui vient de lui octroyer un premier prêt. Elle compte acheter 10 douzaines de Poudre pour enfant, 20 sacs à main féminins, 20 paires de chaussures feminines et 2 cartons de produits de beauté. Elle s’approvisionne à Bobo Dioulasso (république du Burkina Faso un pays limitrophe de la république du Mali) généralement une fois par mois. Elle vend ses articles au grand marché de Sikasso et au niveau du domicile conjugal. Sa clientèle est composée essentiellement de femmes, de démoiselles et des nouvelles mamans. Ses ventes se font généralement en détail au comptant et rarement à crédit à une clientèle très fidèle. Le bénéfice estimé à 100.000 FCFA servira aux dépenses familiales en appui à son mari, à payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.

loans.use: Purchase of handbags, beauty products and women's shoes

loans.name: Top-Up Group

texts.en:
Pictured are Osman C., Unisa K., Mummy G. and Hawa S.. Their group is called Top-up, named after the main product the group leader is selling. They have finished repaying their previous loan with SMT. That loan helped their businesses grow, increased profit and improved on the members living conditions. Another loan of Le 4,000,000 loan will help give strength to their businesses.

The leader of this group is Osman C.. Osman is 35 and was born in Yele, Tonkolili district. He is married with 2 children. Osman owes a tele-centre. Here, he makes telephone calls for people, sells top-up cards, phone batteries, recharges mobile phones (as 95% of the people do not have electricity, people pay Le 1,000.00 for their phones to be recharged) and so on. Other members of the group also sell top-ups, cigarettes, mints, candles, biscuits, under-wears, bras, childrens` clothes, fish and so on.

loans.use: Expand on their current businesses.

loans.name: Mariam Chaka

texts.fr:
Mademoiselle Mariam Chaka C. is an unmarried student of education at the Teacher Training Institute in Sikasso. She lives with her younger siblings, her mother and her father in Médine, a working-class neighborhood of Sikasso, in the third administrative district of Mali.

She is working a paying job in addition to her coursework. Having learned about commerce from her mother, a well-known storekeeper in Sikasso, she has been able to reconcile her academic activities with her commercial ones (the sale of clothing and sundries). She has been involved with the Soro Yiriwaso microlending organization for a year; she has received and paid back a student loan, and is seeking her first personal commercial loan. With it, she will buy nine units of ITAGET-brand wax-printed fabric, ten sets of bedsheets, ten units of embroidered cloth, twenty pairs of men’s and women’s shoes, and twenty break-resistant necklaces.

She usually purchases her stock from her mother and sells it elsewhere in the city. With this loan, she hopes to purchase stock in Bobo Dioulasso, in neighboring Burkina Faso, and in Lomé, the capital city of nearby Togo. Her clientele consists mainly of young women, married and otherwise, from her school and from her neighborhood. She sells her goods out of her home, at school and on foot around town, taking payment in cash and often on credit.

The projected profit is estimated at 150,000 CFA francs, which will provide for both personal and family expenditures, pay off the interest on the loan, and be reinvested in her business.

Translated from French by Jonah Durning-Hammond, Kiva Volunteer.

Mademoiselle Mariam Chaka C. est une célibataire, élève-maître à l’Institut de Formation des Maîtres ( IFM de Sikasso ) qui vit avec ses cadets, sa mère et son père dnas une familles nucléaire à Médine, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).

Malgré les études d’enseignants en cours, elle mène parallèlement des activités génératrices de revenus. Son apprentissage s’est effectué auprès de sa mère une grande commerçante très connue au niveau de la ville de Sikasso. Ainsi elle a su concilier ses activités scolaires et ses activités commerciales(des habits, des articles divers). En rélation avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis une année, elle a bénéficié du prêt scolaire (que Soro Yiriwaso accorde à toutes les institutions de Formation des Maîtres (IFM) à travers le pays) et est à son premier prêt individuel commerçant. Son prêt prédédent a été correctement remboursé. Elle va acheter avec ce prêt, 9 pièces de pagnes wax “ITAGET”, 10 draps de lit, 10 pièces de tissus brodés, 20 paires de chaussures pour hommes et femmes et 20 paires de colier “chaîne garantie”

Elle se ravitaille habituellement auprès de sa mère à Sikasso pour ensuite revendre dans les différents quartiers de Sikasso. Avec ce pret, elle souhaite aller faire ses achats cette fois ci à Bobo Dioulasso ( république du Burkina Faso) et à Lomé ( capitale de la république du Togo). Sa clientèle est composée essentiellement de démoiselles de son école, de son quartier et des jeunes femmes mariées. Elle vend ses articles à domicile, à l’école et en ville d’une façon ambulante en détail (au comptant et souvent à crédit).

Le bénéfice prévisionnel est estimé à 150.000 FCFA avec lequel elle compte résoudre ses dépenses personnelles, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.

loans.use: Purchase of printed cloth, embroidered cloth and bedsheets

loans.name: Adamu Group

texts.en:
Pictured are Adama B., Rebeca F., Fatmata T. and Ramatu K.. They have finished repaying their previous loan successfully and are now requesting a new one in the maount of Le 3,200,000.00. The new loan, like the previous loan, will help them to improve their businesses even futher Consequently, the living standard of members of this group and their dependents will improve.

Adama B. is the leader of this group. She is 39, and was born in Bombo, a village near Makeni. She is married with 3 children. She sells cigarettes and fish. She has been in this business for 5 years now.

loans.use: To purchase more baskets of fish.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Fight For Shame Group

texts.en:
This group is named Fight For Shame. Its members include Isatu K., Sallay B., and Beti K.. They have finished repaying their previous loan successfully. The previous loan helped them improve thestatus of their businesses, but they are requesting new loan of Le 2,400,000 to further help them improve their businesses.

Isatu K. is the leader of this group. She is 45 and was born in Makeni. Isatu is married with 4 children. Her husband is an architect, and she sells dried fish. She has been in the business for the past 15 years. When Isatu receives the new loan, she will use it to buy cartons of fish and rubbers of oil.

loans.use: Buy more cartons of fish.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Petty-Traders Group

texts.en:
This is Alpha B. and Haja J.. They have finished repaying their previous loan successfully. Group leader Alpha B. described that first loan as a great blessing. The loan helped them improve the size and quality of their products and, consequently, the living standard of these families improved. In order to strengthen their businesses further, they are requesting an additional loan of Le 1,200,000.00.

Alpha is now 43. He was born in Kabala, Northern Sierra Leone. He and his wife and 3 children live in Makeni where he operates his businesses and the children go to school. Mr. Alpha sells items like batteries, torches, gas lights, cigarettes, pastes, tooth brushes, and so on. He has over 10 years of experience in this business.

loans.use: Expand on their current businesses.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Pedro

texts.es:
Pedro is 39 years old, single, and lives with his parents. He has a physical handicap from birth affecting his legs and causing him to walk with difficulty. In spite of this he finished high school with a great deal of sacrifice as the school was located some distance away and he had to walk several blocks to get to school.

Upon finishing his studies he was without work for 2 years. Due to his handicap most businesses did not want to hire him. One day he decided to study for a career as a dental technician. After completing his studies he opened his own workshop which has now been operating for 16 years.

He wishes to obtain more capital in order to increase his stock of materials for the manufacturing of dental prostheses due to the difficulties he has in traveling to obtain them and also due to their high cost. It is for this reason that he is requesting a loan for the purchse of these materials.

Translated from Spanish by Kristy Placido, a Kiva volunteer.

Pedro tiene 39 años, es soltero y vive aún con sus padres. Posee un impedimento físico de nacimiento en las piernas que hace que camine con dificultad. Cuenta que debido a eso terminó el colegio con mucho sacrificio pues el colegio quedaba en una zona retirada y el debía caminar varias cuadras para llegar hasta la escuela.

Al culminar sus estudios secundarios estuvo sin trabajar 2 años debido a su impedimento ya era muy difícil que las empresas quieran contratarlo, hasta que un día decidió estudiar la profesión de Mecánico Dental. Una vez culminados dichos estudios habilitó su propio taller que funciona hace ya 16 años.

Anhela contar con más capital para aumentar su stock de materiales empleados para la elaboración de prótesis dentales, debido a que se le dificulta mucho movilizarse para conseguirlos y además son muy costosos. Es por eso que en esta oportunidad recurre a un préstamo para la compra de dichos materiales.

loans.use: Increase stock of materials for the manufacturing of dental prostheses.

loans.name: Success Group

texts.en:
This picture is of Aminata K. and Isha K.. Other members of the group were not available for a snap shot. They named their group Success. They have repaid their previous loan successfully but they would like an additional loan Le 1,600,000.00 to further help them expand their businesses.

Aminata is the leader of this group. She is 26 years of age. She was born in Moyamba, Southern Sierra Leone. She currently lives in Makeni together with her husband and 1 child. Aminata sells soft drinks, cold water, rum, cigarettes, candles etc. in a small kiosk.

loans.use: Expand on their current businesses.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Artesanas Group

texts.en:
The Artesanas come from the tiny town of Xepatuij and hold their weekly gatherings in the nearby city of Nahuala. Their group was formed 6 years ago but new members have been added over time.

The group has now 10 members and their work varies from weaving traditional blouses called huipiles, embroidering blouses with beautiful designs, sewing skirts, baking and selling bread, and weaving and selling the traditional reboso, a square piece of woven material the women use to carry their children and many other items.

The Artesanas women say that in the country, there is enough space to have business going but there is no clean water and electricity. The living conditions are hard. The city of Nahuala has fewer opportunities, but better living conditions. Working in a trust bank gives them the support socially and in their businesses. Besides that, they benefit from the additional trainings Friendship Bridge offers them.

Where there was no reason to leave the house before, their weekly gathering is a way to relax and is something to look forward to. Dominga T. says this helps to deal with their often difficult lives. Since she started attending the group meetings, she has made friends. The laughing and chatting brings joy to all of their lives.

The women of Artesanas sell their goods in the local market of Nahuala. Some of them have customers coming to their houses to place orders for the traditional skirts. Making a traditional skirt can take up to a week of work. At this moment, selling skirts and other clothes is difficult due to the rainy season when there is little demand.

Maria T. claims that most women stopped hoping to fulfill their own dreams; however, thanks to microfinance, now they can dream of creating opportunities for the next generation. One of the ladies proudly states that before there was not enough money to buy pencils, schoolbooks and bus fares. Now that they are working with Friendship Bridge, the children can go to school and do very well.

loans.use: Purchase thread to elaborate weavings and embroidery and purchase flour for baking bread

loans.name: Comité Atenas Group

texts.es:
The Atenas Group began in November 2007 when one of its founders learned of the program Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras from a neighbor who had formed her own group. She contacted her friends and neighbors who agreed to participate in the program. The group is made up of very hardworking, active women. The members are involved in various activities such as the sale of notions, handicrafts, cosmetics, ice cream, etc.

The Atenas Group is comprised of 17 members who are primarily located in a rural area. Besides the business activities of each one and working as housewives, they also carry out different activities for fundraising for the group such as raffles, dinners, etc. to benefit neighborhood improvements or emergency cases. It should be emphasized that the group has not had a single late payment of previous loans as they are very responsible. They understand the importance of communication and support among everyone.

They now would like a new loan that will be invested in the purchase of t-shirts, pants, shirts, socks, children’s clothing, among other things. They will also purchase various flavors of ice creams, hairdressing items and cosmetics, and notions, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Kristy Placido, a Kiva volunteer.

El Grupo denominado Atenas tuvo su inicio en el mes de Noviembre del Año 2.007, una de las integrantes se enteró del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras por intermedio de una vecina la cual ya había formado su propio grupo. Luego se propuso contactar con sus amigas y vecinas, las cuales accedieron en participar del programa. El comité está conformado por señoras muy trabajadoras y activas. Las integrantes se dedican a distintas actividades como, venta de mercería, artesanías, cosméticos, helados, etc.

El Grupo Atenas esta conformado por 17 integrantes que se encuentra localizado en una zona principalmente rural. Además de las actividades que realizan cada una y de ser amas de casa, ellas también realizan distintas actividades para la recaudación de fondos para el grupo como sorteos, polladas, etc. de los cuales la recaudación obtenida va para mejoras del barrio o casos de emergencia. Cabe destacar que el grupo no tuvo atrasos en el pago de sus cuotas de créditos anteriores ya que son todas muy responsables, las mismas comprenden la importancia comunicativas y solidarias entre todas.

Ellas hoy desean un crédito nuevo que lo invertirán en la compra de ropas como remeras, pantalones, camisas, medias, ropa para niños, entre otros; también compraran helados de distintos gustos, artículos para peluquería, al igual que cosméticos, y artículos de mercería, etc.

loans.use: Loan will be invested in the purchase of t-shirts, pants, shirts, socks, children’s clothing, various flavors of ice creams, hairdressing items and cosmetics, and notions, etc.

loans.name: Divino Niño Jesús Group

texts.es:
The group was formed in March 2008 and is made up of 18 hardworking women. The group is lead by María Rosa J. who sells foods. She decided to form her own group, sending invitations to many of her friends, the majority of which were part of a mothers group at the school in their town.

In the Group Divino Niño Jesús all of the members are in good standing with the payment of their balances and they value the opportunities granted to them by the Fundación Paraguaya through this program. They are now in their second cycle and are requesting a total sum of G. 7.600.000.

The group is very united and supportive as they help one another and the group continues to progress. All of them come from economic disadvantage but they are very hardworking. They wish to provide greater economic stability to their children and to be able to collaborate with their husbands to increase their household income.

This group will use the loan in order to buy milk, cheese, tobacco, sweets, fruits, chickens, flour, sugar, noodles, and vegetables among other things to sell, as these women primarily sell these products.

Translated from Spanish by Kristy Placido, a Kiva volunteer.

El Grupo fue constituido en el mes de marzo del 2.008, el Comité está integrado por 18 mujeres emprendedoras. El grupo es liderado por la señora María Rosa J. la cual se dedica a la venta de comidas, la misma decidió conformar su propio Comité realizando varias invitaciones a sus compañeras ya que la mayoría de ellas forma parte de una comisión de madres en una escuela de la pueblo.

En el Grupo Divino Niño Jesús todas las integrantes son muy cumplidas con el pago de sus cuotas y valoran la oportunidad que brinda la Fundación Paraguaya mediante éste programa. Ellas se encuentran en el segundo ciclo, en forma global desean retirar el monto de G. 7.600.000.

El grupo es muy unido y solidario ya que todas se ayudan entre sí para que el Comité vaya progresando. Todas son de escasos recursos pero muy emprendedoras, las mismas desean poder brindar una mejor estabilidad económica a sus hijos y poder colaborar con sus esposos al dar un ingreso más en sus hogares.

Este grupo retira el crédito para comprar leche, queso, tabaco, golosinas, frutas, gallinas, harina, azúcar, fideos, verduras entre otros para la venta, ya que estas señoras se dedican principalmente a la venta de estos productos.

loans.use: This group will use the loan in order to buy milk, cheese, tobacco, sweets, fruits, chickens, flour, sugar, noodles, and vegetables.

loans.name: Kuña Kyre´y Group

texts.es:
This group was formed in the month of November, 2007, thanks to the hardwork of the president of the group, Sandra M. Rodríguez, who approached the Fundación Paraguaya in order to learn more about the program. Since its inception the group Kuña Kyre'y (Active Woman) has supported solidarity, unity, and friendship.

It is based on these principles that the group is able to make payments on time and have weekly meetings with the goal of communicating problems and generating solutions to any problems that arise. They organize profitable activities with the goal of creating a good foundation so that they can help if one of the members finds herself having problems.

The members of the Group are committed to this program, which represents financial and social help for all of them. Economic help comes from access to low-interest, easily-accessible loans which are easy to repay. Social help comes from the help the women provide to each other in joining and starting projects individually as well as promoting fundamental human values for the good relationships of the Comité.

The total loan amount requested is 11,100,000 Paraguayan Guaranies, and will be used primarily for the purchase of clothing such as t-shirts, pants, shirts, socks, undergarments, shoes, and also to purchase ingredients for the preparation of cakes and other foods as the majority of the women sell these things.

Translated from Spanish by Kristy Placido, a Kiva volunteer.

El Grupo fue constituido en el mes de noviembre del 2.007, gracias a la acción emprendedora de la presidenta del Comité, Sandra M. Rodríguez quien fue la que se acercó a la Fundación Paraguaya a fin de conocer las bases y condiciones del programa, desde sus inicios el grupo Kuña Kyre'y (Mujer Activa) se apoyo en la solidaridad, unidad y compañerismo.

Sostenidos en éstos pilares es como realizan sus pagos en el tiempo establecido y sus reuniones semanales a fin de comunicar sus problemas y generar posibles soluciones ante cualquier eventualidad, organizan actividades rentables a fin de contar con un buen fondo con el cual puedan ayudar si alguna de las compañeras se encuentra en algún problema.

Los miembros del Grupo manifiestan su conformidad hacia el programa ya que el mismo representa ayuda económica y social para todas, refiriéndose las mismas a lo económico ya que pueden contar con préstamos de bajo interés y de rápido acceso y con facilidad de pago y en lo social por que ayuda a cada una de ellas a integrarse y a emprender proyectos en forma individual y promueve a que las mismas tengan como fundamento los valores humanos para el buen relacionamiento del Comité.

El monto solicitado en forma global es de guaraníes 11.100.000 y lo utilizaran principalmente para la compra de ropas como remeras, pantalones, camisas, medias, lencería, zapatos, además de comprar ingredientes para la elaboración de tortas y comidas pues la mayoría de ellas se dedica a la venta de estos.

loans.use:
The purchase of clothing, flour, sugar, vanilla, meats, dairy products, breads, salt, noodles, vegetables, fruits, soft drinks, etc.

Compra de ropas, harina, azúcar, vainilla, carnes, lácteos, panificados, sal, fideos, verduras, frutas, enlatados, gaseosas, etc.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria P. has used her Esperanza Bank of Hope loan to run two business: She and her husband Miguel manage a general store selling kitchen essentials and snacks on one side of her home, and a clothing store on the other.  The couple still support two of their seven children, and Maria says that she plans to continue to work hard so that they don't have to work as hard as she has.  With her future loans, Maria hopes to expand her clothing business.

loans.use: Colmado de Maria (food and clothing sales)

loans.name: Oñondivepa Group

texts.es:
The Group was formed in the month of June, 2008, thanks to the hard work of the director of the school Perpetuo Socorro which invited the mothers of the families of that institution to participate in an informative chat at the school. That meeting was attended by 16 women who now are part of the group Todas Juntas (All Together).

The members are involved in various business activities such as: the sale of food, the sale of silver jewelry, chipas (a traditional bread snack), fruits, vegetables, clothing, etc. Everyone participates in weekly meetings and they work actively together on all of the activities the group develops.

This is the first cycle of the program Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras that the Fundacion Paraguaya is developing. Each group member will take on average Gs. 300.000 and the group would like a loan of a total sum of Gs. 4.700.000. This is a very well-organized group in which unity and solidarity are of utmost importance to all of the group members.

Translated from Spanish by Kristy Placido, a Kiva volunteer.

El Grupo fue constituido en el mes de junio del 2.008, gracias a la acción emprendedora de la directora de la Escuela Perpetuo Socorro quien invitó a las madres de familia de dicha institución a participar de una charla informativa en el local de la escuela. En dicha reunión asistieron 16 mujeres, quienes integran hoy el Comité denominado Oñondivepá (Todas Juntas).

Las integrantes se dedican a diversas actividades tales como: venta de comidas, joyas de plata, chipas, frutas y verduras, ropas, etc. Todas participan de las reuniones semanales y trabajan de manera activa en todas las actividades que el grupo desarrolla.

Se encuentran en el primer ciclo del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras que desarrolla la Fundación Paraguaya. Cada una retira en promedio Gs. 300.000 y el grupo retira en total la suma de Gs. 4.700.000. Es un grupo muy bien organizado en donde prima la unidad y solidaridad entre todas las integrantes.

loans.use:
Purchase of merchandise for sale such as meat, sugar, flour, noodles, fruits, and vegetables. Also coal, silver jewelry and clothing.

compra de mercaderías para despensa como carne, azúcar, harina, fideos, carbón, frutas y verduras. También carbón, joyas de plata y ropas.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase 8 sets of rings, 8 piston units, 10 thrust units, 10 O'rings, 10 retainers for oil, 2 propeller units, 10 boxes of gear lubricant, and 10 units of spark plugs NGKB8HSUS for outboard motors.

payments.comment: La cuota real es de $ 83.33 dólares

loans.name: Luis Adolfo

texts.es:
Luis Adolfo, a young 29 year old who lives in the Laureles Norte neighborhood, is single and does not have any children yet. He sells ceramic tiles, a business that he initiated 8 years ago. At first, the most difficult part was the acquisition of a location in order to set up shop. The business started with little inventory which he purchases with his own savings. However, it has grown over time and he has been able to increase sales. The use of this loan will be for the purchase of more ceramic tiles in order to reinforce his inventory, since his plans are to grow in order to have more locations where he can offer his products.

Tranlsated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer.

Luis Adolfo, un joven de 29 años que habita en el barrio Laureles Norte, es soltero y todavía no tiene hijos. Se dedica a la venta de cerámica, negocio que inició hace 8 años, y que al principio lo más difícil fue la adquisición de un local para realizar sus ventas, el negocio lo empezó con poco inventario ya que solamente contaba con ahorros personales, pero a través de este tiempo ha ido creciendo y ha podido aumentar su negocio. El uso del préstamo será para la compra de más cerámica para fortalecer su inventario ya que sus planes son crecer para tener más locales en los que ofrecer su producto.

loans.use: Reinforcement of inventory through the purchase of ceramic tiles.

loans.name: Francisco Nicolás

texts.es:
Mr. Francisco P. makes and sells blocks and construction materials. It has been 8 years through which he has had highs and lows, overall because of the competition that is generated by other businesses. He wants to find a central location in the city in order to attract more clients. The loan he is requesting is for the purchase of 130 bags of cement to later offer in block sales. Francisco is 45 years old, has 4 grown children, his wife and life companion supports him through the care and order of their home. They live in the La Primavera neighborhood, the same place where his business is located.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva volunteer

Don Francisco P. se dedica a la elaboración y venta de bloques y materiales de construcción, han sido 8 años en los que ha tenido altas y bajas, sobre todo por la competencia que generan otros negocios. Quiere encontrar un local céntrico en la ciudad para así poder captar más clientes. El préstamo lo solicita para la compra de 130 bolsas de cemento para después ofertarla en la bloquera. Don Francisco tiene 45 años de edad, 4 hijos menores de edad, su compañera de vida le apoya con el cuido y manejo de su casa de habitación. Habita en el barrio La Primavera mismo lugar donde tiene su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase of 130 bags of cement.

loans.name: Indira Cyntia

texts.es:
Indira is a young, single mother. She is 24 years old and has a 3 year old son. They live in the La Primavera neighborhood with her family. Indira sells various merchandise such as shoes and clothing. She has 2 years experience with these sales, and started in light of the need to have greater income with whic to raise her son. She started with her own funds which is why there has not been much inventory or variety. She needs the loan for the purchase of women's shoes and clothing and as such increase and diversify her sales.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva volunteer.

Indira es una joven madre soltera, tiene 24 años de edad, y un hijo de 3 años, habita en el Barrio La Primavera con su familia. Indira se dedica a la venta de mercadería variada como lo son zapatos y ropa, tiene 2 años de tener estas ventas, comenzó en vista a la necesidad de tener un ingreso con el que pudiera mantener a su hijo, empezó con fondos propios y es por eso que el inventario y la variedad no han sido muchas. Requiere del préstamo para la compra de zapatos y ropa de damas y así ampliar y diversificar sus ventas.

loans.use: Purchase of women's clothing and shoes.

loans.name: Aldo Alberto

texts.es:
Aldo Ramirez, with the help of his first loan, was able to invest in the improvement of his business. He acquired equipment for the internet in addition to library products. With this loan he will buy a computer to put in his cybercafe and as such continue with the planned growth for his business. He hopes to be able to complete his cybercafe by putting in a cafeteria so that he can provide full service. The previous loan he repaid early and has demonstrated a habit of timely payment, and hopes to be able to receive a new loan. Aldo is single, is 28 years old and lives in the America 4 neighborhood. He is originally from the Atlantic coast. He finished his studies and emigrated to the city in search of better opportunities and a better life.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

Aldo R. con la ayuda de su primer préstamo pudo invertir en la mejora de su negocio, adquirió equipos para el cyber así como también productos de librería. Con este préstamo comprará una computadora para invertirla en el cyber y así seguir el crecimiento planeado para su negocio. Espera poder completar su cyber poniendo en él una cafetería para así poder ofrecer el servicio completo. El préstamo anterior lo pagó anticipadamente y demostró una cultura de pago muy buena, y espera poder acceder a un nuevo crédito. Aldo es soltero, tiene 28 años de edad, habita en el barrio América 4. Es originario de la Costa Atlántica, culminó sus estudios y emigró a la ciudad en busca de mejores oportunidades y una mejor vida.

loans.use: Purchase of a computer.

loans.name: Mirtha Del Socorro

texts.es:
Mirtha is requesting a loan for the purchase of beauty products to invest in her business so she can diversify the inventory in the general store she runs from her home in La Primavera, Managua. She has one 14 year old son, who is a student and sometimes helps her with the business. Mirtha is a single mom and is concerned only with her son's future. For this reason she hopes to be able to grow and strengthen her store so that she has sufficient income to ensure the well-being and education of her young son.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer.

El préstamo que está solicitando Doña Mirtha es para la compra de productos de belleza para invertirlos en su negocio y así poder diversificar el inventario que posee en su pulpería ubicada en su casa de habitación en el barrio La Primavera de Managua. Tiene un hijo de 14 años, quien es estudiante y algunas veces le ayuda con la atención del negocio, Mirtha es soltera y ella sola tiene que sacar a su adelante a su hijo, es por eso que espera poder agrandar y fortalecer la pulpería para así contar con suficiente ingresos que le aseguren la manutención y estudios de su hijo adolescente.

loans.use: Purchase of beauty products.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Angeles Group

texts.en:
The members of the Angeles trust bank live in the lovely village of Santa Clara, about 1½ hour away from Sololá. The group was formed 7 years ago, and they requested 6 loans already.

The loans gave them the opportunity T. start a small business and be more independent and self sufficient. It is interesting T. see how they have found a way T. expand their businesses by travelling outside of their own village T. other markets T. sell their products. By travelling T. different markets in surrounding villages and towns they have expanded the number of clientele. They travel T. Sololá, Nahualá, San Pedro, San Pablo and some of the women travel even as far as Quetzaltenango which is three hours away.

Most of the women are working very hard and own two businesses. The group leader Simona S. says: many of us have a plot of land where they grow fruits and vegetables and raise some animals too. So do I. We sell our fruits in the markets ourselves. During the evenings we work on the beautiful regional embroideries. And some of us have a food store where they sell the bread they bake themselves. One of the women even has a little business making canastas: the baskets that all of the women use T. bring their products T. the market Working with the trust bank has given them the opportunity T. improve their living standards. This is because now they can have access T. clean water and electricity. The women share a lot of their ideas in how T. run their business at the weekly meetings. This way they help each other.

During their childhood many of these women could not attend school, and illness and hygiene were crucial problems. However, nowadays their kids have better opportunities and are doing well in school. If we support these women and their respective families together we are helping them, their communities and Guatemala T. develop.

loans.use: purchase food for animals, fertilisers. purchase utilities for embroidery

loans.name: Volver A Empezar Group

texts.es:
The center of Alto Lima is located in the Ballivian zone in the city of El Alto which is where the "Volver a Empezar" Association is found. They work with great responsibility with their payments and internal activities. Within the group, many of the women lack basic services in their homes. For example, doña Verni cannot rely on potable water that should be supplied by public water basins. What's more, like many others, she cannot rely on gas services and must buy gas in tanks. Lamentably, she lives in a zone where distributors of these tanks do not pass very frequently which is why she has to go to busy streets in the hopes that one of these trucks will pass by. She longs to be able to rely on these services in her home. The main activity of this group is the weaving of sweaters, scarves, and other pieces of clothing, in Alpaca wool that they later sell in the "16 de julio" market in the city of El Alto. Currently, they want to be able to increase their production so that they can sell their products to handicraft shops. It is for this that they need more capital for the acquisition of raw materials to make their sweaters. They have the security of increasing their income, in this manner they will also be able to improve the quality of life for their families.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer.

El centro focal de Alto Lima esta ubicada en la zona Ballivian de la ciudad de El Alto, a este pertenece la asociación “ Volver a Empezar ” que trabajan con mucha responsabilidad en cuanto a sus cuotas de crédito y actividades internas. Dentro el grupo muchas de ellas carecen de servicios básicos en sus casas por ejemplo doña Verni no cuenta con agua potable por lo que debe abastecerse de agua en piletas publicas, además como muchos tampoco cuenta con servicio de gas y debe comprar gas en garrafas de distribuidores, lamentable es que ella vive en una zona donde estos camiones distribuidores no pasan muy seguido, por lo que debe ir a calles concurridas a esperar que pase el mencionado camión, ella anhela poder contar con estos servicios en su domicilio. La actividad principal de este grupo es el tejido de chompas, mantillas y otras prendas de vestir, en lana de alpaca que luego las venden en la feria 16 de julio de la ciudad de El Alto. Actualmente desean poder aumentar su producción para, vender sus productos a tiendas artesanales, por lo que necesitan mayor capital para la adquisición de materia prima para la confección de sus chompas. Tienen la seguridad de mejorar sus ingresos, de esta manera mejorar también la calidad de vida de sus familias.

loans.use: They need capital for the purchase of raw materials.

loans.name: Perlas Del Ande Group

texts.es:
Thanks to Pro-Mujer and the work that it has done for more than ten women, they are realizing their desire to better their living standards through the marketing of used clothing. Five years ago these women formed the group Andean Pearls, in which they responsibly work. Early in the morning each week they obtain large bundles of clothing from wholesalers. The then sort the clothing out and sell either in the large market of El Alto, “July 16th,” or at nights in the streets of La Paz.

Business has been more difficult of late due to an increase in the price of bundles of clothing. To overcome this issue the women want to purchase in greater quantities and obtain better bulk prices to increase their profits. For this reason they need capital in order to invest in the large bulk purchase from the wholesalers. Increasing their profits will allow the women to increase their savings and thus secure a good future for their families.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

El comercio de ropa usada es la principal actividad de mas de una decena de mujeres que desean mejorar su estilo de vida, afirman que gracias a Pro-mujer y a su trabajo este deseo sé esta cumpliendo. Estas señoras hace mas de cinco años han formado la asociación “Perlas del Ande” en la que trabajan con mucha responsabilidad. Muy temprano semanalmente adquieren fardos de ropa de mayoristas, que luego de acondicionarlas para su venta las comercializan en la feria “16 de Julio” de la ciudad de El Alto y también en las calles de la ciudad de La Paz de forma ambulante y solo por las noches, actividad que ya no es muy rentable por que los mencionados fardos subieron de precio. Ahora ellas quieren comprar al por mayor para mejorar sus ganancias, por eso necesitan capital para poder invertir en la compra de mercadería al por mayor, de esta manera generar mayores ingresos que les permita ahorrar para el asegurar un buen futuro para sus familias.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing in bulk.

loans.name: Sokheng

texts.en: Mrs. Sokheng K. is a farmer in the Sya Village, Kampong Speu Province. Additionally, she works as a grocer, while her husband, Mr. Reth Chou, collects palm juice to process into palm sugar. He also helps his wife in rice farming when he has spare time. Now that the rainy season has arrived, Mrs. Sokheng K. would like to cultivate rice, but she does not have enough cows to plow the rice field. Therefore, Mrs. Sokheng K. has decided to ask for a loan to buy an additional cow for this purpose. Mrs. Sokheng K. has three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while the others are attending school. Previously, Mrs. Sokheng K. obtained a loan from AMK to start her grocery business, and she fully paid it back.

loans.use: Purchase of a cow to plow a field

loans.name: Eth

texts.en: Mrs. Eth K., 37 years old, has five children, four of whom are employed in a garment factory, while the youngest one is attending school. Mrs. Eth K. herself is a farmer, cultivating crops twice a year. During the rainy season, Mrs. Eth K. cultivates rice, while, in the dry season, she grows other types of crops. Her husband, Mr. Khom Khet, works as a palm juice collector for making palm sugar. The family lives in the Sya Village in Kampong Speu Province, and, even though almost all of its members are involved in various business activities, the family's standard of living is low. In order to improve the living conditions, Mrs. Eth K. has decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets for breeding and start a new business.

loans.use: Purchase of piglets for breeding

loans.name: Estrellas De Panamericana Group

texts.es:
Strips of pork, pickling brine, a little hot pepper, bread and a good and toasted skin are the ingredients in the preparation of the exquisite traditional Bolivian Chola sandwich. These sandwiches are sold in specific parts of the city, primarily in the streets. The sale of these sandwiches is quite common among the 10 women who compose the association “Panamerican Stars,” a long time partner of Pro-Mujer.

Beyond the general street sales, the sandwich also sells well at large events such as soccer games and concerts. Due to the market that is expanding in these specialized sectors it is necessary to increase production of these sandwiches.
