The women of Panamerican Stars request a loan in order to purchase supplies in bulk. It is guaranteed that the women’s sales will increase as will their profits.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

lonjas de carne de cerdo, escabeche, un poco de ají picante, pan sarnita y un cuerito bien crocante, son los ingredientes para preparar los exquisitos y tradicionales Sándwich de Chola (denominación tradicional en algunos lugares del País) Estos se los vende en distintos lugares de la ciudad por lo general de forma ambulante, esta es una actividad muy común dentro la asociación Estrellas de Panamericana” grupo compuesto por 10 mujeres que trabajan hace mucho tiempo con Pro-Mujer Este tipo de sándwich también tiene una buena comercialización en eventos como ser partidos de fútbol, conciertos y otros, por lo que eventualmente necesitan duplicar su producción, es por eso que solicitan créditos para la compra de insumos en cantidad. Es seguro que duplicaran también sus ventas y mejorar ganancias.

loans.use: Purchase of supplies in bulk for preparation of traditional sandwiches.

loans.name: Lean

texts.en:
Mrs. Lean L., 58, is a grocery seller in Chub Village, Siem Reap Province. She earns around $2 per day. Her husband, 70, is a construction worker as well as driving a car taxi and he earns around $3 per day. Together they have one child who is a still young and in school. In order to expand her business and increase their income, Mrs. Lean L. is requesting a loan of US$ 500 to purchase more grocery products to sell. The remainder of the loan will be used to purchase gas to sell. The loan will allow her to expand her grocery selling business and improve the family’s income.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL):

HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products and gas to sell

loans.name: Im

texts.en:
Mr. Im S. O., 33, is married with four children and lives in a part of Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. He has been employed as a high school teacher since 1993. Because his salary is barely enough to cover his family's expenses, Mr. Im S. O. works breeding pigs in his spare time. Basically, pig breeding is going well from day to day and he can make profit about 6 to 7 months when his pigs grow enough for sale. If he converts the amount he makes in to a day it is equal $5.30/day. In addition, his wife sells biscuits, candy, and grocery items near a school where there are a lot of students passing by. She can typically make around $6.50/day of income.

A father of four, Im S. O. would like to request a loan from KIVA to purchase more pigs and pig feeds to supply his livestock.

loans.use: To buy more pigs and pig feeds to supplement her livestock.

loans.name: Sarim

texts.en: Mrs. Sarim H., 48, is a widow and has six children, three of whom are employed in different businesses, while another one is attending school. The remaining two are still too young to study. Mrs. Sarim H. and her children live in the Sya Village, Kampong Speu Province. She is a farmer cultivating crops twice a year. During the rainy season, she cultivates rice; in the dry season, she grows vegetables. Currently, Mrs. Sarim H. is unable to plant rice, because she does not have enough cows to plow the rice field. Therefore, she has decided to ask for a loan to be able to buy another cow for this purpose.  Previously, Mrs. Sarim H. obtained a loan from AMK to buy a cow for breeding, and she fully paid it back.

loans.use: Purchase of a cow to plow a field

loans.name: Sarorn

texts.en: Mrs. Sarorn N. lives in the Sya Village, Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a farmer, while her husband, Chean Chuob, earns income collecting palm juice to process into palm sugar. The couple has four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while two others are attending school. The youngest one is still too young to study. Mrs. Sarorn N. currently faces an obstacle to her farming business, because she does not have enough animals to plow her field. Therefore, she is asking for a loan to buy a cow for this purpose. Mrs. Sarorn N. already has experience with borrowing from AMK - she used the previous loan to buy a cow for breeding, and she has fully paid it back.

loans.use: Purchase of a cow for a farming business

loans.name: Chhun

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhun L. is a mother of three and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her famiL. have temporariL. moved to Phnom Penh, where she is employed as a garment factory worker and her husband operates a motor-taxi business. This couple can typicalL. make around $ 6 per day, which is used to cover their food, their house rental, and other expenses.

Mrs. Chhun would like to request a loan from KIVA to help her husband buy a passenger cart in order to convert from a motor-taxi business to tuk-tuk business, which would allow him to carry more passengers and provide him a better standard of living.

loans.use: Buy a tuk-tuk.

loans.name: Ty

texts.en:
Mr. Ty T., 51, makes charcoal to sell. He sells charcoal, transporting it to get it to the customer’s home. T. buys wood from his villagers and some he finds in the forest by himself. He works hard every day and earns around $7 per day. His wife, 50, grows crops to sell and earns around $1.60 per day. They live with two children in Chub Village, Siem Reap Province.

With increasing customer demand, T. wants to expand his wood charcoal making business and needs a small truck to transport his charcoal to sell. Now T. is requesting a loan of US$ 1,200 to add his savings to purchase a small truck to use for his business. The loan will allow him to increase income: using the truck he can transport a lot of charcoal.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL):

HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To add to his savings to purchase a small truck to use for his business

loans.name: Vann

texts.en: Mrs. Vann K. lives in the Tang Kruos Lech Village, Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a farmer, and her husband, Mr. Chorn Sum, helps her in planting the crops. They have seven children, one of whom is doing housework, while three others are firewood collectors. The remaining three are still too young to work or study. Since her children’s firewood business is doing well, Mrs. Vann K. has decided to ask for a loan to add to her own savings and be able to buy cows for the transportation of firewood that her children sell door-to-door. Previously, Mrs. Vann K. obtained a loan from AMK to buy a cart, and she has fully paid it back.

loans.use: Purchase of cows for the transportation of firewood

loans.name: Phally

texts.en: Mr. Phally S. lives in the Tbeng Khpos Village, Kampong Chhnang Province. He is 24 years old, married, and has a little child. His wife, Mrs. Thol Reab, is a farmer, while Mr. Phally S. earns income charging batteries. However, Mr. Phally S. currently faces an obstacle to his business, because the machine he uses to charge batteries is too old and uses a lot of fuel. Therefore, Mr. Phally S. is asking for a loan to buy a new charger to improve his business and, simultaneously, the environment. Previously, Mr. Phally S. took out a loan from Credit Co. Ltd to buy a cow, and has fully paid it back.

loans.use: Purchase of a new battery charger

loans.name: Hay

texts.en: Mr. Hay B. works as a motorbike-taxi driver in the Dem Popel Village, Kampong Chhnang Province. Additionally, he earns income as a cow sales middleman, buying cows and re-selling them at a higher price. Since his second business is doing well, Mr. Hay B. has decided to ask for a loan to buy another cow for re-sale. His wife, Mrs. Salim Nhoek, is a farmer, and the couple has five children, three of whom are attending school, while the others are still too young to study. Mr. Hay B. already previously took out a loan, which he used to buy a cow to start his business, and succeeded in paying it back.

loans.use: Purchase of cows for sale

loans.name: Rin

texts.en:
Mrs. Rin M., 42, is a farmer as well as raising pigs to sell. She earns around $3.33 per day. Her husband, Mr. Srey ly, 50, is a motorcycle taxi driver who earns around $5.50 per day. They live with three children in Chrey Village, Siem Reap Province. M. works hard every day because she has a big responsibility to take care of her children and cope with the family’s expenses. With the intent of growing her pig-raising business, she is now requesting a loan of US$ 1,000 to purchase more pigs to raise as well as pig feed. She'll use any remainder of the loan to purchase fertilizer to use for her farming business. The loan will allow her to expand her pig-raising business and improve the family’s income.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL):

HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs to raise as well as pig feed and fertilizer to use for farming business
